name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Syria, the situation in Palmyra and the case of Mazen Darwish (2015/2732(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, the fall of Palmyra and Ramadi is a blow to the belief that the fight against ISIS is progressing and that the liberation of Mosul could indeed begin soon. The international coalition that is fighting ISIS from the air is clearly making some progress and has been successful in destroying certain strategic and economic targets, to the detriment and degradation of ISIS/Daesh. The ground offensive, however, clearly has a lot further to go. Relying on an ill-prepared, unwilling Iraqi force and Iranian-backed Shia militias can only achieve so much and, in some cases, is proving to be counterproductive in the campaign for Sunni hearts and minds in Iraq. The fall of Palmyra is of huge concern as we witness one of the world’s greatest ancient ruins – a testament to the great civilisations that have flourished in the Middle East throughout the millennia – being subject to the whims of a band of barbarian philistines. Tragic as this is, however, it is nothing compared to the loss of life, the sexual violence, enslavement and monstrous brutality that ISIS/Daesh is perpetrating across the region, and we will do all that we can today to remember that as part of the debate. As we think of the human cost of the crisis in the Middle East, it is apt also today in this Chamber to discuss the case of Mazen Darwish, who is a victim of the totalitarian-run state that Assad has left to administer. It serves in some sense to remind us where much of the story began. This Parliament stands up for the belief in freedom of speech, and I am proud today again to call for the release of Mr Darwish on those grounds.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Mr President, I think that everyone and everyone shares and regrets and we have words about what is happening in Syria, about the lives lost and the destruction that is happening in places of humanity's cultural and historical heritage.  My problem with this discussion is not so much what is said, I think we share what is said. My biggest problem is about what is not said and what is not said is that these lives that are lost, the places that are destroyed, only exist because there are weapons, because there is war. And we still refuse in this Parliament to take on such basic things as saying that there are responsibilities of countries that sell arms to groups that make terrorism, to groups that destroy lives, to groups that destroy cultural heritage and humanity.  So I would very much like that in the vote that we will have to stop just regretting, having crocodile tears, but move forward for very concrete proposals, particularly with regard to putting a moratorium on the sale of arms for terrorist groups and those that are actually destroying the cultural heritage of humanity, to put a moratorium on the purchase of oil when we speak , for example, oil that is produced in territories that are occupied by the self-proclaimed Islamic State. That would be concrete measures, concrete words to stop talking about lamentations and crocodile tears, as I said, which we always share here.  European countries have a lot of responsibility, unfortunately, in this matter and so do the European institutions. So what I ask of colleagues and colleagues who are in this debate today is that they can support the amendments we are making. These are very simple changes and have to do, as I said, with the condemnation of direct or indirect support, in financial terms, in terms of weapons, in terms of training, of the direct or indirect support that is made to terrorist groups that are destroying this cultural heritage of humanity in Syria, which are destroying so many lives. But there is another issue that is fundamental and I end with it, Mr. President, which has to do with the call that the United Nations has systematically made to us in relation to the World Food Programme, the lack of resources to feed Syrian refugees. We need to increase these resources and I would also like this amendment that we tabled here today to be adopted, because if not what we are going to continue to do is debates like this but no concrete action that can change people's lives.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Author. Mr President, the UNESCO-listed city of Palmyra is first and foremost a symbol. It is a symbol of our cultural heritage and civilization. It is the place of convergence of diverse civilizations of the Middle East and the Near East, a place of progress of spirit and tolerance, as well as the place of origin of freedom of thought and expression.  By seizing the ancient city of Palmyra on May 21, massacring hundreds of people, as well as in Iraq, elsewhere in Syria and Libya, the Islamic State group is once again demonstrating its desire to destroy and annihilate any culture, religion or ideology different from its own. The origins of our civilizations are destroyed, local populations and Christian religious minorities, among others, live in terror, a historical heritage is ravaged, cultural property is stolen and resold to finance terrorist actions, the humanitarian situation continues to worsen. The emergency is serious. When will the European Union finally take concrete action? It's time we took responsibility. Our values, our civilization, our conception of tolerance and human rights are at stake.  What does the High Representative intend to do, what are her concrete plans? We are not here simply to be outraged with words, but to act.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the There is no end to the killing in Syria; In the month of May alone, thousands of people died, including more than 1,400 civilians. The terror of the Islamic State often eclipses the fact that the Assad regime is responsible for the majority of the deaths. Neither the suffering of its own people nor international protests have prevented the Syrian regime from regularly attacking civilian targets with barrel bombs. Anyone who dares to speak out against the regime or against the jihadists in Syria is in danger. Human rights defender Mazen Darwish has also repeatedly raised his voice. He and his colleagues Hani al-Zitani and Hussein Gharit were imprisoned, tortured and tried for their critical words. Yesterday, Mazen Darwish's wife wrote to me about how worried she had been since her husband's disappearance in early May. Yara writes: We must find a solution to end this war madness. It would be a step in the right direction if the government released prisoners such as Mazen and many others who are committed to peaceful and rational solutions.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: Author. – Mr President, unfortunately, the situation in Syria has dramatically escalated in recent months, and the actions carried out by the Assad regime, Daesh and other terrorist groups do not go away, despite the efforts of the international coalition. This time under the siege of Daesh falls the ancient historical city of Palmyra. Palmyra is one of the most important cultural centers of the ancient world, but for Daesh it is an object with important gas fields and part of the strategy of fighting war. The European Union must use its entire toolkit to protect the heritage of Palmyra and other Syrian sites, as well as strengthen its cooperation with the Secretary-General of UNESCO in the fight against cultural cleansing. I pay particular attention to the continued violation of human rights, international humanitarian law, torture and mass arrests by the Assad regime. The arbitrary detention and disappearance of independent journalists, human rights defenders and humanitarian workers are criminal acts that must be condemned and punished.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In hardly any region of the world are human rights violated as systematically as in Syria. Mazen Darwish is one of those brave people who rebel against it. The Assad regime has held him in prison for years, and his fate has been uncertain for several weeks. We must fear for his life. He is a criminal for the regime because he stands up for human rights and democracy. But it is precisely such people who will need a new, free Syria, which I hope will soon exist. Da'esh and Assad agree on one thing: they do not want free and independent people. In Palmyra, Da'esh destroys everything reminiscent of Western civilization, individuality and freedom.

name: Diane JAMES
text: author. – Mr President, the situation and human rights abuses in Syria are intolerable and grotesque. The examples of torture, mutilation, murder and sexual abuse are now legion. A destabilised state, where any attempt to uphold free speech is doomed to personal disaster, with heroic individuals concerned, such as Mr Darwish, consigned to imprisonment and worse. Mr Darwish and people like him deserve our support in their time of need, and by speaking up for the free flow of information they uphold that most fundamental tenant of democracy. However, we must also recognise that all too often, instances such as these arise due to countries such as Syria becoming merely the stage for bigger and nationally-vested battles. I trust that any proposed intervention will be measured and in the context of protecting individuals, and not furthering other interests that merely exacerbate the situation and contribute to the further abuses that we have already seen.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – We have already had a lot of resolutions on Syria in the European Parliament, but this one is something exceptional and exceptionally important. She's special because we agreed on her all factions as one man, as one man. Palmyra's UNESCO Heritage Site is one of our heritage sites and we must protect it by all possible means. Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I fear that some of these monuments may reach the black market and thus, to a large extent, become a source of other terrorist organisations and operations. However, the resolution also applies to the human rights of people living in the area themselves. We, as Members of the European Parliament, strongly condemn the current situation and condemn the violations of human rights by the regimes there. On behalf of my PPE faction, I call for the fight against IS to be systematic and based on the joint cooperation not only of European partners, but also of local, regional and non-state actors. Only then can we succeed in the fight against IS.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Our emergency resolution on the situation in Syria today focuses on two important and urgent problems. The first is the attack by the so-called Islamic State terrorists on the ancient desert city of Palmyra, which is one of the most important World Heritage sites in the Middle East. Secondly, we call for the release of Mazen Darwish and his comrades-in-arms from the detention of the Syrian Assad regime. His case exemplifies what the European Parliament can do to defend human rights. As MEPs, we have the opportunity to build up targeted public pressure. Such pressure can sometimes make a decisive contribution to gaining more freedom for the victims of political repression here. Mazen Darvish has been in custody for more than three years without a court ruling. Now the urgency of his case has increased once again. He was taken to an unknown location and his relatives have not been in contact with him since 3 May 2015. The case of Mazen Darwish is representative of the brutal repression of the peaceful opposition by the Syrian regime, over which Russia still holds its protective hand. President Assad systematically persecutes human rights activists and independent journalists. I would also like to mention today the human rights organisations which have been campaigning for the release of Mr Darwish for years and with which we stand side by side, first of all his wife, Yara Bada, with whom we have been in close contact in preparation for today's resolution. But also the organizations Reporters Without Borders, Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, which together with others run a website for the human rights activists imprisoned in Syria. I would also like to mention those who have honoured Mazen Darwish for their support in the fight for human rights. These include the Prize of the 16 Luther cities, "The Intrepid Word", the UNESCO World Press Freedom Prize, the Bruno Kreisky Prize for Human Rights, but also the Pinter Prize of the PEN Club.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I would like to express my concern as a European MP representing a country – an eastern external border of the European Union. The actions of Islamic State terrorists have already achieved their effect – they have increased the refugee flow, severed economic ties and panicked the ordinary population. Without a doubt, the destruction in the ancient cities of Palmyra, Nimrud, Mosul, Hatra and Horsabat aims both to provoke terror and to serve as a means of financing terrorists.  Much of the ancient historical heritage of Syria, Iraq, Libya will now be available on the black market for antiquities. The European Union must step up the fight against the smuggling of artifacts to stop Islamic State's attempts to finance its crimes. I call urgently for the Council of Interior Ministers to coordinate measures and actions against the fight against trafficking in antiquities as a top priority of the European Union's external and internal security.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, we have not signed and, on the face of it, we will not vote for this joint resolution. The issue of heritage is not the only issue at issue. The situation in Syria is presented in a binary way, in particular obscuring the responsibility of some so-called Western governments in the chaos that prevails today in that region. A past responsibility, with the Iraq War, and a current responsibility, with the choice to turn a blind eye to the ambiguous games of some so-called friendly countries, such as Turkey, or some Gulf states. Not to mention the issue of arms and oil sales. The conflict has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives and displaced millions of people, while the Union is procrastinating on its share of international responsibility, both here and there. Progressives and Democrats have been abandoned in Syria. Mazen Darwish, like Hani Al-Zitani and Hussein Ghareer are symbols. By the time the red carpet was rolled out to Bashar al-Assad, they were already fighting for freedom of expression. Compared to them, this resolution is very weak.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in the tragedy of Syria it is difficult to know where to start. I very strongly endorse the comments from all corners of the House in respect of Mazen Darwish, who we certainly do want to see released as quickly as possible. Our focus is on ISIS itself and Palmyra prison, and on the need for us as a European Union, and as the West, not to drift towards the Assad regime by accident in the fight against ISIS. That fight is valid in itself, of course, but we must ensure that we are even-handed, as the Assad regime, in the eyes of the people of Syria, is not the lesser of two evils. In the eyes of the people of Syria, it is the same evil as ISIS, and one man with a gun looks very similar to another. ISIS destroyed the notorious Palmyra prison, amongst their other crimes in Palmyra, but the destruction of that prison can only enhance the way they are viewed by the people of Syria. We must of course combat ISIS, but they do exist for a reason and we must be aware of the causes of ISIS, as well as the symptoms.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tragedy in Palmyra and Syria, the battleground that has become of too many opposing interests, is the result of the mistakes made in recent years and above all not only by the West, but above all by gulf countries, which are all too condescending in arming and financing anyone who was anti-Assad. And today Daesh dominates by destroying the present, the past and threatening the future. Mazen Darwish, the other human rights activists and illegitimate journalists, who are being crushed by terrorists on the one hand and the Assad government on the other, are paying the price. The more than 200 victims in Palmyra, however, remind us that we must also be realistic and immediately push for an open dialogue with all the regional and non-regional players, so that we can immediately arrive at a solution that can put a united front against terrorism, and then, once the country has been stabilised and pacified, lead everyone to pay for their responsibilities even before the International Criminal Court.  A country on its knees is asking us for this, and millions of refugees are asking us to do so in the Middle East and also in Europe.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 20 May, the black flag of ISIS has been flying over the temples of Palmyra. Corpses and rubble have taken the place of the wonderful archaeological sites. ISIS and radical extremism want to erase the progress of our civilization, deny freedom of expression and religion.  ISIS is advancing in Syria, Libya, Iraq and Europe is silent, indeed perhaps it is better to say it speaks too much, without doing anything: mountains of chatter, of resolutions, documents as it is today, no concrete action, no strong reaction, no real solution. Europe should be ashamed because it is incapable of tackling the issue of terrorism, just as it is incapable of tackling the problem of the immigration of refugees, including Syrians.  You will remember that, in the wake of the emotion of yet another massacre of migrants, on 23 April there was an extraordinary summit of 28 EU countries. Just over a month ago, therefore, action had to be taken immediately and on Tuesday, however, they decided that the much-vaunted European solidarity can wait until September, 100 days! And Italy has to make do! Meanwhile, the Mediterranean Sea continues because of you to be the graveyard of thousands of refugees.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – We have discussed the situation in Syria and Iraq several times, but unfortunately the situation in these countries seems to be getting worse and worse. It reminded us once again of the islamic state's takeover of Palmyra. The terror brought by these terrorists to this ancient city once again shows us that these people are a threat to the universal values of all mankind, regardless of religion.  I would like to call here today, first of all, to support those represented today in our resolution by Mázin Darwis, but also by Razan Zaituní, those who, in extreme circumstances, still draw attention to human rights violations, discrimination against minorities and all other acts that can be regarded as manifestations of crimes against humanity. With the so-called The Islamic State is fighting for the fundamental values of human civilization.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I will start by reminding all my colleagues that despite the US-led coalition air strikes against the Islamic State group, today it appears that the group is stronger than ever. It now controls about half of Syria’s territory and one third of Iraqi territory: definitely more than 12 months ago. There is an urgent need for us to revisit our strategy and our way of fighting ISIS. Islamic State fighters have frequently destroyed ancient artefacts like the ones in Mosul and other places in Iraq. In May the city of Palmyra fell – a city at the crossroads of several ancient civilisations which houses some of the world’s most spectacular ruins. The fighting is putting at risk one of the most significant sites in the world and a UNESCO world heritage site. Therefore, I would like to reiterate today the importance of the preservation of the cultural heritage of the whole of humanity. The destruction of these monuments is not just a war crime and should be considered as an imprescriptible crime. It is the equivalent of a crime against humanity.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: – Mr President, for the moment, the cultural cleansing undertaken by Daesh at other precious sites they have seized has not taken place at Palmyra, one of the greatest of all cultural treasures of the Middle East. As a former UNESCO World Heritage Site chairman myself, the thought that this wondrous jewel could be destroyed concerns me and so many others deeply, never forgetting that probably over 1 000 people have lost their lives in and around the site. Indeed, the destruction of such sites is in fact contrary to Islamic scholarship, where previous civilisations and the learning and architecture of antiquity was studied, preserved, often incorporated and, in a positive sense, used. As my colleague Boris Johnson, the Mayor of London, has put it: this is not a clash of civilizations; it is a struggle between civilisation and nihilism, and it is a fight we must win.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Daesh has carried out systematic attacks on a large number of archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq. Now we can only hope that they do not also deprive the world of the irreplaceable cultural heritage that exists in the city of Palmyra. This recurring approach has been described as cultural cleansing. In particular, where the acts are directed against members of a religious or ethnic group in order to prevent the practice of religion, remembrance and learning, they may be equated with persecution and, in certain circumstances, with genocide.  But the resolution is also about human rights. The imprisonment of Syrian human rights defender Mazen Darwish and other freedom fighters is once again evidence of the gross violations of human rights that take place every day in Syria. My admiration and solidarity goes to all Syrian activists who continue their fight in a conflict-torn environment and I call for the immediate release of all persons who have fallen victim to arbitrary detention.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I would like to express a different point of view from that of our colleague, Mr Smith, who said that the Syrian regime should not be seen as the least evil.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are in politics. We do not draw an ideal world, disembodied and in accordance with our wishes in this comfortable assembly. The policy of the lesser evil, however, was the one carried out by the Anglo-Saxons in the alliance with the Soviet Union to destroy the Hitler regime. It is clear, however, that the authoritarian regimes, although very imperfect and highly critical, in Iraq, Libya and Syria were nevertheless protective of religious minorities and relatively tolerant of women's rights. So when there is no alternative, we must indeed rally to the politics of the least evil. I do not know of Mr. Mazen Darwish's case. I fervently hope for his release, but I have the impression that it is being referred to as a kind of alibi to restore a false balance. European independent journalists are much safer, however, when they are in the ranks of President Bashar al-Assad's regular army than when they go to investigate on the Side of the Islamists.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I am listening very carefully to the debate on the tragic situation in Syria. It is good that this issue is on the table here, but we must admit that this debate clearly shows that the Islamic State is strengthening and that the international community has not yet found a way to fight it.  I would therefore like the Council representative to say afterwards whether the EU is considering other means of suppressing this extremely criminal and dangerous association, and whether further military interventions can really be considered.  To Palmyra itself, I want to say that it is indeed extremely tragic that, in addition to war crimes and the killing of tens of hundreds of civilians, cultural monuments are being destroyed. I think we should consider how to tighten sanctions on trade, trafficking, the trafficking of monuments that are stolen as part of the war that the Islamic State is waging against our civilization. I think that a harsh recourse could lead, at least in part, to less trade in these monuments and thus the Islamic State will not raise additional funds.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the EU and its Member States have to involve themselves as soon as possible, and act strongly, in order to save parts of the historical and cultural heritage of mankind, especially in the Middle East. I am deeply concerned that terrorists from Daesh have seized control of the historic Syrian city of Palmyra. The population is scared to death and the historical heritage of this city is under threat of destruction. These shameful events are also due to the many mistakes made by the Assad Government. One of these mistakes, clearly reflecting the repressive nature of Bashar Assad’s regime in Syria, is the detention of Mazen Darwish. I strongly support our call for an immediate and unconditional release of Mazen Darwish and other political prisoners in Syria arrested solely for exercising their right to the freedom of expression.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the situation in Palmyra is particularly critical. The risks to the region from ISIS have increased in recent times. The destruction of religious and cultural monuments by the jihadists is aimed at destabilising populations and destroying their cultural heritage. The jihadists are now engaged in lucrative smuggling of archaeological treasures.  Palmyra is more than two thousand years old and is a cultural treasure, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Measures must be taken to protect ancient Palmyra to put an end to ISIS's terrorist activities, the massacres of Christian populations and the looting of archaeological treasures. At the same time, the action of the Assad regime, which extensively violates human rights, must also be condemned and the regime must proceed, immediately, to the release of human rights activist Mazen Darwish.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, we have been witnessing several months of years of culture and genocide. The Islamic State has conquered much of the territory and is genocide, making a culturecide that we must put an end to.  Palmyra and Mazen Darwish are two symbols of Syria, Palmyra as a World Heritage Site, a UNESCO heritage site, and Darwish as a man with his backers, as a man fighting for a new Syria, for syria's freedom and for democracy in Syria.  We are obliged here, in addition to the speeches we hold and the consensus we have on all these issues, to send a clear message that it is time to put an end to all these crimes that are happening before our eyes.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, we are faced with a situation where we do not want to acknowledge the main responsibility. Without absolved of responsibility for the Assad regime, which is why I call for darwish's immediate release, I would like to stress that the aim of the intervention in these regions was not supposedly to restore democratic regimes, but oil. The oils and only the oils. And that is why we and the European Union and all the forces that supported this unacceptable regime are responsible.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, the recent occupation of the ancient and historic city of Palmyra, combined with the destruction of cultural monuments and the massacres of civilians there, has once again brought to light the wrong policy pursued by the European Union on the Syrian problem.  Initially, he tolerated the creation of ISIS by the US, in cooperation with Turkey, Israel, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, on the pretext of overthrowing Assad's regime. And when ISIS not only failed to overthrow the regime, but turned against Iraq and the Syrian people, then it did not intervene to solve the problem. It did not demand that Turkey stop supporting the jihadists, but praises it for accepting waves of refugees it has created and even wants to fund it.  In this way neither the humanitarian crisis is solved nor the problem. Syria will be transformed into a country in which everyone will fight against everyone, the Sunnis against the Shiites, the regimes against the dissidents, russia's influence will increase ... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the capture of Palmyra by ISIS put the city in the international spotlight but left residents there wondering if ancient statues are worth more than their lives. The community is facing acute problems such as shortages of food, water and medicine. In addition, they could become targets of Assad’s airstrikes, not to mention the brutal acts of ISIS militants. However, I want to emphasise again how crucial heritage sites are, as testimony to the continuous presence of diverse communities in these regions. The destruction of religious and historical patrimony goes together with the violence that is directed against these groups. This resolution highlights how these acts can be considered as crimes against humanity and as cultural cleansing. It is also high time for the international community to develop a renewed protocol for the protection of cultural heritage in times of war, and I urge the EU to be at the forefront of this.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, the fall of Palmyra, of Ramadi, is vivid evidence of the ineffectiveness of the policy that led the so-called Islamic State. Coalition against Islamic State. It is quite obvious that with limited airstrikes, with logistical support for the so-called Islamic State( moderate opposition not only does not defeat Islamic State, on the contrary – it is getting stronger and stronger, it is advancing and taking over new territories in Syria and iraq, and now Libya.  Again, we are witnessing rivers of blood and monstrous crimes against humanity, we are once again witnessing the destruction of a cultural and historical heritage that will never be restored. It is right to pay serious attention at last to the issue of Islamic State, to reconsider the policy of the countries that should lead this anti-terrorist operation. Also to make sense of the policy towards Turkey, which is supposed to support terrorists, if we do not want to see what is happening in Palmyra tomorrow in Washington, in Brussels, Paris and in other cities.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, all wings of the European Parliament agree to condemn the Islamic State and its crimes. But we have to ask ourselves how this terrorist organisation manages to survive to this day, what its economic connections are and where it obtains its weapons.  Two weeks ago a high-traffic Turkish newspaper posted on its website visual footage depicting men from Turkish intelligence service MIT helping to send weapons to the jihadists in Syria. Moreover, Reuters reported on May 21st that eyewitnesses and prosecutors allege that MIT helped deliver weapons to jihadists in Syria from late 2013 to early 2014.  The veil of silence covering Turkish Islamists' relations with Syrian jihadists must be lifted and severe sanctions imposed on Turkey if it is shown to support the Islamic State.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I was in Syria last week and I personally took a picture on the ground. When we talk about the successes of ISIS, we must of course also talk about the backers who finance this company. And so, last year alone, there were tens of billions of dollars in aid from Qatar and Saudi Arabia. The Syrian army recently stopped vehicles from Turkey that were modern American air fists, anti-aircraft weapons, and anti-tank weapons. I myself was able to convince myself that there are 1.5 million refugees from Palestine living in Syria, who must not be left alone. I spoke to leaders of Christians, the Orthodox Church, Anglican Christians and Armenian Christians. And they all asked for help – not to get more Christians out of Syria, but to stay there because they can freely exercise their faith there, along with the Mohammedans.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Syrian Palmira is controlled by Islamic State militants. The fate of the country with its UNESCO World Heritage Sites is worrying. It is necessary to immediately stop the destruction of Syrian and Iraqi cultural heritage, including religious objects. We cannot tolerate the acts of terror committed by IS/Da'esh, which is why I call for the protection of the cultural heritage of Syria and Iraq by protecting cultural objects, religions in accordance with international humanitarian law. I condemn the systematic and widespread human rights violations by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, terrorists belonging to ISIS and other jihadist groups operating in Syria. I also condemn the judgments handed down against civil rights, human rights activists, bloggers and journalists. The Syrian Government should respect freedom of expression and the freedom of human rights defenders. I call on the Syrian authorities to immediately and unconditionally release Mazena Darvish and all those detained or convicted of peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of the EU’s High Representative, I would like to thank you for again adding Syria to this week’s plenary agenda and for giving us an opportunity to follow up on the plenary debates that we conducted on the same issue in February and April this year. Although terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq have been seriously weakened in many respects over the past weeks, the challenges ahead remain huge, as illustrated by the fall of Ramadi and Tadmor/Palmyra at the hands of Daesh. As was the case in all cities that have fallen to Daesh, the inhabitants of Tadmor have been and are still exposed to arbitrary killings and violence. The ancient site of Palmyra, right next to Tadmor, is also a symbol of Syria’s rich cultural heritage and identity. It has been a crossroad of civilisation throughout history. The threat of deliberate destruction that Daesh is exerting in archaeological and cultural sites such as Palmyra may amount to a war crime, according to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. The EU has taken all the appropriate steps in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2199 to prevent the illegal trade in cultural property that contributes directly to the financing of terrorist groups. But the occupation of Palmyra/Tadmor by terrorists is only one of the latest military developments in Syria. It is first and foremost a strong reminder of the urgency to achieve a lasting political solution to the crisis. To contribute to that effort, we must remember that firstly, while Daesh is a single organisation and that a regional approach is needed to tackle it, the circumstances in Syria and Iraq are different. Secondly, from the EU perspective, an inclusive political transition in Syria and inclusive political governance in Iraq are crucial to sustainable peace and stability: the fight against Daesh and other terrorist groups must be conducted in parallel with the search for lasting political solutions. Thirdly, military, political, counter-terrorism and stabilisation efforts need to go hand in hand to be effective both in Syria and Iraq. This approach is at the heart of the EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the Daesh threat, which was adopted in March 2015 and is currently being pursued and implemented. This is also the position presented by High Representative Mogherini on behalf of the EU at last week’s meeting of the Small Group of the Global Coalition to counter Daesh. The fight against Daesh and other terrorist groups is not only a military endeavour. It must be conducted in parallel with efforts to address the root causes of the political crisis in Syria and Iraq. An inclusive political transition in Syria and inclusive political governance in Iraq are crucial. This is the key policy objective of the EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the ISIL/Daesh threat, adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council on 16 March. The fight against Daesh and other terrorist groups will require sustained engagement and efficient coordination, and more than ever the EU is determined to continue to use all relevant means to contribute to this effort alongside other regional and international partners. On Syria, our position is clear: it is the Assad regime’s brutal war against its own people, massive human rights violations and systematic obstruction against democratic reforms that have contributed to the flourishing of Daesh in Syria. As a consequence of its policies and actions, the Assad regime cannot be a partner in the fight against Daesh. The EU continues to fully support the efforts of UN Special Envoy de Mistura to achieve a reduction in violence that may create an environment conducive to a political process. The EU has participated in the Geneva Consultations on the political and security developments since the adoption of the Geneva Communiqué of 2012, and we hope that this will help reignite an inclusive political process on the basis of this Communiqué. Efforts to reignite a political process must be inclusive, involving women and civil society, and must be accompanied by confidence-building measures such as the end of indiscriminate bombing and arbitrary arrest or detention, as reported by the United Nations Commission of Inquiry. The EU reiterates its call for the immediate and unconditional release of all political prisoners and activists, including human rights defender and free speech advocate Mazen Darwish, who has been arbitrarily detained since 16 February 2012. We condemned this arrest and called for his immediate release. If Mazen were tried today, his alleged crime would fall under the provision of existing amnesties, but the legal process appears to have been deliberately stalled and Mazen has never been tried. There are undeniable reports of thousands of cases of arbitrary detention throughout Syria. It is a vital report and documents such crimes to ensure that perpetrators are held accountable. Our ultimate objective is to help build a democratic and pluralist Syria where all minorities and vulnerable groups have a place. The magnitude of the Syrian crisis is testing the capacities of the entire international aid system. The needs are overwhelming, and an extraordinary effort is needed to mobilise significant funding, ensure access to the people in need, and aid efficiency. We are also determined to continue supporting the Syrians and the neighbours of Syria affected by the crisis. Humanitarian aid and longer-term assistance are, and will remain, important pillars of the EU’s response to the crisis in Syria and in the neighbouring countries. At the Kuwait III Conference of 31 March, the Commission and Member States pledged close to EUR 1.1 billion – double the EU pledge at the 2014 conference. Of this, EUR 500 million in humanitarian aid, early recovery and long-term stabilisation assistance come from the EU budget. So humanitarian and non-humanitarian aid is delivered both inside Syria and in neighbouring Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq and Turkey to refugees and host communities. Those countries have played a considerable part in the international communitiesʼ humanitarian response to the Syria crisis, hosting well over 3.5 million refugees. The political and humanitarian crisis in Syria remains, therefore, at the heart of our internal debate on migration in the Mediterranean and an important part of our dialogue with all our regional partners in this region. This highlights our will to sustain the level of our humanitarian and non-humanitarian engagement in response to the crisis in Syria and its regional consequences.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written statements (Article 162)

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. Palmyra, Syria, may be the latest world heritage site to be destroyed by Islamic State militants. We see every day that the cultural purge of the Da'esh is moving forward mercilessly. In Iraq, they are dismantling a 2,000-year-old Christian community, expelling the indigenous Yazidi and Turkmen populations, erasing traces of ancient cultures. The trade in movable art is also a significant source of finance for terror. This time, the walls of Palmyra, one of humanity's most special common heritage, are being attacked by the Islamic State, the relics of the Assyrian civilization. The greatest destruction in the modern history of the world is carried out by the jihadists before our eyes, exhausting the notion of a crime against humanity.  But the violence has now targeted the Christian community in the Palmyra area. The jihadists are removing the u u umist Christian leader in Syria, this time father Jacques Mourad, who owns the nearby Mar Elias monastery, by extremists. The monastery was home to many refugees in the civil war-torn zone, regardless of religion. It is typical that local Muslim leaders have also demanded the immediate release of the monk from the international community. I propose that international and European governments and security services make all means available in the region to detect similar crimes and free hostages. This is not only a religious issue, but also a matter of stand up for fundamental human rights.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The current situation in Syria is most alarming. The city of Palmyra, which fell to the Islamic State on May 21, is currently looted from its cultural treasures, whose illicit purchase and sale help finance terrorist organizations. The European Union must fight against these actions of destruction in order to preserve an essential cultural heritage, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.  Action must also be taken in the face of the growing violence against the Syrian population. More than 220,000 people have lost their lives since the conflict began in 2011. The European Union must strive to find a lasting political solution. This effort cannot be achieved without the cooperation of European partners as well as local and non-governmental actors.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. – At first glance, the combination of the situation in Palmyra and the case of Mazen Darvis may seem chaotic. But there is an important link: the conquest of Palmyra by the militants of the so-called Islamic State. The Islamic State's defeat is more than symbolic. It is a loss in the geographical, historical and commercial heart of Syria. It's a loss at the crossroads of cultures. It is a loss for all of us who do not want to accept the offensive of Islamic fundamentalism. The arrest in 2012 of lawyer and prominent anti-government activist Mazen Darvis was a government act linked to the first phase of the civil war. Western military, logistical, propaganda, and diplomatic support for anti-government insurgents in Syria, accompanied by preparations for a Libyan-type intervention, dramatized the situation. This support has made a major contribution to the formation of the fighters of the so-called Islamic State in a form with which not only the governments of Damascus and Baghdad, but also the statesmen of Western powers, do not know the advice. Clearly, the time has come to change strategic objectives, to redefine adversaries and allies. The European Union is getting dragged into too many conflicts. Regardless of the moral or legal nature of these actions, the Union does not have the strength to fight on so many fronts. We need to act wherever possible. And as part of this negotiation, promote freedom for activists like Mazen Darvis. Only then do we have a chance of success.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: in writing. – The idea that Europe is more concerned about Palmira's "stones" than its people has spread in recent months. The number of victims, following the takeover of the city of Palmira by ISIS on 22 May, exceeds four hundred. No archaeological ruin, ancient temple or architectural monument can be worth more than one of these lives. However, a country's heritage is an integral part of the identity of its people and, therefore, I believe that the EU should cooperate with Unesco to protect it. In addition, as an effect of the threat to the archaeological area of Palmyra, public awareness of the human tragedy that is taking place has increased. With this resolution, the EU calls on the Syrian authorities to end the destruction of the estate and to release journalist and human rights activist Mazen Darwish, who has been wrongly imprisoned since 2012.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The conflict in Syria has led to a great humanitarian crisis. It is our moral duty to stand for the values we, the European Union, represent and believe in. The war crimes such as mass killings and wreckage of cultural heritage, I consider to be grave acts of inhumanity. A society which destroys its own people, history and culture is bound to moral downfall. The 2 000 years old Palmyra heritage site is being crudely used by a large terrorist group as a war tool to spread terror and hatred. Furthermore, deliberate targeting of Mr Mazen Darwish and other freedom of expression activists in Syria proves a deepening deterioration of human rights and stability. We must also take into consideration the worrisome information about transnational financial resources of IS/Da'esh and their 200 000 fighters, including EU citizens. It is high time we stopped undervaluing the nature of this conflict and undertook more vigorous steps. In that matter I gladly welcome all diplomatic forms of influence to pressure the Syrian authorities for an activist’s immediate release and the protection of Palmyra and I support the continuous international collective efforts to stop IS/Da'esh’s crimes.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on eight motions for a resolution on Paraguay: legal aspects of early pregnancy (2015/2733)).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. Madam President, as you know, we are dealing here with cases of rights defenders, or other people, other citizens, who are under pressure from the authorities of either authoritarian or, as in the case of communist countries, which are truly totalitarian. This time, with the resolution on Paraguay, we are discussing a private matter. It is a rape, committed within a family, of a horror perpetrated on a ten-year-old girl. This type of tragedy, unfortunately, is quite common in Latin America, not only in Paraguay, but also in other countries.  I know that the left chose Paraguay because it has more interest in focusing on that country than on others. I think it is a mistake, just as it is a mistake to turn this debate, which I think is about the rights of the child, into a debate on other issues, particularly abortion. Of course abortion is necessary in this case and it will be done. That is why we have drafted a resolution with the Conservatives on this issue. I would like to add that, while welcoming the fact that the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, came to this House as Vice-President of the Commission during the emergency debate, today no representative of the Commission is present. I don't understand why.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. – Madam President, the left, Mr Preda, defends rights in all countries, not just Paraguay.  According to the United Nations, 19% of pregnant women in the country are minor; on average, two children under the age of 14 give birth each day, and 2.13% of maternal mortality is girls between the ages of 10 and 14. In Europe, as in Latin America, it is vital that sexual and reproductive rights and health are recognized as inalienable human rights, and it is only women and girls who have the right to decide on their reproduction, their own sexuality, their bodies and their own health.  And so we ask Paraguay to respect its international commitments in this area: not guaranteeing a legal and safe abortion is state violence, and the Committee on Torture has indicated that it can be considered institutional torture.  That is why we are also asking the European Union to take internal action — because it is also not an issue that we have resolved at home — and also that, in its dialogue with Latin America — and now that we have just had the summit between the European Union and CELAC - the gender equality action plan, which is essential, is fully developed. So I invite everyone to support this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder how we can argue even in the face of an atrocious case such as this, which I do not even want to mention. All I am saying is that an interdisciplinary committee has been set up which apparently has done absolutely no duty. I would remind you that abortion is only permitted in Paraguay when a woman's life, a pregnant child is in danger. And I wonder, how a little girl 1.40 meters tall and weighing 34 kg pregnant can't be medically endangered. This is an exceptional case, but it reminds us that, unfortunately, Paraguay is not fulfilling its international obligations. Abortion legislation absolutely must be reviewed and include cases such as rape and incest, in order to give all women the opportunity to exercise their inalienable right. We must exert the appropriate political and commercial pressure because, as Mr Urtasun said earlier, if action is not taken, we will almost end up endorsing a kind of live torture.  I hope that there will be more responsibility in this Parliament on these issues.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Three weeks ago, supporters of the homosexual amendment to ireland's constitution attacked a pro-family demonstration, and during this attack, ten-year-old Muireann DeClár was hardly killed. Why am I talking about this at the moment in this debate? Because this girl was ten years old, and this is the only opportunity to talk about it, because I don't think any of us are deluding that we will have a debate in this House about what the Referendum in Ireland looked like. There was a proposal, Parliament did not take it up. Now back to Paraguay , if the degenerate who is the perpetrator of this drama we are talking about were sentenced to death, he would have had dozens, probably hundreds of defenders, in our room. About the humanity of the child who is waiting to be born, no one will recall, so I had to tell you about it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, I will save you time, because I have prepared a one-minute speech. A ten-year-old girl was raped by her stepfather and is getting pregnant. The Paraguayan authorities, who were unable to protect her from her rapist when they became aware of the situation, forbade her termination of pregnancy, which her mother claimed, on the grounds that her health was not in danger. Abortion is strictly prohibited in Paraguay, regardless of the situation, and therefore including in cases of rape or incest, except in cases where there is an imminent danger to the mother. Neither the opinion of the director of the hospital where the girl was located, nor that of the UN expert group, specially dispatched to the site, nor even the statistics showing that the risk of maternal mortality is four times higher among adolescent girls under the age of sixteen, could do anything about it. This is not an isolated case: two children under the age of fourteen give birth every day in Paraguay. Yes, Mr Preda, the vast majority of Latin American countries penalise abortion and we condemn it broadly. Defending the right of women to dispose of their bodies is an ongoing struggle, here as elsewhere. But when this right is denied to a ten-year-old who has been raped by her own stepfather, a sense of inhumanity and anger prevails. Such topics leave no room for political polemics.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. – Madam President, does it make sense for us to speak in the European Parliament today of a ten-year-old girl who does not reach 1.40 m, who has been raped by her stepfather, whose pregnancy is discovered by her mother after five months? I think it does make sense. And she has it because this girl is the embodiment and symbol of thousands of girls who every year suffer rape and pregnancies and not everywhere receive the same care and care. Denying these minor victims of sexual violence and mistreatment a humanitarian abortion not only violates international law, as the UN itself denounces, but also violates our obligation as an international community to provide it with access to comprehensive health guaranteed to it by the Convention on the Rights of the Child, whose 25 years we recently celebrated jubilantly. She is a child who could live anywhere in the world, yes, but lives in Latin America and lives in Paraguay. And I don't think this girl is left-wing or right-wing, but she lives in Paraguay; a girl who, like all the children in the world, we have committed to protect, and is the only real living nexus between our European agendas today between Brussels and Strasbourg. This child is that bond that exists because there are international laws that, in this case, are clearly pronounced demanding a humanitarian abortion. The child's interest must prevail over any consideration.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Allow me to begin by congratulating you on your birthday. This discussion is not about the issue of abortion per se, but about how adherence to dogmatic beliefs endangers the lives of individuals. It is a specific case, the suffering of a young woman who is actually a child and who has done the worst thing that can happen to a human being. She was raped by her stepfather, and she is denied the right to abortion, which is in principle. And this is not an isolated case, but such cases are common in Latin America. Such cases occur in a climate of taboo and criminalisation of abortion. Thousands of suicides occur. Abortions are carried out illegally. And all of this, I believe, is something that needs to be discussed from this point of view and where we must not put on ideological blinkers.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, today we raise our voices to denounce a reality to which action is needed, which is teenage pregnancies. This reaches alarming figures in Latin American countries, such as Venezuela, Nicaragua, Bolivia, Paraguay. And it is precisely in the latter country that a ten-year-old girl becomes a new innocent victim, having been raped by her stepfather and becoming pregnant at a very young age where her physical and mental health is at risk. Ladies and gentlemen, this is not an ideological issue: here we must unite our voices in the complaint and in the request for help for this victim. There is no law that is above the legitimate interests of the child, today represented by this child.  I put myself in the shoes of this child, in her mother's shoes, and I demand justice for all the victims. This child is mute and helpless today in Paraguay, but we are not and I give her my voice to demand justice and dignity.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, this debate is not fundamentally a debate on Paraguay or abortion. It is a debate on human rights, based on a concrete case, particularly heinous and tragic, that occurred in Paraguay. In fact, the fundamental values of the human person are at stake here. This 10-year-old child has been the victim, in essence, or is being the victim, of two crimes: a crime committed by his own stepfather, a crime that will certainly be the subject of due punishment within the Paraguayan judicial system, but a second crime, the crime committed by the State itself, in that it has excessively strict legislation that prevents the use of abortion in such a situation.  This is not the time and this is not the time to have a fundamental debate on the issue of abortion. It's a matter of another nature. We are talking about humanitarian abortion, in an absolutely limiting circumstance, in order to safeguard the psychological and physical integrity of a ten-year-old, and this Parliament cannot be insensitive to such a situation.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we are all united in our indignation and condemnation of the violence this girl had to suffer – but that is not good enough for the girl. It is nice that we are all angry but what she needs is the choice to terminate this pregnancy. This is a 10-year-old girl! Imagine if it were your daughter, or your granddaughter. She should be playing with her friends. Instead she is forced to carry the child of her rapist, and that means that those who deny her a choice continue the violence against her. The PPE/ECR resolution talks about dignity. Where is the dignity in forcing a little 10-year-old girl and so many other girls around the world – like the little victims of Boko Haram for example, more than 200 of which are also pregnant and also have no choice? Where is the dignity in that? Where is the dignity of forcing this little body to carry the baby of her rapist? I hope everybody is going to vote for our resolution and give this girl a choice. (Some applause)

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, obviously the case before us is disgraceful and deserves all our rejection because it is, once again, a case of violence against women and, in this case, a girl. We condemn and demand justice, of course, in this attack on the dignity of the child, and we demand the right of all women to ensure our health, including access to safe abortion. However, this case in Paraguay is not unique, and we are also talking, in this case, of a State that suffered a parliamentary coup in 2012 by the right and which has experienced a serious deterioration in women's conditions, according to the various international reports. In fact, we are still waiting for a strategic equality plan in this country. It is important not to leave these cases un substantiated; because there is no possible justification for denying this child's right to be protected and to have a safe abortion. And finally to say that, in the face of paternalistic measures of development cooperation, we support multilateral negotiating mechanisms such as the Summit held these days between the European Union and CELAC.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, every girl and woman has the right to decide about her own body. This is an indivisible and non—negotiable human right, and therefore the Paraguayan authorities’ decision to force this girl to continue with a life-threatening pregnancy resulting from rape violates her rights under Paraguayan and international human rights law. They fail to protect her and violate her right to life, to health and to physical and mental integrity, as well as her right to education, jeopardising her economic and social opportunities. I strongly urge the Paraguayan authorities to meet their international obligations and protect human rights by ensuring girls have access to safe abortion, at least when their health and life are in danger and in cases of rape and incest. The EU cannot shy away from this situation. It should use all means to help this girl and, globally, all the other girls in the same situation.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, a ten-year-old girl who was raped in an incestuous setting is alleged to have been forced to keep her child. However, Paraguayan criminal law would allow, as the Simone Veil law in France, when it was promulgated, to legally terminate a pregnancy prematurely if the mother is in real danger, which is clearly the case, given the age of this girl and her barely pubescent anatomy. These dramatic cases must find a legal solution. On the other hand, and it is your resolution that obliges us to do so, it is necessary to ask ourselves about a generalisation without control of the legal authorisation of the practice of premature terminations of pregnancy, apart from cases of medical necessity. This is a deeply shocking act for the woman. To force it to do so is also to flout it.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, today we are talking about Mainumby: a girl who is 1.39 metres tall and weighs 34 kilos, with problems of anemia, malnutrition, ten years old. She has become pregnant – a pregnancy of more than five months – by her mother's partner, who is currently already in prison.  The chances of pregnancy going ahead and no risk to the child are minimal. All international agencies explain the risks in the case of these childhood pregnancies so it can be a violation, which not only harms the physical body but also damages the soul.  It is necessary – and we all agree there – for the Government of Paraguay to accept safe and therapeutic abortion in order to protect Mainumby's life. There is no higher priority at the moment than the protection of this girl – there we all agree – and I don't think it should ever be mixed with an ideological debate about abortion, because it would be a matter of some thinking more about her ideology than this girl's life. I'll take the protection of this girl's life.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all saying this morning, as I too say this morning, Europe cannot stand impassively in front of a 10-year-old girl who became pregnant after being raped by her stepfather. A similar nefariousness affects each of us, as human beings wherever it happens in the world, but it also concerns the European Union as an institution, which has the possibilities and the means to intervene in the regions where these tragedies take place.  Any exploitation and polemics are totally out of place! It has rightly been said that carrying on an unwanted pregnancy under these conditions is compared to torture and as such we will have to deal with this situation. This is not a waste case, but a sadly widespread phenomenon, in Paraguay and elsewhere. We have a duty to intervene for this little girl who, at just 10 years old, will have to give birth to another child and for all the girls in the world who suffer such abuse.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, this is really not the time for ideology. Just imagine if something like that happened to one of us or our daughters. That's enough to make us think, and that's why I see this discussion today as an invitation for the Paraguayan authorities to look at this case, but not just this case, but in all the other countries in South America and other countries in the world where situations like this happen. This little girl is a symbol of many other girls. We have to fight for her right, and that is why I agree to find a legal solution because it is a danger to both mental and physical health. We have to help her. In no case can our ideology prevail here, nor can we instrumentalize this discussion today for our purposes. So this is not a discussion about abortion, this is a discussion about the situation that we are aware may be happening in some corners of Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, denying a young girl essential medical care is nothing short of cruel and inhumane treatment and a gross violation of her fundamental human rights. This is why I believe that the request to Paraguay to recognise the inalienable rights of women and girls to bodily integrity and autonomous decision making, especially regarding the right to voluntarily access family planning and safe and legal abortion, must be strongly supported. It is unacceptable for governments to turn a blind eye to cases of child pregnancy and the sexual abuse of women. They must recognise that it is undeniable that early pregnancy poses a severe risk to the health of girls and to their children. Moreover, rapid access to safe abortion for women and girls who are victims of rape or incest should be guaranteed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the drama of the ten-year-old minor highlights the cases of violence and sexual abuse in the countries of the impoverished Latin American International Monetary Fund. At the same time, child pregnancy in Latin America has taken on alarming proportions. The international conventions protecting the rights of children, and in particular the relevant UN Convention, must therefore finally be implemented in order to put an end to the rape of minors.  We must condemn the forms of family violence and seek to increase sentences in cases of rape of minors. At the same time, there must be programmes of psychological and medical support for victims, but also the lifting of the ban on abortion in such cases. There must be information campaigns, as early motherhood in Latin America is linked to cultural norms, educational level and social status.  Finally, domestic violence is intensified by the tensions of poverty and the social marginalisation of the peoples of Latin America.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, today we are voting on a joint resolution on human rights violations in Paraguay. This resolution was triggered by an incident that occurred a few months ago and reported in the media about a Paraguayan minor, ten years old, who was sexually abused by a family member, to whom the Paraguayan Government did not give any medical-legal assistance, nor the possibility of exercising the right to therapeutic or ethical abortion. The truth is that in this region of the globe, these cases are recurrent and tend to increase.  The protection of victims and, in this case, of minors is a matter that is not properly provided for in Paraguayan law and, in situations of termination of pregnancy caused by rape, the Paraguayan State shows no openness in defending the physical and psychological integrity of victims of this type of violence. The truth is that situations like this bring serious health problems and economic exclusion to adolescents. It understands that no argument can be invoked to overtake the human condition of child and woman. It calls on the Paraguayan Government to take due care in protecting the interests of its citizens and, in particular, the most unprotected, such as the cases of minors who are victims of sexual abuse. Thank you and happy birthday, Madam President.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Madam President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the first time I visited Paraguay was 37 years ago, and already at this time I heard about how many girls and young people were pregnant due to rape by parents, stepparents, uncles, brothers and others, with no option to end these pregnancies. At this time, I didn't think that, almost 40 years later, there would be this same discussion. That we should also ask that not only justice be done against perpetrators, but also that this girl, like so many others in so many countries, has the right to end this pregnancy. And I do not understand how the right in this Parliament speaks of dignity, if you are arguing against the termination of this forced pregnancy, the result of rape, so that this child is no longer at risk. I call for more efforts in the Action Plan now being discussed in the EU-CELAC, in the gender-based violence chapter, to give choice to legal and safe abortion, at least in cases of rape for minors.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, I see that hypocrisy is the master in this Chamber. We are talking about a 10-year-old girl from Paraguay, who has certainly had a bad misadventure and will unfortunately suffer the consequences. But everyone who speaks in here, we talk about Paraguay, but is there anyone who talks, for example, about the ten thousand suicides in Greece, about everything that is happening in Europe, about how many girls and boys in Europe have big problems? No, we must always give lessons to the world, to Paraguay, to Ethiopia, to Burundi, to Burma, in all places, because we are giving lessons, but we are not capable of managing Europe as people ask us! And then, since you talk a lot, each of those who spoke this morning, you take out a thousand euros each, I take them out too and you go to Paraguay to help the little girl. Don't have a hypocritical chat in here, read a piece of paper and then give a about what happens to that little girl. Get the money out, go to Paraguay and help the little girl! Shame on you!

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you for giving me, on behalf of the High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission, the opportunity to brief you on the situation with regard to children’s rights in Paraguay. In the past months, the sad and emblematic case of a pregnant ten-year-old girl in Paraguay has attracted much attention worldwide. It has highlighted the vulnerability of children and adolescents to violence and sexual abuse in Paraguay and many other countries in Latin America, where child pregnancy is a serious problem. The EU is following the case and the protection of children’s rights in Latin America more generally. There have been recent cases in other countries in the region as well as in other parts of the world. The European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Commission are in close contact with international organisations in Paraguay, including UN Women, the UN Population Fund and UNICEF. We Europeans join their voices in calling for increased efforts to protect children against all forms of violence, including sexual violence, within and outside of the domestic sphere. The EEAS and the Commission also agree on the need for the authorities to step up prevention and increase awareness so that citizens know where to report abuse. The perpetrators must be brought to justice and the victims must receive adequate medical care and support. The EU continuously emphasises respect for children’s rights through cooperation and political dialogue. Human rights, including children’s rights, were part of the discussions that took place last November in the IX EU-Paraguay Joint Cooperation Committee. We know that Paraguay is confronted by economic and social challenges, poverty and inequality, making children particularly vulnerable. That is why we are supporting the government’s efforts to tackle poverty by supporting education and social protection. The EU is also financing human rights activities that support women, children and indigenous peoples. Under the ‘Non-state actors and local authorities in development’ programme, an EU-funded project aims to protect adolescents’ sexual and reproductive rights by raising awareness among young people, teachers and parents. The EU Member States are also active. In line with the May 2015 Council Conclusions on Gender in Development and with the Policy Coherence for Development principles, the EEAS and the Commission will continue working on sexual and reproductive health and rights and seek to advance understanding of the components and elements related to sexual and reproductive health and rights in the EU’s development policy. Children’s and women’s rights are EU human rights priorities in Paraguay. The EU financially supports actions aiming to protect adolescents’ sexual reproductive rights through strengthening awareness among young people, teachers and parents, as already mentioned. We hope that the work we are doing with Paraguay will contribute to the protection of the rights of children so that no child will have to suffer violence and sexual abuse.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, I am sorry but I feel that we did not get an answer from the Council. I am glad that the Council is committed to human rights, but we would like to know what the Council presidency is going to do in this particular case. Are you going to intervene on behalf of the girl? You talk a lot about human rights: that is fine, and I am convinced that you are committed. What is the Council Presidency going to do? Are you going to approach the Paraguayan authorities and intervene on behalf of this girl and try to make sure that she gets a choice to get a life?

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – First of all, I am here to represent the High Representative. The Council was not invited. Secondly, as I have already pointed out, the Council, under the Latvian Presidency, has agreed conclusions on gender and development, as well as the policy coherence for development (PCD) principles. Also, the Gender Action Plan is being prepared. These are the very concrete EU measures which the Council and the Commission together are going to implement.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Today we stand firm in our strong condemnation of the denial of essential medical care to a ten-year-old rape victim. This is a tragic and disturbing case that is unfortunately far from isolated in Paraguay and in other countries in the region. Denying access to safe and legal abortion to an abused young girl is not only an immediate physical risk to her body, but it also ensures that she will continue to be victimised again through being forced to give birth to her rapist’s child. The government of Paraguay must give priority to humanitarian and health concerns over religion, especially when a child is involved. Physical and sexual exploitation of women is a serious human rights violation. Further denying women an abortion, particularly in a case where their mental and physical health is at risk, extends the suffering of a victim in a cruel and unnecessary manner. Paraguay must take immediate steps to fully implement the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The suffering of many women, and in this case when we talk about girls, is one of the worst possible violence against young lives. The fact that we have numerous examples of pregnancies of minors should not leave anyone indifferent. How dangerous this is for the lives of girls and babies shows a high percentage of mortality or very common tragic social cases.  For these reasons, we must provide the right to safe abortion of unwantedly pregnant minors and all minors whose lives are directly or indirectly at risk. I strongly condemn violence against minors and want every bully to receive an appropriate punishment for their crimes. Paraguay is just one of the countries in Latin America where we are witnessing the monstrous pregnancy of a 10-year-old girl we need to help in our future life as a symbol of our non-compliance with this inhumane case.  I expect the European Union to include this topic of violence against minors on the agenda of the first next summit in its meetings at the highest EU-CELAC level, as the protection of the rights of the child is clearly set out in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In April 2015, a ten-year-old girl visited a hospital in Asuncion,Paraguay due to severe stomach pains. However, after an extensive medical examination, it turned out that the ten-year-old was pregnant in the 21st week. She was raped by her stepfather. The girl's mother demanded an immediate abortion, which authorities did not approve. Unfortunately, this is not an isolated case in Paraguay. According to the latest United Nations data, 21% of pregnant women in Paraguay are minors. Around 600 girls aged 14 and younger become pregnant each year, mostly as a result of rape. In 2014, 42 young girls died during pregnancy or as a result of an illegal abortion. The United Nations Committee therefore called on Paraguay in March 2015 to amend the legislation on abortion, as the right to health and life is no longer guaranteed and there is a massive violation of human rights. It is an untenable state of affairs, a violation of human rights, an individual disaster for every girl who is forced by law to carry a child. Pregnancy and childbirth are often life-threatening for the girls, not to mention the traumatic side effects. Paraguay must grant underage pregnant women the right to access safe and legal abortion.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on seven motions for a resolution on the situation in Nepal after the earthquakes (2015/2734 (RSP)).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a humanitarian tragedy with 8 786 dead and 22 303 injured. 864,000 people have lost their homes, 5.6 million need immediate medical assistance and 8.1 million need humanitarian assistance. What is happening very soon on Nepal? Even monsoon rains, which are expected in the coming weeks and which could not only bring the supply and aid chain to its knees – since many villages are only within walking distance – but even more so completely undermine the sowing season, also destroying the possibility of having a harvest this year.  We must act and demand that we ensure that all the aid and funds allocated are used in the most transparency and in the best possible way, especially in order to give priority to defending the rights of the weakest, women, children and the sick.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – One and a half months after the devastating earthquake, we are getting a better view of the progress of the relief effort in Nepal and the dramatic situation. For example, it is incomprehensible that the Nepalese government is still sticking to cumbersome customs procedures and a tax on relief goods. The dispensation of those relief supplies left a lot to be desired. Elderly and single women now sometimes have to walk tens of kilometres to get help supplies. Especially for the Dalits, those who live at the bottom of the social ladder, it was particularly difficult to get relief supplies. Officially, the caste system hasn't existed since 1963, but the reality is different.  If international aid is not better handled, reconstruction is likely to take a very long time. And the state itself also needs a facelift: new state structures with strong and decisive governments at local and national level and democratisation in the field of education and health care.
