Only in this way can Nepal turn the tragedy into something positive, with the support of the EU in particular. I wish Nepal much courage and success.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Author. – Every natural disaster is a tragedy that infamously affects the lives and running of the country, as well as the entire region. Moreover, where such disasters happen in areas such as the Haiti and Nepal, we're losing words to describe the situation.  Even before the first earthquake, Nepal was not sufficiently urbanized, the country was plagued by poverty. After several earthquakes in the last few weeks, Nepal's 8 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, which unfortunately is on the way. True, the residents themselves are involved, but these are the actions of people who are desperate and in need of help.  In particular, the resurging of health facilities and services in the country, especially in remote areas, is necessary, including by providing medical tents and equipment to replace medical facilities that have been damaged and destroyed.  I believe that it is the duty of the Nepalese Government and the international community to ensure that children who have been separated from their parents are reunited with their parents as soon as possible. Children need to be at the heart of humanitarian intervention. They must be given special attention because they are in a particularly sensitive situation.  Aid workers have noted cases of malnutrition and threats of child abuse and trafficking. We stress the importance of bringing children back to school benches, but this will not be possible without the considerable and coherent efforts of Nepal and the international community.  For us, the problems with customs procedures for humanitarian supplies are unacceptable. We call for the abolition of all so-called aid taxes that local police on the Nepalese border have paid for the delivery of humanitarian aid. Help should quickly reach the places where it is needed and not serve as a means of doing business.  I therefore ask the European Parliament and all the Member States to do their best to help Nepal and its people to get back on their feet. Nepal's past state was not satisfactory, but now it is completely disastrous. The danger of a third earthquake is real.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At the beginning of April we visited members of the South Asia delegation Nepal. We wanted to motivate the leaders of the main parties to finally adopt a constitution. It was also about climate change and human rights issues. Remarkable progress has been made there. And we visited EU projects, including a hospital as an early warning institution in the event of disasters. It was not remotely clear that two weeks later 9 000 people would fall victim to the quake of the century. Hundreds of thousands lost their homes, yard and livelihoods. Temples, historical sites and other sites that we visited in Kathmandu and Bagdapur no longer exist. The wave of solidarity is impressive: thousands of volunteers, the delivery of food, medicines and donations from all over the world – EUR 60 million in four weeks from my country alone, Germany. In the event of natural disasters, health institutions and local authorities need to better network and expand emergency systems. The fascinating Nepal with which I have been associated for years should not and must not be left alone in the future! Namaste!

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Madam President, I chaired the Parliament delegation that Mr Mann has just referred to and which was in Nepal two weeks before the earthquake struck. We know that there were disaster preparedness plans being implemented, but not across the whole country at that point. We know that those preparations helped save lives, but we nevertheless express our deep sympathy for all of those who lost loved ones, and indeed for the country as a whole. It is a country, as we have heard, of real logistical problems in getting aid out: three main types of geography and three centuries in terms of development, as was once explained to me. Development needs support in terms of the main parties agreeing on the new post-conflict constitution and developing local government, which will be crucial for the reconstruction effort. That is estimated to be 50% of GDP. That GDP will be hit because tourism is the main source of income, followed by remittances. So the donor community needs to pay what it has promised, and we will be paying attention to that.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Madam President, Nepal is in an ongoing state of emergency. International humanitarian aid has been – and will continue to be – crucial to both the immediate relief of the suffering there and, in the long term, for reconstruction of this beautiful country that I was honoured to visit once. Respect for human rights must remain at the centre of all these efforts. I am appalled at reports that the most vulnerable groups are being discriminated against on the basis of their caste or gender. Nepal must embrace its duty to protect all of its population, including the Dalit community. No one should be denied basic aid, especially on the basis of who they are or where they come from. The disaster also threatens to deprive children of their basic right to education. With more than 7 000 schools damaged, education and the reconstruction of schools must remain a priority. It is our duty to do everything we can to help Nepal return to a state of normality.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: author. – Madam President, I too was in Nepal just two weeks before the tragedy. Seeing the images of the devastation of areas we visited was heart-breaking – 2.8 million people are in dire need of aid, and nearly a million of them live in hard-to-reach areas. Reaching them must be a priority before the upcoming monsoon rains cause further damage and access to them is cut off. Free and smooth access should be facilitated for all incoming humanitarian aid, which should be distributed fairly to all. I welcome the EU’s assistance. However, as the UN has pointed out, much more international support is needed. Nepal also needs an aid package for long-term recovery and development, including safeguards against future natural disasters. The International Donors Conference in Kathmandu is welcome, and I urge the EU to play an active role in it. The S&D Group is fully committed to supporting Nepal’s ongoing efforts towards recovery, peace and prosperity. We hope the disastrous earthquake will unite all the political forces in Nepal, as it is now even more necessary than before to reach a political consensus.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. " Dramatic pictures from Nepal went around the world a few weeks ago, sometimes they can still be found somewhere, but gradually interest decreases. Many of us were in Nepal, many went to Nepal, not only because of the extraordinary beauty of this country, but also because of the extraordinary charm of these wonderful people, their spirituality, their peace, their kindness, and their beauty. Their drama is not over and we must remember that. Many of them, most of them live on very steep slopes, and we as tourists requiring some comfort still lead to the fact that even more trees are cut down there, because we want warm water, because we want a shower. Will we show solidarity today – we who are happy to admire Nepal? We often use the word "solidarity". If we want to do something concrete, let us not let the appeals for help be silenced. We must help nepalese people materially, specifically, at European level, at national and personal level. And the last sentence ...  (The President interrupted the speech of the Member)

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, as someone who has a long-standing relationship with Nepal – having worked with the pro-democracy movement prior to the first-ever democratic elections, which I observed – and someone with a deep admiration for the Nepali people and their determination to rebuild their country after the recent devastating earthquake, I know that one of the major concerns now is for children. There are 1.7 million vulnerable children who have been affected, many of them having lost their parents. Many children have been displaced, and it is at this time that they are most at risk of being trafficked or taken by unrelated adults. It is therefore really important that we urgently put into place procedures to prevent this from happening. Also, recognising that many schools have been destroyed, we need to unite and to prioritise rebuilding these schools and getting the children back into their classes so that their studies are not completely disrupted. The monsoon season is fast approaching, and this will have major consequences for the relief efforts ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Karol KARSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Nine thousand people died, half a million homes destroyed, three million refugees – that is the scale of this terrible tragedy. The international community immediately responded with assistance, sent 76 rescue groups, 70 medical groups, almost 4,000 trained specialists from 36 countries. In the first days of the tragedy alone, the European Union has set aside EUR 40 million. However, we are discussing here not in the debate on humanitarian aid, but in the debate on violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Despite the extremely difficult situation, it appears that the Nepalese authorities are charging a special tax on money and gifts flowing from all over the world at the border. Moreover, these funds do not always go to all those in need – women, Dalits are particularly disadvantaged in this situation. We must bear in mind that there is no room for selective treatment, discrimination and the European Union should strongly counteract such phenomena.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam Chairman, the scale of the tragedy that occurred on April 25th and May 12th in the Nepal earthquake is best seen in numbers: nearly 9 million dead, 2.8 million displaced persons, 1.7 million children without one or two parents, 5.8 million people need health care, 1.6 million people need all kinds of assistance. The World Heritage Site has been destroyed, the government estimates that it is worth $10 billion in damage, followed by monsoons and the inability to sedave rice, which means eating problems again next year.  Thus, the European Union needs to organise coordinated assistance with the international community in such a way that with financial resources we also have humanitarian aid in agriculture, in seeds, in health people's teams, for the restoration of cultural heritage and the international community must help that country find its way to democracy because they are obviously well at the moment going with the consensus they have.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I will begin by saying that nothing human is alien to us, eer in Europe or Nepal or Burundi or Paraguay, because of the unfortunate interventions that we sometimes have to listen to. It seems that the world is a hostile place, where the effects of natural disasters and, above all, misery are frequent and inevitable.  The reality is different. Nepal is not a reality of others: it is a slave country to the networks of globalization that Europe has driven. More than a quarter of their gross domestic product depends on the remittances of their migrants – migrants who live, not infre sfreches, as slaves in the Middle East – and these remittances are hardly enough to cover the imports that Nepalese need simply to survive, drowned out by debt and the rules of global trade that prevent access and finance a genuine development strategy: a vicious cycle with which we must break.  Europe has a duty of solidarity that is far from fulfilling. The UN notes that at least 300 million are needed just to alleviate the humanitarian catastrophe – funds that have not yet been unlocked.

name: Seán KELLY
text: . – A Uachtaráin, gan dabht ar bith is truamhéalach an tragóid atá ag titim amach i Neipeal tar éis an chreatha talún; 9 000 marbh agus a lán daoine gan dídean, gan scoil agus gan bia fiú amháin.  Teastaíonn ó gach duine réasúnta cabhrú leo. Tá moladh ag dul don Choimisiún, atá ag tabhairt 3 mhilliún euro; na Stáit Aontaithe, atá ag tabhairt 10 milliún dollar; agus an Bhreatain, atá ag tabhairt 6 mhilliún punt steirling. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid an cheist a chur: an bhfuil an chabhair seo ag dul chuig na daoine is mó a bhfuil sé ag teastáil uathu, go háirithe an grúpa Dalit, an grúpa is lú stádas i Neipeal? Caithfimid a bheith ar an airdeall go bhfuil an chabhair ag dul chucu agus go rachaidh an chabhair chucu.  Freisin, ceist eile: an bhfuil an iomarca NGOs (eagraíochtaí neamhrialtasacha) ag obair? Chuala mé go raibh 600 díobh i Háítí le déanaí. Ba chóir dúinn níos lú NGOs a bheith againn agus chabhródh sé sin leis an scéal freisin.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the people of Nepal have been through a very difficult time lately due to the devastating earthquake that struck the country last month, and I would like to offer them my deepest sympathy. I would like to express my concern about the thousands of Tibetan refugees living in Nepal. Most of them do not have Nepalese citizenship, and as a consequence they become invisible to the state. Tibetans in Nepal do not have their basic rights guaranteed, since all the human rights provisions in Nepal’s Constitution apply exclusively to Nepali citizens. Moreover, Nepal is not a party to the UN Convention relating to the Status of Refugees. It is heart-breaking that, at times like these, it becomes clear how the most invisible groups tend to be extremely vulnerable. I would therefore urge the Nepalese Government to polish up its constitution in such a way that at least the basic rights of everyone living in its territory can be guaranteed, especially during times of crisis.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I call on the European Union institutions and the Member States to continue to support the reconstruction process in Nepal and to increase the humanitarian aid being given to that country. I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims and my strong solidarity with the people of Nepal after the recent devastating earthquakes there. I would also like to thank the State of Nepal and the international community for the efforts they are making in the reconstruction of the country. However, it is true that more could be done in terms of search-and-rescue activities, providing humanitarian relief to people in remote, hard-to-reach areas, ensuring free and smooth access for all incoming humanitarian rescue and relief provision, and taking action to support resilience and mitigate the effects of natural disasters. Europe must stand beside Nepal in its transition towards democracy, and in the field of development cooperation we will keep on mobilising international financial support.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, I am aware of the tragedy of the earthquake victims, their anxieties and their needs, as my country, Greece, has often been hit by Enceladus. In Nepal, earthquakes left 9,000 dead and thousands injured. At the same time, 2.8 million of our fellow human beings are facing a humanitarian crisis. Nepal therefore needs increased international aid and solidarity. First of all, housing needs to be addressed, with tents in the first phase and a reconstruction programme thereafter. Health care is essential, as is food aid. Humanitarian aid must reach all over the world, in all the hard-to-reach areas, in all the earthquake victims. Millions of children in Nepal have lost their parents and a child protection network must be set up to prevent them from being kidnapped by slave traders.  Madam President, Nepal is broadcasting SOS and the European Union must respond immediately, with even more humanitarian aid.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I listen carefully to this debate. We need to help, of course, but at this stage we mainly need to address how aid is distributed, whether certain groups in Nepal are discriminated against and therefore whether the aid fulfils its purpose. Like many colleagues, I am very taken aback by the news in the media and in the press, as well as information from, say, Czech fellow citizens who are in Nepal at the moment. Information that some groups simply do not receive assistance. Whether the aforementioned Dalits or, say, poor children, women, these are now groups that are at great risk. I am therefore very happy that the motion for a resolution makes a clear call for our High Commissioner, Mrs Mogherini, to negotiate with the Government in Nepal and to make it clear that aid can continue and be used fairly. Without fair use, aid becomes only an economic tool in the hands of the ruling class in Nepal, and that is, in my opinion, wrong.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, happy birthday first. Colleagues, the tragedy in Nepal should raise awareness: people have died, others have been injured, there are homeless people, without food, without medicines and not ten, not a hundred, millions. We, as the European Parliament, must thank the volunteers from many countries who went to the scene, who carried aid. They are also volunteers from my country and publicly thank them. I believe, colleagues, that we as a European Union, as a parliament, must show solidarity not only in declarations, but in concrete facts. The European Parliament, the European Commission must find new and much more means of financial aid to the people of Nepal. In my country there was an earthquake many years ago and I saw dead, missing, people without (...). That is why I feel solidarity (...) (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.) I was saying that I experienced an earthquake in my country in 1977 and I saw people pulled from under the rubble, people homeless. That is why I believe that we must stand in solidarity and I feel solidarity with the people of Nepal and I propose that we set an example ourselves, the parliamentarians, to make a solidarity account.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam President, the scale of this tragedy is enormous and we are shocked by what we hear happening these days, a month and a half after the humanitarian drama that took place in Nepal. What we have to do is make sure that the allocated funds are transparently spent. It is remarkable that the Nepalese government continues to seek tariffs on humanitarian aid.  We know that Nepal was a poor, underdeveloped country even before this disaster, and we also know that half of the income was earned from tourism that is now significantly endangered.  Therefore, help is needed. Eight million people have requested humanitarian aid. Today's debate and resolution are an opportunity to call on all members of the European Union to help. Solidarity is necessary and let's not think nepal is far away. Nepal can happen to us.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – In crisis situations people react, collaborate, resort to solidarity and intervene to help those in need. The instinct to help people is inscribed in the fundamental values of humanity and is part of our essence. The S&D resolution underlines the need for solidarity and unity in the international community, towards a people who have suffered enormously in the face of an uncontrollable natural event. The Nepalese people need constant and long assistance to ward off the dangers posed by the tragedy of 13 May. In the face of the dangers of more than 1.7 million children in Nepal, we must know that we cannot remain impassive. The destruction of infrastructure in Nepal produces very long-term effects, which (...). The tripling of EU financial funds for humanitarian assistance in Nepal is to be appreciated, but what we must do is to continue together to rebuild Nepal on the principles of unity and solidarity, so that Nepalese civilization continues to provide protection and well-being to its citizens.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy – Madam President, on behalf of Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini, I welcome the adoption of Parliament’s urgency resolution on the situation in Nepal after the devastating earthquakes of 25 April and 12 May. There is a close bond of friendship that ties the European Union and its Member States to Nepal. The European Union and its Member States have already expressed the deep sympathy and solidarity of the European Union for the human losses and injuries, and the physical devastation of homes, infrastructure and heritage sites. A disaster of this size calls for more than words. The EU and its Member States were quick to act and show tangible solidarity with the Nepalese people. Immediately after the earthquake and following the appeal by the Nepalese Government, there was a clear expression of EU solidarity. The Commission provided EUR 3 million in humanitarian aid to support, in particular, emergency shelter, healthcare, and logistics and coordination. This amount was doubled to EUR 6 million following the visit by the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management, Christos Stylianides, who travelled to Nepal together with Valerie Amos, the UN Under-Secretary-General and Emergency Relief Coordinator, to express EU solidarity. The European Unionʼs Civil Protection Mechanism was also activated to support the rapid deployment of relief material and experts from EU Member States. The EU also provided consular support to EU citizens in Nepal. In addition, the Commission fast-tracked the disbursement of EUR 16.6 million from existing development funds. This frontloaded cash allows the Nepalese authorities to address the most pressing needs. We are also envisaging, under the Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace, support in bringing necessary supplies to the remotest districts, which are very difficult to access after the earthquake. This support would also address the need for temporary learning spaces, as many schools have been destroyed. Concerning your question on the partial reinstatement of custom duties, I would like to inform you about the actual situation. As per the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of Nepal ... (The President interrupted the speaker to ask for quiet in the Chamber) We are talking about the earthquake in Nepal and how the European Union can help. When we talk about the reinstatement of customs duties, we need to know that, as per the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of Nepal and the UN, which was signed several years ago now, humanitarian relief items are exempt from customs duties. Initial confusion about this in the first few days after the earthquake was overcome and the government applied this approach more coherently following Commissioner Stylianides’ visit, streamlining procedures. At the end of May, however, the Government replaced a general waiver by a list of relief items that remain exempt from customs duties. The UN system, which the EU supports, has been actively gathering information from aid agencies on the application of this approach. This will serve as evidence for the meeting the UN will have with the authorities so as to resolve the issue. If these efforts at local level are not successful, the Commission stands ready to advocate, with the government, building on the contact that has already been established in the response to the earthquake. The EU is now actively participating in the ongoing post-disaster needs assessment, which should be ready by mid-June and which will serve as a basis for the recovery strategy. The EU will participate in the Donor Conference on reconstruction to take place in Kathmandu on 25 June. (The President again called for quiet in the Chamber) Nepal also needs political stability to push forward its economic development and now its reconstruction. We hope that the long-overdue constitution could be adopted as a key step forward in Nepal’s peace process. This should then be followed by establishing more decentralised, strong and accountable institutions. The long-overdue local elections should take place to restore legitimacy at local level. Nepal also needs to address a number of human rights challenges, in particular the need to guarantee inclusivity to all and deliver justice to the conflict victims. Many Members asked about human rights. Gender, non-discrimination and children’s rights are key priorities of the EU human rights strategy in Nepal. The EU has been a long-standing supporter of civil society in addressing discrimination and violence against women and promoting better social economic conditions for women, as well as promoting the rights of children. The Government of Nepal has taken measures to prevent the trafficking of children. For instance, since the earthquake, the government has been more watchful of any possible trafficking and has been trying to raise public awareness against it. Some of the districts most affected by the earthquake are the source districts from which trafficking of girls has taken place. (The President called for silence in the Chamber) The EU supports a number of human rights organisations working on women’s and children’s rights which are active in the fight against human trafficking. The EU has been funding programmes to combat case-based discrimination and the untouchability issue, including supporting Dalit-led organisations and empowering other vulnerable groups such as women and children in slums. As one of the major donors, the EU will continue to monitor the distribution of aid, as well as responding to human rights issues such as impunity and discrimination. Nepal has survived a terrible tragedy. Time will be needed for full recovery. Therefore, the EU and other international partners will continue to support Nepal and its people in these endeavours. I thank you very much for your interest in the situation in Nepal. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The situation in Nepal since the terrible earthquake is critical. The thousands of bereaved families must be supported by international solidarity and every sovereign state can take part. This is why Qatar's attitude, which refuses thousands of Nepalese workers to return to their country to attend the funerals of their loved ones who died after the earthquake, must be strongly denounced by the international community. The scandal calls into question Qatar's bid for the 2022 World Cup. The total impunity of this emirate must finally end.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. Following the recent earthquakes in Nepal, still the poorest country in South Asia, it is estimated that around three million people are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance as the monsoon season approaches. Despite the immediate relief provided by the EU, its Member States and the international community, we express our deep concern that hundreds of thousands of people are still without aid and are still in isolated areas, not reached by relief. We call for particular attention to be paid to the precarious situation of children and women, with regard to the problem of their malnutrition and lack of health care, and to the growing danger of epidemics spreading and spreading. While we welcome the fact that the EU has recently tripled the amount of funds dedicated to EU-Nepal cooperation in its budget, we call for new support for the country in its transition to democracy and in the area of development cooperation. Community aid should be provided through local organisations where possible in order to promote self-sufficiency and support local industries and businesses, which is also crucial to achieving a rapid transition to a sustainable recovery in the country.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I supported the resolution on the situation in Nepal after the earthquake, as the country is currently also threatened by a monsoon starting in early June, which can cause additional damage and rising water levels, making it harder for aid workers to access vulnerable populations.  In addition to the need for the European Union and international organisations to improve their responses to global emergencies, I believe that the European Parliament should continuously emphasise the need to increase funding for humanitarian aid, while transparently carrying out its role in overseeing the delivery of humanitarian aid and spending budgetary resources.  For the adoption of the European Consensus on Humanitarian Aid in 2007, parliament is largely responsible for confirming its active role in humanitarian and development assistance with this resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing – I offer my sincere condolences to all those affected by this terrible tragedy, including the families of over 8 800 people who lost their lives in Nepal, India, China and Bangladesh. I appreciate the rapid response of the Nepalese institutions, as well as the effective assistance of the international community. Here, too, we can see how important humanitarian aid is. Nevertheless, the reconstruction and reconstruction of this country will require longer-term efforts, and therefore development aid is justified. I firmly believe that the lives of the inhabitants will quickly return to normal.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing - Nearly 9,000 dead and more than 21,000 injured were injured in earthquakes on April 25 and 12 in Nepal. The country is still in desperate need of humanitarian aid, with aid organisations on the ground warning that the situation will also be complicated by the approaching monsoon season. Due to the increased risk of hepatitis infection and other communicable diseases, the number of victims may increase by hundreds. I am glad that this resolution does not forget the most vulnerable, the children. Up to 1.7 million children were affected by the earthquake, 320,000 of whom lost everything – homes, warm clothes, access to education, but many of them lost even more, their families. It is orphans who are at increased risk of abuse, neglect, disease or human trafficking. I applaud the efforts of the government and humanitarian organisations to provide these children with care as quickly as possible, as well as their temporary placement in monasteries, churches and makeshift camps, but the information about their disappearance from these places is more than worrying. Although Nepal has suspended the possibility of international adoptions and the travel ban on unaccompanied minors, I believe that protection must be even more intensive. Only in this way will at least those children whose families have survived be able to return to them as soon as possible.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, in the course of Tuesday’s debate on the Supervisory Committee report on OLAF, a Member of this Parliament, Mr Sarvamaa, addressed me in the most insulting and unacceptable terms. He charged me, in a most slanderous way, with deliberately lying and consciously trying to mislead the debate. I find this totally unacceptable, and I want to bring it to the attention of all our colleagues. In all my deliberations I have expressed definite, categorical opinions, but always to the best of my knowledge and to the best of my ability to interpret facts. I will be continuing this debate in the Committee on Budgetary Control, where I can go into the substance of the issue, because I know that Rule 164 does not permit me to do so. However, I want to be very clear that the type of procedure being pursued in the committee needs very serious review and upgrading.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, I would like to apologise to Mr Pirinski for my language concerning him. Mr Pirinski, the reason for the language I used was that I think I know that you know better when you say that OLAF was never given a chance to reply to the allegations that were made in the annual activity report of the Supervisory Committee. That is why I said what I said – but, having said that, I apologise for my language and I hope you accept the apology. (Applause)

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, I had asked for the floor before the agenda, they missed giving it to me and they replied that they would give it at the end of the speech. That didn't happen. I would therefore like to speak now on this subject, which I had asked for before the agenda. I won't take long.  In the Roman Senate, every morning it sounded like "Hannibal ante portas" and from me every day you will hear "hands down from Greece", you are not allowed to intervene in my country, which its people are taking its own way. You have no right, those who defend lenders, to help lenders!  The only solution is to stop for a year the freezing of all Greece's obligations and the Greek people are able to find their own way. (Applause)

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Madam President, what happened in this Chamber last night was a disgrace. It was an outrage. Under Rule 191, the EFDD Group requested a vote to suspend the sitting and that vote, under the rules, should have been taken immediately. Instead, the Vice-President took it upon herself to suspend the sitting for 30 minutes so all you guys could come down and vote. This highlights one of the reasons why many people perceive this place to be a Mickey Mouse chamber. You either have a rule book or you do not. You either stick by it or you rip it up and then we make it up as we go along, just as happened last night. As a result, we will be writing to President Schulz to clarify that the rule book is applied evenly across this House and that we are not discriminated against, like we were last night, simply for being Eurosceptics.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Mr Nuttall, the sitting was suspended because of the disorder in the Chamber, according to Rule 22. Maybe you know something about that, since you were here yesterday evening. I am sure you can understand.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this oral amendment is intended to bring the situation up to date. There was a reference to the deal between France and Russia over the Mistral assault ships, and now we have negotiations for the termination of that deal. Therefore, as you know, we have to adapt the report to reflect that situation. So – instead of ‘urges France to abandon, unequivocally and finally, the sale of amphibious assault ships to Russia’, which is to be deleted, we propose the inclusion of: ‘welcomes France’s decision to reconsider the delivery of the Mistral amphibious assault ships to Russia and salutes France’s negotiations to unequivocally and finally cancel this deal’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, actually, because there was a mention of the same situation with the Mistral in 2 paragraphs, we have to adjust this one too. We would add to the end of the paragraph ‘and looks forward to the successful conclusion of the negotiations to cancel this contract’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all those colleagues who have taken an interest in this report, and also for your votes. (Applause)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, I would like to ask the European Parliament and the European Union to set up a professional organisation to examine what, ultimately, in the sense of the rule of law, legal professions today mean national self-determination. I cannot accept that when the interests of the Western world so require, for example in the case of Kosovo, national self-determination means something different from, say, Crimea. Thus, I cannot accept that, in the case of South Tyrol, the concept of national self-determination and autonomy is different from, say, Szeklerland, Highlands, Southland or Transcarpathia. The European Union talks so much about the rule of law as a value. The rule of law means that the law is predictable, objective and not politically useful. It would therefore be important, on the basis of research, with the involvement of experts, such as the examination and use of the Human Rights Court decision on Kosovo, to say that the concept of national self-determination should be interpreted uniformly.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Cooperation requires trust – without trust, no cooperation. The annexation of Crimea has severely shaken confidence in Russian foreign policy. This is not just about the European Union's relationship with Russia. No, it is about the confidence of everyone, especially the smaller, neighbouring countries. What is the Russian embassy? Either you do what I say, or I take a piece of land from you. That cannot be right. That is why the European dual strategy is: firstly, to tell Russia clearly that we do not accept this and have therefore also imposed sanctions, but secondly, to maintain dialogue nonetheless. For one thing should be clear to us: there can only be a political solution in the Black Sea, especially in the interests of the people. That is why both are important: on the one hand sanctions, on the other hand, dialogue. It is still believed that human reason will prevail again in the end.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I have seen a lot of things pass through this place that have shocked me and have reaffirmed my conviction that Britain would be better off out of here. I have to say that this report tops the lot. I would like to draw attention in particular to the split vote on paragraph 16. I will once again make it clear that I am equally disgusted by Mr Putin’s actions, but this report is truly frightening. It calls for the strengthening of sanctions that are damaging businesses across the continent, and, worst of all, for the European Union to arm Ukraine. The path to peace is not through tit-for-tat measures, and it is certainly not through the flooding of an already volatile situation – and a most fragile ceasefire – with more weapons. I have seen this situation develop, during my time in this Parliament, from a few protests in Kiev to the worst security crisis since the end of the Cold War. The European Union must stop its persistent warmongering; Russia must ensure that it abides by the Minsk peace agreement; and all sides need to get back around the negotiating table and work out a proper and lasting peace deal.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I would like to point out that I not only voted in favour of this resolution, but also would like to point out that the issue of international law and violations of international law in the event of the annexation of Crimea has been expressed unequivocally by the Council of Europe, which is set up by the States precisely for the assessment of human rights issues and for the assessment of issues of international cooperation between states. Therefore, many of the debates that are taking place on the annexation of Crimea are, in my opinion, unnecessary, and the issue of trade disruption is, of course, essential, but I do not know whether the aspect of trade could outweigh the fact that a state clearly illegally annexes the territory of another state and we should only take this into account. I think that these aspects, that we should take into account because of commercial interests, are completely indefensible.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cheapamar go raibh deireadh leis an lá go ndéanfadh tír amháin ionsaí ar thír eile san Eoraip. Faraor, nuair a d’ionsaigh an Rúis an Chrimé, tháinig deireadh leis an tuairim sin.  Dar ndóigh, bhí ar na tíortha éagsúla san Aontas – agus ar an Aontas i gcoitinne – athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar a bpolasaithe agus is é sin atá ag tarlú anois. Bhí laghdú tagtha ar an méid airgid a bhí á chaitheamh ar chúrsaí míleata agus cosanta. Dar ndóigh, caithfear é sin a athrú; agus tá sé sin ag tarlú, mar níl a fhios ag aon duine cá stopfaidh Putin ag an am seo.  Bíodh sin ráite, caithfidh mé a rá gur tír neodrach í Éire agus nach bhfuilimid i NATO. Dá bhrí sin, staonamar i vótaí éagsúla a bhain le fórsaí míleata agus NATO. Ach, dar ndóigh, d’aontaíomar leis an tuarascáil i gcoitinne agus bhíomar sásta aontú lenár ngrúpa mar aonad.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, rarely can the phrase ‘armchair generals’ have applied quite so literally. Here we have the armchairs, and in our rhetoric in these reports we are adopting the most belligerent tone when, in reality, the European Union is considering lifting even the feeble sanctions it has already imposed on the Kremlin if Russia stops advancing further. The annexation of Crimea has, in effect, been accepted by all sides. The reason that I suggest we have this dichotomy is because we have a guilty conscience. We feel that we stirred up a problem that we were not then prepared to support with the resources – military and financial – that it would have required to rescue our own victims. The good news is that the European Union is not the sole organ of foreign policy. In Ukraine, my own country has been most strongly engaged with Canada and the US in providing assistance and advice to Ukrainian forces and, as long as NATO rather than the EU remains the basis of our security, we may yet avoid a total failure.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The text put to the vote is a political resolution aimed solely and exclusively at deliberately damaging relations between the European Union and Russia, which is unacceptable and forced me to vote against it. First, the Resolution instrumentalizes history in order to present Russia as to blame for the situation in Ukraine and responsible for strengthening NATO's military capabilities in Eastern Europe. The text goes so far as to propose not to rule out the application of Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, i.e. war. Rapporteur Pascu's bellicose proposal is complemented by a call to continue the policy of sanctions on Russia. I believe in peace and cooperation with our neighbors. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against the final report on "the strategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia". This report represents an increasingly militarised EU approach to the situation in the region. Given Sinn Féin’s commitment to Irish neutrality I voted against many aspects within the report that called for a greater militarised approach.  The final report included aspects such as the possibility of mobilising European naval and airspace assets to the Black Sea; and called on NATO to continue to develop its cyber and missile defence capabilities. The report also urged the Commission to support the Member States in their efforts to identify solutions by which to raise their defence budget to the level of 2% and welcomed the pledge made by members of NATO to ensure that their defence spending reaches a minimum of 2% of GDP by 2024. Increased military spending, especially in a time of economic crisis where ordinary people are already suffering as a result of savage budget cuts, is deplorable. The militarised approach this report advocates would only escalate tensions further in the region. This is why I voted against this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I strongly condemn the illegal annexation of Crimea and the direct and indirect support of the separatists and the human rights violations that go with them by Russia. By continuing the war in eastern Ukraine, the Russian Federation is provoking a permanent destabilisation of the strategically very important Black Sea region. In his report, Ioan Pascu calls for unconditional compliance with the Minsk ceasefire agreement and urges better and more intensive cooperation between the countries bordering on the CSDP. It is essential that the EU strengthens its own resilience in order to prevent the threat of escalation and to prevent the conflict from extending to Georgia and Moldova in all circumstances. I welcome the report and reiterate the threat to the entire Black Sea region.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is an accumulation of poncifs and exaggerations. Russia is alleged to be guilty of "annexation of Crimea" but also responsible for "the escalation of military violence in Crimea". The main source of this text is a report by NATO, a military organization that aims to fight Russia. The European Union, by failing to recognize the referendum of 16 March 2014, denies the people of Crimea the right to self-determination, denies democracy and the right of peoples to self-determination.  This openly hostile relationship with Russia also prompts a partnership with Turkey against Russia, even as Turkey pursues an ambiguous policy towards terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State group, as well as submission to the Americans through NATO. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the military situation in the Black Sea should be a matter for NATO, not the European Union. Whilst I disagree with Russia’s actions in the Crimea, I believe that the European Union is likely to make matters worse rather than better.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to raise the European Union's awareness of the importance of the Black Sea at a time when we are reviewing both our defence and security strategies. The deployments and aggressive modernization of the fleet put in place by Russia are a security challenge that cannot be ignored or solely entrusted to NATO.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. ‒ I support NATO members committing to spend the agreed 2% of GDP on defence; it is important for the security of all NATO members.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The Black Sea Basin is strategically an extremely important region for the EU, its Member States and associated partners. However, due to the changes in its geopolitical landscape defined by Russia’s aggression and its illegal annexation of Crimea, the security situation in the region has been deteriorating rapidly. I believe it is crucial that we do not turn a blind eye but condemn Russia’s aggression by favouring a strong and united EU policy towards its authorities. We must adequately respond to the fact that Russia is investing in its military capabilities, such as bolstering its air and naval defences and modernising the Black Sea Fleet, as well as be ready to counter its employment of hybrid warfare tactics and propaganda machinery. I hold the view that as long as the Crimea remains occupied, as long as Russia is funding bandits in the eastern part of Ukraine and does not change its offensive policy, the EU must remain firm in keeping their sanctions against Russia and simultaneously update and make the best use of such instruments at its command as the EU security strategy and the EU neighbourhood policy in order to preserve security of the Black Sea Basin and the EU neighbourhood.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea.  The sea basin is one of the most important regions in the world. However, it is also of strategic importance for the European Union as an external border on security and defence and the development of the Eastern Partnership. Following the annexation of Crimea, the change in the balance of forces and russia's illegal control of hundreds of kilometres of the Crimean coast makes the Black Sea basin a largely virtually paramilitary zone. Such changes in the geostrategic situation require an effective response from the European Union. In order to ensure the security and stability of the region, a wide range of measures are needed, including the modernisation and strengthening of the military capabilities of the Member States of the European Union in the Black Sea Basin. I fully agree with the rapporteur that these changes, as well as the increased pressure from Russia on the European Union's eastern border, as noted in the report, the use of disinformation as a weapon must be taken seriously and properly reflected in the European Security Strategy.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. "Decidedly, the Eurocrats are obsessed with Russia, which they accuse of all evils by constantly repeating the most grotesque lies. What a dangerous irresponsibility! So what will lead us to such bellicose rhetoric that requires total submission to NATO?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have positioned myself in favour of the Pascu report because I believe it is essential to achieve constructive relations between the countries of the Union and Russia in order to evolve together in a climate of peace. The Pascu report tends towards this goal.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea is yet another example of what could probably be described as Russophobia by many European officials. The proliferation of resolutions to this effect in the European Parliament is becoming ridiculous. Let us remember for the umpteenth time that Russia is neither an adversary, let alone an enemy of European nations. Each State is of course free to decide for itself the foreign policy it wishes to pursue, but I hope that my country, France, will have normal and non-belligerent relations with Russia. For these reasons, I cannot approve this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have seen many controversial aspects in the report, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Black Sea basin is a strategic region for the EU. This Resolution urges Member States to continue without acknowledging the annexation of Crimea and condemns Russia's support for Ukrainian separatists.  NATO-Russia cooperation is requested to be based on a change in its policy towards Ukraine and for the sanctions regime to be extended if Minsk ceasefire agreements are not fully implemented. The Resolution notes that NATO has a moral obligation to strengthen the defence capabilities of Georgia and Ukraine, while urging the Commission to update its strategy for the region.  Beyond the purely military, Member States are encouraged to diversify their energy sources, and the Commission is encouraged to continue negotiations on the pipeline that will connect the EU with Turkey. Human rights violations during the conflict are also requested to be investigated and concern is expressed about the environmental impact that the conflict may be having on the region.  That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it reiterates the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia and draws attention to the changed strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin. The Black Sea Basin is one of the most important strategic regions of the world, which is essential for the EU and its Member States, especially with regard to ensuring their security and defence, as well as important in the context of the EU Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership. Parliament points out that the military balance in the Black Sea basin has changed since the illegal annexation of Crimea, and now Russia is illegally controlling hundreds of kilometres of the Crimean coast and its own waters against the NATO-EU maritime border. Parliament expressed concern at the high risk of increased Russian pressure on the EU's eastern border, including pressure on Romania, Poland and the Baltic states, and called on EU Member States to continue to abide by the agreed sanctions against Russia, as well as to suspend any military cooperation and defence cooperation and to terminate treaties such as the supply of Mistral-class air-amphibious vessels to Russia.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. The report calls on the European Union to continue its initiatives to diversify energy sources in the Black Sea and encourages Member States to take steps to reduce their energy dependency.  It is important for Russia to implement the Minsk ceasefire agreements, but contrary to point 16 of the report, I believe that the conflict can only be resolved peacefully through negotiations. It draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the increased presence and security situation in the region. In line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. The Black Sea Basin is one of the most strategically important areas in the world and is of utmost importance for the EU and the Member States. The area is particularly important in the context of ensuring their security and defence and for the EU Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership. Changing the geostrategic picture, the way the military situation in the Black Sea basin develops and the violent annexation of Crimea to Russia are indications of wider and systematic challenges to the post-Croatian system of European security. Coordination with NATO and the US is of utmost importance as the Black Sea Basin is an essential part of Euro-Atlantic security. In conclusion, I support this report because it reflects the current situation and identifies key security concerns in the Black Sea area.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that the annexation of Sevastopol and Crimea by the Russian Federation represents a very serious violation of international law.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's allegedly illegal annexation of Crimea.  Like the report on EU-Russian relations, this text echoes the worn-out refrain of anti-Russian policy. Not only does it contribute to the escalation of tensions, but it also despises the citizens of Crimea who have expressed by vote their desire to join Russia. No one is unaware of the partiality of this report, which aims only to align with Washington's policy and the break-up of the continental bloc.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea because I appreciate that it correctly captures the situation in this region. The report also proposes a set of measures to strengthen the Black Sea basin region so that similar aggressions to the annexation of Crimea are no longer possible. The Member States of the European Union must remain further united in one voice in terms of strengthening the sanctioning regime vis-à-vis Russia as long as it does not intend to comply with the rules of international law, while showing a willingness to resume discussions when the occupied territories are restored to Ukraine and international law will be respected.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The relationship is exceptionally anti-Russian. EU policy on this issue is wrong and pre-conceivable and seems to be inspired by American indications. Otherwise, an embargo which does more damage to European companies than to the political situation would not be explained.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the final report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. This report represents an increasingly militarised EU approach to the situation in the region. Given Sinn Féin’s commitment to Irish neutrality I voted against many aspects within the report that called for a greater militarised approach. The final report included aspects such as the possibility of mobilising European naval and airspace assets to the Black Sea, and called on NATO to continue to develop its cyber and missile defence capabilities. The report also urged the Commission to support the Member States in their efforts to identify solutions by which to raise their defence budget to the level of 2% and welcomed the pledge made by members of NATO to ensure that their defence spending reaches a minimum of 2% GDP by 2024. Increased military spending, especially in a time of economic crisis where ordinary people are already suffering as a result of savage budget cuts, is deplorable. The militarised approach this report advocates would only escalate tensions further in the region. This is why I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the points raised in this report, notably concerning the strategic transformation of the Black Sea region following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. Russia has now gained a very important launching pad facing the west, the Balkans and the south, where it has established a permanent naval task force. The report also condemns Russian action to provide direct and indirect support to the separatists, which only encourages the conflict to continue. The EU needs to stay firm with Russia, including the possibility of continuing and strengthening sanctions. I also agree with the importance of the review of the European security strategy and the possible increase of CSDP cooperation with the Black Sea littoral partner states Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report's concern about the 'Russian arms race' must also take into account hostile attitudes on the Western side, such as funding for anti-Russian factions that are disoling the EU from its propensity for soft power. Contrary to what the Pascu report says, still attempting the diplomatic route with Moscow is the only solution that can be found by the Institutions of the European Union. In my opinion, a diplomatic dialogue with Moscow must be relaunched by all means and at all costs, because not only is it unthinkable to engage in a confrontation, but even worse would be to do so by proxy. I also believe that the real great risk is that a completely drifting Russia will seek an ever closer and closer partnership with China, and perhaps also with Iran, creating an Asian bloc that would therefore create a much bigger problem than we face today. For these reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe we need to do all that is in our power to help support the security of Ukraine and the wider Black Sea region. The Black Sea is an important strategic region for all European security and should not be neglected in our policymaking. We should never accept the illegal annexation of Ukrainian soil.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained during the vote on the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following the events in Crimea. This dossier deals with a sensitive and sensitive subject which should be further discussed at the highest political and diplomatic level.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, with its limited competence in foreign affairs, is not, in my view, the right place to decide whether or not choices made by other sovereign states are correct. Nor should this institution be set up as a court of international law, however much there may be reasons to try to extend European influence to the areas covered by this resolution. I abstained, therefore, because I felt agnostic about this text.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. – The Irish PPE delegation abstained on a number of votes in the report on ʽStrategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russiaʼ. These votes concern issues such as: providing Ukraine with defensive arms, urging Member States to increase their defence spending and enhancing the military capabilities of NATO in the Black Sea Basin. Ireland is a neutral country and is not a Member of NATO; the status of countries such as Ireland should be respected in this instance. While we support the EU’s approach to the crisis in Ukraine, we do not believe that all EU Member States should be obliged to support NATO policy action in the region. Since the general intention of the report is positive, we voted in favour of the final report but abstained on a number of separate votes.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The Black Sea is an important External Border of the Union as it forms the eastern border of Romania and Bulgaria. Now, around this Sea are also Turkey, Georgia (whose region of Abkhazia has been experiencing a growing Russian military presence), Russia and Ukraine, including the Crimean peninsula recently annexed by Russia, brutally defying the international order. In the context of relations with Russia, the strategic-military situation of this region is of course crucial. While relations between the Russian Federation and its Member States must seek peaceful solutions and not conflict, the EU must remain firm, in conjunction with NATO, and ensure security from an energy, maritime, border and, not least, and, not least, security point of view with the people of this region.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is particularly important that the European Parliament also speaks out strongly against the annexation of Crimea, which is contrary to international law. The conflict in south-eastern Ukraine can only be resolved politically on the basis of the Minsk agreements. The current international legal framework must be respected, and this includes maintaining or, if necessary, tightening up sanctions.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The events in the Strategic Black Sea area have changed Europe's geopolitical balances, especially in terms of energy security, and have opened up new scenarios, to which European foreign policy is called to account. In this context, I agree with the need for Europe to speak with one voice, but I would like to stress the importance of redefining relations with Russia, favouring a more cooperative than a confrontational perspective.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report firmly supports the non-recognition of Russia’s annexation of Crimea; reiterates its commitment to the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine, notes with concern that the illegal annexation of Crimea has precipitated a significant change in the strategic landscape of the Black Sea Basin and the adjacent area, expresses concern about Russia’s current defensive and offensive military build-up in the Black Sea, and condemns the fact that Russia is providing direct and indirect support to the separatist groups in Ukraine. I thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The text put to the vote is a political resolution aimed solely and exclusively at deliberately damaging relations between the European Union and Russia, which is unacceptable and forced me to vote against it. First, the Resolution instrumentalizes history in order to present Russia as to blame for the situation in Ukraine and responsible for strengthening NATO's military capabilities in Eastern Europe. The text goes so far as to propose not to rule out the application of Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, i.e. war. Rapporteur Pascu's bellicose proposal is complemented by a call to continue the policy of sanctions on Russia. I believe in peace and cooperation with our neighbors. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The document underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. It also draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the presence of the OSCE in the region and the security situation. In line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The main purpose of this report is to raise concerns about the strategic changes that have taken place in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report draws particular attention to the fact that, by occupying the entire peninsula, Russia has established a powerful rear base to the West, the Balkans and the South, where it has stationed a permanent naval force.  The report also stresses that the European Union should strengthen its own resilience and mobilise in the face of the challenges of using information as a weapon and the security of it. Considering that there is cause for concern about the violations of the Minsk agreement committed, according to multiple indications, by Russia and the separatists, it is necessary for the European Commission to carry out a review of the European security strategy and in the context of the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy strengthens cooperation under the PSDC with the partner states of the Black Sea coastline.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament strongly condemns Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol under international law. Clearly, economic and financial sanctions alone, while helpful, are not enough to resolve conflicts. That is why we need to rethink our overall common security and defence strategy. The resolution of the conflict in eastern Ukraine will only take place with a Europe that speaks with one voice and now takes more firm account of the need for its security and its common defence.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. The report calls on the European Union to continue its initiatives to diversify energy sources in the Black Sea and encourages Member States to take steps to reduce their energy dependency.  It draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the increased presence and security situation in the region. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the annexation of Crimea has precipitated profound changes in the strategic position of the Black Sea Basin and the entire region. Russia now has a powerful firing range to the West and South, where it has stationed a permanent naval force. I am particularly concerned about the development of Russia's defensive and offensive military capabilities, as well as the plan to expand and modernize the Russian fleet in the Black Sea.  I believe that long-term relations with Russia should be based on cooperation and not confrontation. However, I believe that in the short to medium term, any resumption of cooperation will have to be based in particular on a change in the direction of Russian policy towards Ukraine.  I hope that the ceasefire agreement reached in Minsk on 12 February will be respected and that it will leave enough time for a negotiated political solution to be found. If this were not to prove to be true, I believe that the sanctions regime should be maintained and that Ukraine should be helped to strengthen its defence capabilities.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's allegedly illegal annexation of Crimea. Like the report on EU-Russian relations, this text echoes the worn-out refrain of anti-Russian policy. Not only does it contribute to the escalation of tensions, but it also despises the citizens of Crimea who have expressed by vote their desire to join Russia. The Union should stop trying to continually impose its will beyond its borders. No one is unaware of the partiality of this report, which aims only to align with Washington's policy and the break-up of the continental bloc.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the report on strategic martial law in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, because I believe that many important events have been missed in the report, and Turkey is also noted as a strategic partner of the Union. I believe that the Republic of Turkey skillfully benefits from its status as an applicant member, but we are obliged to note its close cooperation with Russia. As a Bulgarian representative, I must recall that the South Stream project, which had to pass through Bulgaria, was terminated, and in its place another gas corridor under the name Turkish Stream is planned, which will bypass Bulgaria and is contrary to the economic interests of both Bulgaria and the Union.  It also does not mark Russia's role in relations between balkan countries. Most of all, its role in Macedonia and Serbia is not reflected, which, although they do not have access to the Black Sea, have their weight in the distribution of military forces.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe it is necessary to point out the complete lack in the text of any element of self-criticism on the part of Europe with regard to its actions; What is not lacking, however, is a very strong criticism of Russia which, by pursuing its geopolitical interests, certainly makes reprehensible mistakes, but certainly no less than the European and American forces. What Europe does not seem to understand is that foiling the possibility of the formation of a large Russian-led Asian bloc, resuming diplomatic dialogue with Moscow, would be much preferable to the choice to finance proxy wars. In my opinion, I do not share all the confidence placed in Turkey as a strong ally in view of all the critical issues that this Parliament has repeatedly raised with regard to it, as well as the recent Istanbul-Moscow talks.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The current situation in the countries around Russia should be given special attention to the problems that may arise for the rest of Europe. The existence of a blacklist prohibiting access by European politicians to Russian territory is an arbitrary measure and a counterproductive and harmful act to the already low channels of communication between the EU and Russia.  Given the current scenario, the EU must critically reassess its relations with Russia and which have been severely damaged by the illegal annexation of Crimea. It is also crucial to define a contingency plan to meet the 'aggressive and divergent' policies led by Moscow, and the EU should support Russian citizens fighting for democracy and the rule of law in the country, such as human rights defenders, bloggers, independent media, academics and NGOs.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report, because it is essentially against Russia and is intended to support the security of European states exclusively on NATO options.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because the EU has no credibility when it comes to lecturing other countries on annexing sovereign territory. We in Ireland remember Nice II and Lisbon II. We will not forget it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ both the European Union and the UN are strongly opposed to the military annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation, which has thus undermined ukraine's territorial integrity and thereby violated elements of international law and international treaties. As a result of the illegal annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation, the strategic and military situation in the Black Sea region and in neighbouring areas has changed substantially. The European Union will have to respond to these developments by changing the European security architecture, which is outdated and does not correspond to the latest developments in international relations. However, I am opposed to NATO intervening in this escalating situation by sending troops to areas affected by hybrid warfare.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 As with the previous report on Russia I think this report is also about wanting to play stupidly to war. No further comment is needed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the recent developments in the military situation in the Black Sea Basin which represent a big challenge to EU security, I welcome more warmly than ever the adoption in the Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) of this comprehensive report. I believe that the EU can play a very constructive role and be a very important actor in this region, as this region is for the European Union. Stability in this region must be our key priority. We must enhance cooperation with NATO and with the United States, and the OSCE should enlarge the scope of its efforts with regard to Black Sea security, this being fundamental to resolving protracted conflicts in the country.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report, as the Black Sea Basin is strategically one of the most important regions in the world and is crucial for the Union and its Member States, in particular to ensure their security and protection. As a matter of particular importance, attention should be paid to the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, as the Black Sea Basin is an extremely important external border of the European Union and is therefore an area of priority strategy. Nevertheless, I am concerned that the illegal annexation of Crimea has brought about a significant change in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region and, in my view, Russia's aggressive action is a step backwards to an approach characterised by hostility between the blocs. Another problem is the change in strategic conditions, the emerging military situation in the Black Sea basin and the violent annexation of Crimea by Russia pose a broader and systemic challenge to the post-Cold War, norm-based European security architecture.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Paşcu report, given that we need to address, in a clear, decisive and comprehensive manner, changes in the strategic and security landscape of the Black Sea following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. We cannot close our eyes to the fact that, through the heavy rearmament of Crimea and other developments in the region, Russia is creating another military launchpad, this time in the Black Sea. That is why we need to stick to our policy of non-recognition of Russia’s annexation of the Crimea and Sevastopol, consider stepping up sanctions if Russia’s destabilisation of eastern Ukraine and illegal annexation of Crimea continue, and call on the Member States to act to their full potential within NATO by speaking with one voice, investing in a stable neighbourhood and strengthening security cooperation with Black Sea coastal partner states.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Ioan Mircea Pascu's report on the military-strategic situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's allegedly illegal annexation of Crimea joins a consistent European Union logic of stigmatization and interference with Russia. The challenge to Crimea's referendum on self-determination, held on 16 March 2014, reflects the eternal contempt of the European Union's self-proclaimed elites for direct and referendum democracy. Moreover, the conclusions drawn on safety in the Black Sea Basin are worrying. Behind moral pretexts, such as the defence of human rights on which the European Union knows how to turn a blind eye when it comes to preserving its interests and those of the United States, there is a very clearly threatening attitude. For these reasons, patriotic MPs will oppose the validation of this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against it as the Resolution is extremely belligerent and unable to reflect critically on the role of the European Union in the current situation in the Black Sea basin. All critical amendments with the EU's role in the conflict, which allude to the creation of prospects for diplomatic dialogue based on good understanding, were rejected. Moreover, this text does not contribute in any way to the resolution of tensions between the European Union and Russia; otherwise, it encourages them. We cannot vote for it, as we support a Europe of dialogue and peace, not a challenging Europe with its neighbouring countries.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea because it condemns the annexation of Crimea, which violated Ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity by violating the fundamental principles of international order. The Mediterranean is a strategic region for the European Union, so security in this area is crucial for the whole of Europe.  The European Union must be united and united in response to Russia's expansion policy.
