I support the report's provisions that any military cooperation with Russia, including the contract for the sale of Mistral ships, should be frozen. In return, military cooperation with eastern partnership countries Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia should be allowed. I am also convinced that NATO's role is crucial for security in the region. At the same time, in view of the changes in the geopolitical situation in Europe, it is necessary that Member States, like Poland, increase their defence budgets. The European Union must also combat Russian propaganda by supporting projects that counterbalance fabricated information disseminated by the pro-Putin media.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. Russia's illegal and aggressive actions have reshaped the strategically important Black Sea basin region, thus recalling the cold war and forcing the EU to take security action. EU countries must remain united and strong, keep in mind their commitments on sanctions against Russia and rely on the collective security that NATO ensures. In addition, Member States must also find ways to strengthen their internal security by increasing their defence budgets to at least 2% of the state budget by 2024. In the meantime, NATO must commit itself to defending members in the event of conflict and maintaining its naval and air force advantage in the Black Sea basin region. Only by working together will we be able to prevent future conflicts and be able to be safe.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. The development of the Black Sea basin is very worrying, and we support the European Council's condemnation of Russia's annexation of Crimea. We are very concerned about the reports that bear witness to war crimes and human rights violations in the region and think it is important for the EU to mark against this with a clear voice. However, we do not believe that a unilateral focus on military rearmament in the region is the best way forward. We would have liked the report to also highlight other appropriate measures to deal with the situation in the Black Sea basin in a more comprehensive way.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. The report calls on the European Union to continue its initiatives to diversify energy sources in the Black Sea and encourages Member States to take steps to reduce their energy dependency.  It draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the increased presence and security situation in the region. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. As the Black Sea Basin is a strategic region of key importance to the EU and its Member States, it is important that the EU and its Member States speak with one voice on EU relations with Russia. While our relationship with Russia should, in general, be cooperative rather than confrontational into the future the EU must take a strong position in the face of Russia’s recent actions, particularly the fact that Russia has bolstered its air and naval defences in the Black Sea Basin considerably and is facilitating the continuation of war by providing direct and indirect support to the separatist groups in Ukraine. We must also send a strong message to our partners in Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia that we continue to support a strong Eastern Partnership.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. The report calls on the European Union to continue its initiatives to diversify energy sources in the Black Sea and encourages Member States to take steps to reduce their energy dependency.  It draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the increased presence and security situation in the region. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, as I believe the situation is such that strong European engagement and action is needed to contain further militarisation and further security deterioration.  At one time, together with the Council of Europe, we worked on creating Euro-regional cooperation on the Black Sea, transferring the experiences and results achieved on the Adriatic and Ionian Seas. Unfortunately, the situation after the Russian annexation of Crimea was changed. Taking into account other problematic situations in the environment, it is necessary to quickly find ways to overcome the situation and above all I see Turkey as a partner to EU member states.  In addition, I consider it important that the report also mentions the ecological sensitivity of the Black Sea basin to which attention should be paid. I welcome the fact that the report calls for the development of an overall EU strategy for the Black Sea region, a review of the European security strategy and the European neighbourhood policy.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin. This text does not take into account the history of the region and the reality of the balance of power. The referendum by which the people of Crimea returned to the Russian fold was first and foremost the consequence of the Kiev coup. Secondly, it is the popular will that justifies this connection, even if it is obvious that the Russian strategy of access to the "hot seas" is not in doubt.  I hope that Europe will restore peaceful relations with Russia, dictated by our respective interests, rather than obeying the strategic agenda of the United States.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on my colleague Ioan Mircea Pascu's report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. If the annexation of Crimea is indeed reprehensible, this report calls for an unnecessary remilitarization of the Black Sea as well as active NATO support for the defence policies of the countries of the region. This report therefore promotes an increase in tensions between the Russian Federation and the European Union, which is not desirable if the situation is sought to be resolved peacefully.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the military-strategic situation in the Black Sea basin. Although a condemnation of the illegal annexation of Crimea remains relevant, an overly aggressive attitude towards Russia is also not the answer. We must avoid an escalation of the conflict and look for a way to cooperate in order to secure the region and the civilian population in a sustainable way.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Similar to the report on Russia, this resolution is unbalanced and one-sided and sees the trigger of the crisis exclusively on the Russian side. I cannot agree with the calls made in the resolution to be more aggressive towards Russia and to upgrade NATO. Instead of working to defuse the conflict and de-escalate the situation, the EU is unilaterally committed to an anti-Russian stance. I reject this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Russia’s challenge to the international legal order initiated in the wider Black Sea region generated and will further require both tactical and strategic responses from the EU and NATO and from all the Black Sea states. The report dealing with the strategic, political and military implications of the illegal annexation of Crimea and of the military conflict in Eastern Ukraine for the security situation in the Black Sea Basin is thus timely and needed.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following russia's illegal annexation of Crimea is another material of the European Parliament, which creates an atmosphere of fear and prefers threats instead of friendly, diplomatic communication. I could not support him with the best of will, because I think it would be a better solution if both sides came to the negotiating table and realised that there are still many things and problems that unite us. Moreover, the report stressed the need to coordinate the EU's action with NATO. However, it makes no mention of how closer cooperation with a military organisation can help to resolve a diplomatically highly tense situation peacefully. What was striking was the sentence: "he (the European Parliament) believes that even if NATO cannot defend them directly, it has a moral obligation to help Georgia and Ukraine defend themselves." Personally, I believe that the European Parliament, as the body that should help to find consensus, should not resort to such wording, because it helps to create a war atmosphere throughout Europe. Moreover, I consider the requirement for the Commission to support The Member States in their efforts to find a solution to increase their defence budget to 2%. After years of tough belt-tightening policies, the EU should return to caring for its citizens, not arming them.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the resolution, which rightly evaluates a significant change in the military balance in the Black Sea Basin after the occupation and annexation of Crimea by Russia. By violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity, in breach of a number of its international commitments and norms, Russia is trying to entrench its aggressive military domination in the region and to challenge Europe’s security. Thus the Black Sea region became a new security concern for both EU and NATO. In view of these developments the EU must review its outdated security strategy, strengthen support for Eastern Partnership (EaP) countries, respond to a challenge of massive disinformation, propaganda and hybrid threats, consolidate its policies and resilience, and send a clear message to Russia that from now on no more incentives will be proposed without Russia respecting its commitments first. Another important message Parliament is sending to the Russian leadership is that the occupation of Crimea will not be forgotten. The international community must take the case of the annexation of Crimea to the International Court of Justice.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mircea Pascu's report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea.  This report has the merit of highlighting the complexity of the strategic and military situation in the Black Sea, while recalling that EU sanctions against Russia must continue to be linked to the implementation of the Minsk agreements. In view of the strategic reality in the Black Sea region, where Russia has been launching a long-term militarisation process for several months, this European Parliament report also reaffirms the need for responsible management of the situation on the part of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution urges Member States to continue the policy of non-recognition of the annexation of Crimea and condemns Russia's continued support for separatists in eastern Ukraine. It is also called for the restoration of NATO-Russia cooperation to be based on a change in Russia's policy towards Ukraine and to continue with the sanctions regime if the Minsk ceasefire agreements are not fully implemented. The Resolution encourages Member States to diversify their energy sources, and the Commission, to continue negotiations on the Nabucco pipeline which will connect the European Union with Turkey. Human rights violations during the conflict are also called upon to be investigated and concern is expressed about the environmental impact the conflict may be having on the region. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The text put to the vote is a political resolution aimed solely and exclusively at deliberately damaging relations between the European Union and Russia, which is unacceptable and forced me to vote against it. First, the Resolution instrumentalizes history in order to present Russia as to blame for the situation in Ukraine and responsible for strengthening NATO's military capabilities in Eastern Europe. The text goes so far as to propose not to rule out the application of Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, i.e. war. Rapporteur Pascu's bellicose proposal is complemented by a call to continue the policy of sanctions on Russia. I believe in peace and cooperation with our neighbors. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Russia's disregard for the sovereignty of neighbouring states, the illegal annexation of Crimea and agreements with separatist authorities in Abkhasia and South Ossetia violate international agreements, norms and rights. Protracted conflicts in several countries are taking place along the Black Sea coast, jeopardising the union's security, as the Black Sea is a strategically important area and the Union's external border. We cannot remain only on warnings and threats to Russia, we need to agree a position and create a common foreign and security policy and truly implement sanctions on Russia to protect the interests of the Union and neighbouring states, so I supported this report. The report calls for a review of the European Security Policy, the Bloc's unified and stronger attitude towards Russia, which should result in a cessation of all conflicts in which Russia participates. Peace and stability of the Black Sea region should be a priority of the Union's foreign policy.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution as a whole because the text does not promote dialogue and a peaceful path for the region. I also voted against paragraph 7, in which the 'Mistral' vessels are concerned, I voted against paragraph 12 ('Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine'), abstained in the second paragraph of paragraph 15, abstained in the third and fourth paragraphs of paragraph 16 (split vote), abstained in paragraph 21, the second part of the split vote (it is that the Crimean Tatars are persecuted because of the territorial integrity of Ukraine' territorial integrity) , abstained on all issues that talk about reproducing NATO's power in the Black Sea region. All this will not increase security and trust between countries. But in general, I repeat, I could not support this resolution, I voted against. It is a pity that there were only 183 members today, while 356 were in for, and it was adopted.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Violations of international law on the eastern border of the European Union complicate and worsen relations with the Russian Federation and threaten the security situation in the Black Sea region. The situation is all the more serious because this unfavourable situation also allows various extremist groups to engage in illegal activity. The diversity of geopolitical interests is naturally influenced by the diversity of propaganda, which, together with the lack of objective information, affects not only the opinion of the people of the European Union and its Member States, but of the people of the world at all. Any further escalation of tension is undesirable. That is why the representatives of the European Union, in close cooperation with the representatives of the Member States, must use all diplomacy, contacts and international conventions and treaties to reverse this unfavourable situation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 10/6/2015, but also because it promotes the revival of a cold war climate in Europe, which does not contribute to the consolidation of peace in the wider region.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report which claims to judge the situation in Crimea. It should be remembered that this annexation, supposedly illegal, is in fact the result of a popular decision of Crimea which has expressed itself democratically in favour of an attachment to Russia.  This text includes both threats against Russia (more sanctions), an enslavement to NATO (which alone can protect us from the great evil Russia), and even goes so far as to officially suggest that the Union become an arms dealer supplying Kiev (as if this were not already the case...).  The conclusion of this report, as always, is that Russia wants to start a new Cold War and that only a strengthening of a common security and defence policy - and therefore more Europe - can save us from it.  We are opposed to this biased statement of the situation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. This illegal annexation has altered the military balance in the Black Sea basin, which is one of the most strategic regions in the world, which is crucial for the EU and its Member States. Furthermore, this act violated the fundamental principles and values of democracy and international law, destabilising the policy of neighbouring countries.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully share the view that the Black Sea basin is a region of strategic importance to the European Union and its Member States. However, my assessment of the strategy to be adopted to ensure greater security within the area remains unresolved. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting on this report.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The situation in the Black Sea basin has undergone significant changes following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. That is why I support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution which supports the non-recognition of this annexation. We also believe that the EU and member states must respond to the challenges posed by this new security situation, and reconsider their foreign and security policies. The Black Sea region must be a real priority for the EU and we must take all necessary security measures in that area and for the nearest states.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Since, in my view, the proposals of this totally unbalanced and one-sided report would only lead to an intensification of the conflict and see the trigger and cause of the conflict exclusively in Russia, I have decided against it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ The Irish PPE delegation abstained on a number of votes in the report on ʽStrategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russiaʼ. These votes concern issues such as: providing Ukraine with defensive arms, urging Member States to increase their defence spending and enhancing the military capabilities of NATO in the Black Sea Basin. Ireland is a neutral country and is not a Member of NATO; the status of countries such as Ireland should be respected in this instance. While we support the EU’s approach to the crisis in Ukraine, we do not believe that all EU Member States should be obliged to support NATO policy action in the region. Since the general intention of the report is positive, we voted in favour of the final report but abstained on a number of separate votes.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report urges the Commission and the Council to adopt new sanctions against Russia and even to consider the delivery of arms to Ukraine! It calls on states to increase their defence budgets and to stand ready to "mobilize European naval and air forces in the Black Sea".  It calls for better "coordination with NATO in particular the Black Sea states and the United States" which have already launched paratrooper teams in Ukraine.  Common security policy but also neighbourhood policy, energy strategy: everything is good to participate in a policy going to war against Moscow. This is not a "courageous and effective attitude" but an outbid in the escalation of tensions that this Parliament is launching here. I am voting against these words, which increasingly take on the colour of a true declaration of war.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is a caricature so it seems exaggerated. More moderate comments would have been desirable. Russia is alleged to be guilty of "annexation of Crimea" but also responsible for "the escalation of military violence in Crimea". Based on the NATO report, which aims to fight Russia. The European Union, true to itself, denies democracy and the right of peoples to self-determination. Indeed, it refuses to recognise the referendum of 16 March 2014. Moreover, this Russian-speaking report prompts a partnership with Turkey against Russia and a submission to the Americans through NATO. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it highlights the various ways in which the Union can respond to the reality in Ukraine and the Black Sea Basin. The report stresses that the EU should strengthen its own resilience to various threats. The report also expresses hope that the Minsk ceasefire agreement will not collapse and will allow for further negotiations to take place.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The military-strategic situation in the Black Sea has changed considerably as a result of Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. With the adoption of this report, the European Parliament reiterates once again that it will not recognise this fact and reiterates its commitment to the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine.  This annexation has serious consequences for the European Union and its allies as a result of Russia's militarization of the Crimean peninsula. Such deployments represent a major strategic setback for NATO, some of whose member states are now at Russia's doorstep. However, this report remains balanced as it reminds us that Russia must remain a long-term partner, provided that it returns to international legality.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing \ u2012 The Black Sea region is the only strategically important area and is essential for security, Foreign Policy and the EU Eastern Partnership, as evidenced by the introduction of the Black Sea Synergy in 2008. This act of annexation has subsequently upset the military balance in the region, and the Russian side now illegally controls the Crimean coast and adjacent waters in close proximity to the BORDERS of NATO and the EU. I agree that the EU and the Member States should prepare a security response to the annexation of the Crimean peninsula, as gross violations of international agreements must not be tolerated. I also support the proposal to call on Russia to fully respect the Minsk agreements and the full withdrawal of Russian military force from Ukraine's territory. Although Russia has not been a reliable partner on security issues lately, I still believe that there needs to be a constructive dialogue in terms of long-term plans, not a path of confrontation. On the other hand, however, the EU cannot withdraw from its demands. We must take a firm stance and strengthen our resilience to Russia's aggressor tendencies.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the report to be very important not only because of its closely held subject matter, but also because it looks comprehensively at the increasingly aggressive foreign policy of the Russian Federation and, as part of this, its threat of war against Russia's neighbours. I have no doubt that the current Russian leadership cannot be restrained or dethrosed by concessions or generous gestures. The European Union (and NATO) must show unethy to avert Russia's crackdown on its other neighbours, including possibly EU countries. I consider this report to be the right step in this direction, which is why I voted for it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union, through its European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership, has been present in supporting development and growth in countries such as Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. That is why we must strongly condemn the illegal and illegitimate annexation of Crimea, which has caused enormous instability in the Black Sea basin. We cannot accept once again what happened in Georgia in 2008, particularly in the Regions of Abkhazia and Ossetia.  The Union should therefore support Ukraine and recognise the illegal annexation of Crimea and, from here, work together with the NATO Partners and the Eastern Partnership countries. I believe that the Minsk ceasefire must be used to find a solution to the destabilisation of Eastern Ukraine. However, if Russia does not respect the same, the Union must rethink economic sanctions and, together with NATO, find ways to strengthen the capacity of threatened countries.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the "strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea" echoes the previous report on Russia. In an eminently anti-Russian approach, which makes Russia all evils, he calls Russia's annexation of Crimea "an illegal annexation", but blames Russia for "the escalation of military violence in Crimea" when the only source of this report is NATO, an organization totally subject to American interests and whose sole purpose is to hit Russia in accordance with the precepts.  Of course, he refused recognition of the referendum of 16 March 2014, although confirmed by recent polls carried out by independent institutes. The European Union thus confirms that it does not appreciate democracy, much less the CHARTER of the United Nations proclaiming the right of peoples to self-determination. Finally, the report calls for a strategic partnership with Turkey (a country to which the Union cannot fault) to counter Russia and thus submit to the American and 'Otanian' desideratas.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. – Russia’s challenge to the international legal order in the wider Black Sea region has generated, and will further require, both tactical and strategic responses from the EU, NATO, and all the Black Sea States. The report dealing with the strategic, political and military implications of the illegal annexation of Crimea, and of the military conflict in Eastern Ukraine, for the security situation in the Black Sea Basin is thus timely and necessary.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. In particular, this text welcomes France's decision to "reconsider the delivery of Mistral-class amphibious assault ships to Russia (...) to terminate this market unequivocally and definitively." For my part, I am opposed to the decision of François Hollande, which discredits our commercial signature. I would remind you that the breach of contract will cost French taxpayers more than one billion euros.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea basin following Russia's annexation of Crimea. There are many elements to doubt Russia's willingness to respect the Minsk agreement. With this text, the European Parliament expresses its concern and condemns the human rights violations committed by Russia. The European Union should strengthen its resilience, security and defence capacity as well as develop its energy independence.  However, I voted against the paragraphs calling on NATO to actively support the defence policies of the countries in the region. Indeed, NATO's strategic directions and policy choices are not within the competence of the European Union.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Black Sea basin is one of the most strategic regions in the world, of vital importance to the European Union and its Member States, particularly when it comes to ensuring their security and defence, and also of great importance for the Neighbourhood and Eastern Partnership Policy. We reiterate our strong opposition to Russia's annexation of Crimea, reaffirming our commitment to Ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity.  We note, with concern, that the illegal annexation of Crimea has led to a significant change in the strategic landscape of the Black Sea basin, leading to a return to a hostile approach based on the confrontation of two blocs. We express our concern at the intensification of Russian pressure on the EU's eastern border, which is also being exerted on Romania, Poland and the Baltic states. We see the recent close overflights by Russian fighter jets on NATO warships and exploratory platforms in the Black Sea as a tangible sign of a more aggressive Russian attitude and warn of a high risk of aggravation of the situation. We express the hope that the ceasefire agreement reached in Minsk will be respected and will contribute to a negotiated political solution.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted for this report and the state of play it sets out. However, I am reserved about calls to NATO.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the concerns about strategic changes in the Black Sea basin following Russia's annexation of Crimea, but I do not agree with the strategy that this report proposes. I believe that sanctions are not the right answer to this problem. Russia's isolation is bad for Europe as a whole and for the whole system of international relations. If we care about the prosperity and peace of the continent, we must step up our efforts to rebuild a dialogue with that country. I have therefore chosen to abstain from voting on it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The Black Sea Basin is one of the world’s most strategic regions, with high importance to the European Union and its Member States, thus ensuring their security and defence. I have voted in favour of this report, which highlights the strategic importance of the Black Sea Basin to my country, Romania, and also to the whole European Union.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I did not support the report on martial law in the Black Sea Basin because I believe that the aggressive language in it will lead to a worsening of the situation in the region. I do not support paragraph 16 calling for a tightening of economic measures between the EU and Russia. The "war of sanctions" that began Europe is difficult for thousands of Europeans. In a state of almost ubiquitous economic crisis, thousands of farmers are forced to seek alternatives to the traditional Russian market for them without adequate assistance from the European Commission. I also disapprove of the call for explicit NATO coordination with the US, as well as the Alliance's activities in the Black Sea region. With such texts, the EP gives a disproportionate burden to the American side for intervention in this European region.  I also do not endorse the recommendation to expand NATO missile defence in the Black Sea region. Just months ago, the North Atlantic Alliance said the goal of this defense was not Russia. The deployment of such facilities in the Black Sea region would lead to rapid responses and unnecessary escalation of tensions in the region – something that no EU citizen will approve!

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Caith mé vóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo.  Tá an tuarascáil seo ag lorg cur chuige níos míleata ó AE chun dul i ngleic le cúrsaí sa réigiún. Tá Sinn Féin tiomanta do neodracht na hÉireann agus mar sin chaitheamar vóta i gcoinne an-chuid gnéithe, go háirithe na cinn a bhí ag lorg láidriú ar an gcur chuige míleata. D’iarr an tuarascáil seo freisin ar an gCoimisiún tacaíocht a thabhairt do Bhallstáit agus iad ag déanamh iarracht réitigh a aimsiú chun an buiséad cosanta a ardú go 2%, agus cuirtear fáilte roimh an ngealltanas atá déanta ag comhaltaí NATO a chinntiú go gcaithfidh siad ar a laghad 2% den OTI ar chaiteachas cosanta roimh 2024.  Ní cheapaim go bhfuil sé ceart nó cóir in aon chor níos mó airgid a chaitheamh ar chúrsaí míleata, go háirithe sa lá atá inniu ann leis an gcúlú eacnamaíochta agus an tionchar tubaisteach atá aige ar ghnáthdhaoine de bharr na ngearrthaí siar uafásacha sa bhuiséad.  Creidim go gcuirfidh an cur chuige míleata a mholtar sa tuarascáil seo leis an teannas atá sa réigiún faoi láthair agus mar sin chaith mé vóta ina choinne.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome this report because I believe that Russia's new behaviour and Russia's illegal occupation of Crimea has created a fundamentally new situation to which we must respond. A strong and unified EU-wide position is in place, which will not change its position to date and will continue to regard Russia's annexation of Crimea as an illegal act contrary to the principles of international law. Russia has gained a base for further potential expansion by annexing Crimea, and the EU should respond to the strengthening of Russian troops in Crimea with concrete steps aimed at ensuring its own security.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because, in my opinion, the report does not have a comprehensive security strategy. I am in favour of revising the security strategies for the Black Sea region, only then can we consider approving the report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The biggest source of tension in the Black Sea security regime is the continued Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea. The international community must make every decision to stop russia's militarisation of Crimea, including a plan to place nuclear weapons. However, the situation in Crimea and eastern Ukraine is not the only one that is a source of tension in the situation in the Black Sea region. The frozen conflict in Transnistria finally needs a positive solution based on moldova's territorial integrity. Otherwise, this is a possible new crisis. Russia must move its troops out of Transnistria. In addition, Abkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia have been annexed, which at the same time has increased the possibility of a new conflict and tensions in the region. Therefore, the european Union and the international community as a whole must monitor and ensure the restoration and compliance of international law in the Black Sea region. All five areas of frozen conflict caused by Russia are in the Black Sea region.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The Black Sea basin is one of the most strategically important regions on the planet and is of fundamental importance to the security of the EU and its Member States. That is why it must be a real priority for the EU.  Russia's annexation of Crimea and Sebastopol violates numerous international standards. But it doesn't end like this: we are concerned about strengthening Russia's defensive and offensive military capability in the Black Sea, and in this sense coordination with NATO is critically important. Many of the Member States of our eastern borders have sounded the alarm, and the hostile Russian attitude cannot be ignored. But we must be warm: we cannot let the Russian situation scale in an uncontrollable way.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have chosen to abstain from the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. Relations with Russia, being one of the main players on the international stage, should generally be more cooperative than confrontational in the long term. It is up to eu policymakers to continue the constructive dialogue with Russia that began with the Minsk agreements, hoping that the ceasefire agreement reached on 12 February 2015 will be respected and thus providing time for a negotiated political solution. In this context, Russia needs to be reassured that both EU-Ukraine cooperation and NATO's commitment to support the regional efforts of the Black Sea states are not military actions taken against Moscow. The further militarisation of the region can only lead to serious consequences for both sides. In order to achieve long-term peace and stability, Russia and all parties involved should use their influence to stop hostilities, prevent more war crimes and new victims.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report is the war cry of the Euro-Atlantic monopolies for generalised imperialist intervention by the EU and NATO in the Black Sea, Black Sea, Caucasus and the wider Eurasian region. It is a map of military operations and interventions in the region that is being drawn up by the political staff of monopolies to strengthen their positions in their competition with Russian capitalism. Even the language used is the same as that of NATO's military "hawks".  The report calls not only for the installation of NATO forces and bases in areas stretching from Poland and the Baltic countries to Georgia and Azerbaijan, but also in the presence of strong EU naval and air forces, to control their energy sources and pipelines to the EU. It demonstrates how dangerous the EU is to the peoples of its Member States and other countries. It does not hesitate, in order to defend the profitability of capital, to prepare even a general conflict in the wider region by all means, with immeasurable bloodshed for the peoples, as its intervention, together with the USA and NATO, in Ukraine shows.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the situation in the Black Sea basin, I would like to vote in favour because the rapporteur, Mr Pașcu, has done an excellent job, focusing on the sensitive issues concerning Russia's dangerous deployment of conventional naval forces and bombers that allow tactical missiles to reach the Bosphorus. I agree with the need not to recognise the annexation of Crimea and I hope that we can achieve an effective dialogue with Russia.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support this strong resolution by which the European Parliament clearly and unequivocally gives its position on the situation in the Black Sea area. It is with regret that I must remember that such strong resolutions were not in the time of the war that destroyed my country in the early 1990s.  The non-reaction at the time when the reaction was needed was detrimental to Slovenia, devastating for Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also for other countries created by the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia. This resolution also comes too late. History repeats itself. The policies of the regime that reign in the Russian Federation have been encouraged by non-response in previous times, during the Crisis in Georgia or events in the Caucasus area. We know from our own European history how totalitarian regimes respond to the passivity of the democratic world.  We have to ask ourselves, isn't our passivity the cause of strengthening the new totalitarian regime in the east? Caring for our own good and not caring for the well-being of our neighbor will eventually result in a situation in which there will be no more neighbors to help us, but with an even more difficult and greater challenge we will have to bear alone.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea is yet another example of what could probably be described as Russophobia among many European officials. The proliferation of resolutions to this effect in the European Parliament is becoming ridiculous.  Let us remember for the umpteenth time that Russia is not an adversary, let alone an enemy of European nations. Each State is of course free to decide for itself the foreign policy it wishes to pursue, but I hope that my country, France, will have normal and non-belligerent relations with Russia. For these reasons, I cannot approve this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although the EU must continue to insist on the consistent application of international law and non-compliance with violent border change, significant strategic changes in the Black Sea basin triggered by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea must simply not be ignored. Internal political instability of states in the wider Black Sea region and frozen conflicts in Pridnjestrovlje, Abkhasia, South Ossetia and Nagorno Karabakh have already influenced the increase in instability in the Black Sea region.  However, we must be aware that the occupation of the entire locationally extremely important peninsula further complicates the security situation in europe's closest neighbourhood. Crimea, as the most singuthed part of the mainland within the Black Sea, is invaluable strategic military importance and its control greatly facilitates the control of the entire Basin. The presence of Russian forces in Crimea and the further strengthening of the Russian Black Sea military fleet located in Sevastopol significantly increases Russia's operating capacity within the region.  The annexation of Crimea has resulted in a change that has concrete implications for defence and security policy and for the union's energy, trade, transport and maritime policy. The EU must respond to the changed circumstances and update the European Security Strategy, the European Maritime Security Strategy and the EU Strategy for the Black Sea. Because my colleague Pașcu's report is a kind of first step in the process, I firmly support it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I believe that the annexation of Crimea has indeed changed the strategic situation in the Black Sea region. This has opened up new opportunities for Russia to support, for example, the Crossbow quasi-state. I believe that European states, especially through NATO, must respond to this new situation. The increased threat to EU and NATO countries on the Black Sea is obvious in the current political situation in the region, and these partner countries of ours deserve our support and reassurance that they will not be left alone in any problems.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, the geopolitical balance of the peripheral region, particularly the Black Sea basin, is being called into question. MEPs wanted to react and adopted a resolution on the strategic and military situation in the Black Sea basin. I voted in favour of this text. I believe that it is crucial for the Union and for geopolitical stability at the Union's borders to define a common strategy between the Union and its Member States. The aim of this report is to raise awareness of the strategic importance of the Black Sea and to outline a possible rapprochement of European and national defence and security strategies.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol triggered a significant change in the strategic landscape and balance of the Black Sea military basin and adjacent areas. Russia's military actions, which resulted in the illegal and illegitimate annexation of Crimea, are subject to an attack plan aimed at strengthening strategic and tactical advantages in order to ensure control and exploitation of oil and gas transport in the Black Sea. Moreover, with the occupation of the entire peninsula, Russia also managed a launch ing pad to the West (the Balkans, the Transnistria and the mouth of the Danube) and to the South (Eastern Mediterranean). Whereas the new Russian military doctrine violates the provisions listed in the Charter of the United Nations and the Helsinki Final Act, and whereas this military infrastructure, with its broad operational scope, poses a serious threat to the entire Black Sea region, the EU is called to consider its strategic interests, identify new defence solutions and rethink its common security policy (which necessarily includes energy policy). I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Today I supported the report on the strategic and military position in the Black Sea Basin. Its stability and prosperity are of strategic importance to the European Union.  Russia has significantly changed the configuration of the region through the illegal annexation of Crimea, the violation of Georgia's territorial integrity and its attitude towards unresolved "frozen" conflicts. This return to a policy of force and militarism of the 20th century is opposed to the peace project that European construction represents. Such belligerent behaviour is contrary to international norms, the principle of the inviolability of borders and all international conventions that Russia had committed to respect. The intensification of Russian pressure on our eastern border thus leads to a general perception that sees Russia move from strategic partner to strategic competitor, or even threat.  While I remain convinced that border security could be achieved through real cooperation with Russia, I cannot ignore the impact that the militarization of the Black Sea Basin can have on overall security in Europe.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the military-strategic situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's annexation of Crimea. The annexation is not in accordance with international law and violates the UN Charter, the Paris Charter and the OSCE Helsinki Final Act. Ukraine is independent, sovereign and must enjoy its territorial integrity.  It is clear that the situation is not improving. Many human rights violations have been committed in Crimea since the occupation by Russian forces. The Crimean Tatars are particularly victims of the regime because they supported the integrity of Ukrainian territory.  We recall that the Black Sea is a priority area for the European Union, particularly in terms of security and defence. Cooperation between Member States and the States bordering the Black Sea Basin must continue in order to resolve long-term conflicts that threaten the overall security of our continent.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU should not recognise Russia's annexation of Crimea, but rather reiterate its commitment to ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity, while demonstrating unity and firmness in its relations with the Russian Federation, implementing a new European security and defence strategy in close collaboration with NATO.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Black Sea basin is a strategic region for the EU. This Resolution urges Member States to continue without acknowledging the annexation of Crimea and condemns Russia's support for Ukrainian separatists.  NATO-Russia cooperation is requested to be based on a change in its policy towards Ukraine and for the sanctions regime to be extended if Minsk ceasefire agreements are not fully implemented. The Resolution notes that NATO has a moral obligation to strengthen the defence capabilities of Georgia and Ukraine, while urging the Commission to update its strategy for the region.  Beyond the purely military, Member States are encouraged to diversify their energy sources, and the Commission is encouraged to continue negotiations on the pipeline that will connect the EU with Turkey. Human rights violations during the conflict are also requested to be investigated and concern is expressed about the environmental impact that the conflict may be having on the region.  That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following russia's illegal annexation of Crimea and the violation of territorial integrity in Georgia, the European Parliament has once again strongly condemned these aggressions by Russia, expressing its deep concern at military escalation, in particular in terms of marine means in the Black Sea Region. To this end, I am in favour of the adoption of this Resolution which reaffirms the need for firm and one-voice positions, both at EU and NATO level, while respecting the international legal framework, while stressing the importance of the Union strengthening its independence at energy level, as well as maritime/border security. Continued human rights violations in the occupied areas (and also in Russia itself), including intimidation and an increase in the number of cases of enforced disappearances, censorship of freedom of expression and persecution of minorities, deserve strong condemnation. I also call for all means to investigate and prosecute war crimes committed in these Regions (and human rights abuses) to be used, and I look forward to the timely intervention of the international community, including the Hague Court, in the investigation of possible crimes that have occurred.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution tabled in plenary by the Committee on Foreign Affairs concerning the 'strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following russia's illegal annexation of Crimea'. Once again, parliament's eyes turned to the east during the plenary session, where the situation is very worrying following Russia's annexation of Crimea. It is, in fact, a strategic achievement, where, among other things, it has set up a permanent naval task force, which allows Putin's Russia to see the Balkan area more and more closely. This situation does not only concern Europe from the point of view of how to resolve relations with the Soviets, but also draws attention to the urgent need to review the European security strategy and the European Neighbourhood Policy, a change which should aim at better cooperation with the partner states bordering on the Black Sea.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against it as the Resolution is extremely belligerent and unable to reflect critically on the role of the European Union in the current situation in the Black Sea basin. All critical amendments with the EU's role in the conflict, which allude to the creation of prospects for diplomatic dialogue based on good understanding, were rejected. Moreover, this text does not contribute in any way to the resolution of tensions between the European Union and Russia; otherwise, it encourages them. We cannot vote for it, as we support a Europe of dialogue and peace, not a challenging Europe with its neighbouring countries.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 The report aims to respond to the changes in the strategic relations between the Black Sea Basin and the surrounding region caused by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The report underlines that the increasing Russian military presence in the Black Sea, as well as the means to carry nuclear weapons deployed in Crimea, require the continuation and tightening of sanctions against Russia, provided that it does not change its policy towards Ukraine. The report calls on the European Union to continue its initiatives to diversify energy sources in the Black Sea and encourages Member States to take steps to reduce their energy dependency.  It draws attention to the importance of joint security and defence policy cooperation with partner States along the Black Sea coast and to support osce initiatives to facilitate the increased presence and security situation in the region. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Russia’s challenge to the international legal order initiated in the wider Black Sea region generated and will further require both tactical and strategic responses from the EU and NATO and from all the Black Sea states. The report dealing with the strategic, political and military implications of the illegal annexation of Crimea and of the military conflict in Eastern Ukraine for the security situation in the Black Sea Basin is thus timely and needed.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I abstained from voting. The West cannot ignore Russia's aggressive action, which resembles geopolitics during the Cold War. We have a moral obligation to confront him not only with the situation in Ukraine, for which he is directly responsible, but also with other 'frozen conflicts' in Georgia, Moldova, etc. The situation following the annexation of Crimea requires a unified approach in the response of EU states.  Economic sanctions are not perfect, but at the same time they are the only answer that the EU has today. At the same time, however, dialogue needs to be conducted with the Russian Federation and efforts must be made to comply with the Minsk agreements aimed at resolving the conflict in Ukraine. I consider a military solution that will cause even more tension in the region as a last resort.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the Black Sea region is one of the most strategically important regions in the world and is essential for the EU and its Member States, particularly in terms of ensuring our security and defence, but also for the EU's neighbourhood policy and the Eastern Partnership. It should be borne in mind that, for the first time since the end of the Second World War, part of one state has been annexed to another, which is contrary to international law. The offensive by separatists in eastern Ukraine, supported by modern armaments, clearly demonstrates that Russia is the aggressor in this conflict. And this is a dangerous precedent for the future. What is happening in Ukraine is an attack on our European values, and we must defend ourselves. When a government disputes this, no one will guarantee that in the future the other members of the European Union will be in solidarity with it if they find themselves in a similar situation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as the Black Sea basin is an important external border of the European Union and that the illegal annexation of Crimea in the Black Sea basin has changed the relationship between military forces, and so now Russia is illegally monitoring hundreds of kilometres of Crimean coastline and nearby waters bordering nato and the EU at sea.  I believe that by occupying the entire peninsula, Russia has gained an extremely important base for launching actions to the west and south in which it has already established a permanent naval battle group. In the event that Russia does not fully implement the Minsk ceasefire agreements, the sanctions regime should continue and intensify. Furthermore, Ukraine, the Republic of Moldova and Georgia should consider strengthening cooperation with each other, for example by considering the creation of a multinational unit and supporting NATO Member States with these initiatives. The implementation of EU energy policy aimed at promoting energy security and initiatives to diversify Black Sea energy sources through, inter alia, investments and financial measures is also essential. The Commission should also support Member States in their efforts to find solutions to increase defence budgets to 2% of GDP.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ I supported the proposal. I condemn Russia's activities in Crimea, which are contrary to international law, Russian President Putin's statements about readiness to use nuclear forces, as well as human rights violations in Crimea.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea area following the illegal annexation of Crimea to Russia. I support good relations with Russia, I support cooperation and not conflict, but not at the expense of illegal and illegitimate acts and violations of fundamental principles of international law. The European Union must therefore strongly condemn the illegal annexation of Crimea and consider its external and security policies in order to change the geostratetic situation. The key here is that the European Union is united and united in its efforts, which is the only reason that it leads to an effective response to security and political threats.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, as it rightly draws attention to the need to develop a new EU security strategy for the Black Sea region. The situation in the Black Sea region has fundamentally changed following russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, which crimea immediately began to use as a cornerstone of its aggressive policy in the Black Sea region and not just there. The resolution rightly calls for an active and uniform policy between EU and NATO Member States in the region and for the reduction of defence budgets to be stopped. The Black Sea is also a strategic area for the European Union in the field of energy and migration, so the EU needs to actively and relentlessly promote its interest in Russian-independent energy supplies and its interest in the possibilities for effective protection of the EU's external border.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, taking into account that I have already supported another important report on EU-Russian relations on this closely related subject. In it, the EP gave a clear verdict to the world and Moscow on the illegal annexation of Crimea and the military violence in Ukraine as the main reasons for the deterioration of relations. The report referred to here, which focuses on the Black Sea region, adds important geopolitical and military aspects and also expresses clear European expectations for NATO and other strategic partners in terms of assessing and managing Putin's policy. I considered the report's finding that Putin is currently testing the tolerances of the EU and the democratic international community in the Mediterranean as a particularly politically important point of view. I believe that these Putin's efforts, which pose an immediate threat to individual EU Member States, make it a direct EU or EP task and responsibility to respond effectively to the Russian challenge. Against this background, I also consider it important for the future of European foreign and security policy to receive the warnings and proposals of this report.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European citizens who read this resolution will stock up on canned beans and cockerels. Unfortunately, Europe, which has united in order not to repeat the mistakes of two world wars, by adopting this text, is preparing a third and, if possible, even more serious, is doing so in order to defend interests that are not its own. Pascu's resolution deliberately mystifies events in Eastern Europe in order to give Russia aggressive behaviour and to identify russia as the EU's great enemy. In order to re-establish the truth of the facts, an equally long text would be necessary: I am not allowed to do so. I voted against. I would just like to remind you of one thing: this resolution flattens the European Union on NATO, as if NATO were the only bulwark against Russian aggression. But it's actually NATO that's been expanding to Russia for years. Until 1990, NATO's eastern borders were closed to Italy and West Germany; Continuing eastwards, a belt of buffer states (from Yugoslavia to Finland), the Warsaw Pact countries and finally the borders of the USSR met in order. The question arises as to whether those who drafted and then approved this text have a conscience or are sufficiently lucid mentally.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote. Not that my colleague's text is not good or that I do not share the same desire for peace in the sector, but because some of the amendments have disappointed me and seems to me to be seen as provocative. For the rest, I am in favour of the autonomy of the peoples and the right of them to self-determination and strongly condemns the illegal occupation of Crimea by Russia.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The illegal annexation of Crimea has created a significant change in the strategic landscape of the Black Sea Basin and this is why the EU should pay particular attention to this region.  If the wording of this report is in some cases, and in my point of view, not always appropriate, I nevertheless decided to vote in favour of this report as the EU needs to draw up, as soon as possible, a comprehensive EU strategy for the Black Sea region. The EU and its Member States must have a security response to the challenges in this area.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted for a report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea.  The historical circumstances that divided Ukraine on both cultural and political grounds have led to the situation that this space plays a decisive strategic role, and the Black Sea basin in some ways forms the backbone of world politics and economics.  Ukraine's security neutrality will only be possible if mutual efforts are made to de-escalate violence and peacefully reintegrate the occupied territories into Ukraine's constitutional-legal order.  We must not allow further preservation of the status quo in the east of Ukraine, and therefore support efforts to approach the development of a comprehensive European Union strategy for the Black Sea region to prevent a situation where Ukraine could be recognised as a collateral victim in geostrategic and geopolitical competitions and to protect its national interests.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ I supported the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea area following the illegal annexation of Crimea to Russia. With the wrongful annexation of Crimea, Russia has acquired strategically important territory. Both military and energy. The EU must respond. It must liad with the other Black Sea countries and strengthen its military capabilities, while maintaining a democratic dialogue with Russia that would lead to the resolution of the situation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against it as the Resolution is extremely belligerent and unable to reflect critically on the role of the European Union in the current situation in the Black Sea basin. All critical amendments with the EU's role in the conflict, which allude to the creation of prospects for diplomatic dialogue based on good understanding, were rejected. Moreover, this text does not contribute in any way to the resolution of tensions between the European Union and Russia; otherwise, it encourages them. We cannot vote for it, as we support a Europe of dialogue and peace, not a challenging Europe with its neighbouring countries.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted, in the context of the serious events in Ukraine in 2014 and 2015, in favour of the report on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. Due to its neighbourhood position, the stability of the Black Sea region is fundamental to the security of the European Union, which is jeopardised by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. With this act in violation of international law, Russia has also been actively involved in destabilizing eastern Ukraine. In response to this major change in the strategic and security landscape of the Black Sea, the report recommends maintaining a strong position and continuing communication with Russia. However, due to a lack of confidence as a result of Russia's latest actions, any resumption of cooperation must be based, firstly, on NATO's firm strategic reassurance to its members in the East. , to restore control of the Ukrainian authorities over their territory within internationally recognised borders.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against it as the Resolution is extremely belligerent and unable to reflect critically on the role of the European Union in the current situation in the Black Sea basin. All critical amendments with the EU's role in the conflict, which allude to the creation of prospects for diplomatic dialogue based on good understanding, were rejected. Moreover, this text does not contribute in any way to the resolution of tensions between the European Union and Russia; otherwise, it encourages them. We cannot vote for it, as we support a Europe of dialogue and peace, not a challenging Europe with its neighbouring countries.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I strongly disagree with the excessively aggressive policy that the EU is pursuing against Russia following its annexation of Crimea. While condemning Russia’s invasion of Crimea, I believe that the country still remains a world superpower with which the EU has to maintain dialogue. Any disputes must be solved through peaceful and diplomatic means, leaving aside any aggressive attitudes that might lead to the most undesirable of results – war. While any further escalation of the already existing tensions must be avoided at all costs, this report in my opinion goes exactly in the opposite direction, hence my decision to cast my vote against it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. In view of the current situation following the Russia-Ukraine conflict, this report is vital and necessary to alert you to changes in the Black Sea basin and the possible consequences this may have. That is why I think it is positive to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The text put to the vote is a political resolution aimed solely and exclusively at deliberately damaging relations between the European Union and Russia, which is unacceptable and forced me to vote against it. First, the Resolution instrumentalizes history in order to present Russia as to blame for the situation in Ukraine and responsible for strengthening NATO's military capabilities in Eastern Europe. The text goes so far as to propose not to rule out the application of Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, i.e. war. Rapporteur Pascu's bellicose proposal is complemented by a call to continue the policy of sanctions on Russia. I believe in peace and cooperation with our neighbors. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'If you followed the discussions in plenary, you had the idea that there were two reports on Russia layers that ran exactly parallel. I voted in favour of the report and believe that we should support the region. But that we would supply weapons to Kiev, that goes too far.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Again, this is a bellicose report against Russia. Blocked in a binary vision of the conflict in Ukraine, the right of the Chamber continues its relentlessness against Russia. The report therefore not only proposes the strengthening of sanctions against Russia, but also recommends "considering" delivering arms to Ukraine.  Even more implausible, the report calls on Moldova and Georgia to "consider intensifying their cooperation, particularly on the military level", all under the leadership of NATO and the United States, which are expressly named and presented as saviours. Let us stop this anti-Russian, primary anti-communist and bellicose propaganda.  Yes, Russia is critical on certain issues and we do not idealize it, but it is a major strategic partner on the international scene and our interest lies in cooperation. It is a Europe that is a vector of peace, capable of helping to resolve the conflicts we need, not a Europe that is putting oil on the fire and thinking it has returned to the cold war. Let us also keep our eyes on the reality of what is happening in Ukraine.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Since, in my view, the proposals of this totally unbalanced and one-sided report would only lead to an intensification of the conflict and see the trigger and cause of the conflict exclusively in Russia, I have decided against it.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea region. The resolution deals with the Black Sea region, but is not objective, but one-sidedly anti-Russian and measures double standards. The fact that the West has also intervened in Ukraine for many years with great financial commitment is not mentioned. It is complained that Russia has obtained a second Kaliningrad with Crimea, a second part of the territory with direct external borders with NATO. The fact that the EU and NATO want to establish themselves direct borders with Russia through accession considerations with regard to Georgia and Ukraine seems to be forgotten. It also complains that Russia is expanding bases in the Black Sea region and maintaining a fleet there. But NATO countries also have a military presence there, which is not taken into account. From this one-sided world view, the resolution logically calls for the sanctions against Russia to be maintained and strengthened. It is worth remembering that in the end troops will cross the border where goods are not allowed to do so. Free trade instead of sanctions! I call for de-escalation of all sides involved in the conflict. This resolution alone contributes to the worsening of the situation.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. – In light of the escalation in the conflict between Russia and the western democracies, including inter alia the build-up of military forces, the risk of a possible arms race and Russian threats of use of nuclear arms, I consider the calls for NATO forces to be moved to the Black Sea Basin an ill-advised and confrontational suggestion. Because of this, I abstained in the vote on this resolution.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Russia needs to cooperate in the long term in our interest, but in the current situation this cooperation is not possible. An alliance and close cooperation with NATO, a successful defence and military grouping, is now important for the EU, and this political crisis in relations with Russia cannot be used as an argument for building parallel structures at European level.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report is the war cry of the Euro-Atlantic monopolies for generalised imperialist intervention by the EU and NATO in the Black Sea, Black Sea, Caucasus and the wider Eurasian region. It is a map of military operations and interventions in the region that is being drawn up by the political staff of monopolies to strengthen their positions in their competition with Russian capitalism. Even the language used is the same as that of NATO's military "hawks".  The report calls not only for the installation of NATO forces and bases in areas stretching from Poland and the Baltic countries to Georgia and Azerbaijan, but also in the presence of strong EU naval and air forces, to control their energy sources and pipelines to the EU. It demonstrates how dangerous the EU is to the peoples of its Member States and other countries. It does not hesitate, in order to defend the profitability of capital, to prepare even a general conflict in the wider region by all means, with immeasurable bloodshed for the peoples, as its intervention, together with the USA and NATO, in Ukraine shows.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the motion for a resolution was in response to Russia's annexation of Crimea, as well as other Russian activities linked to the ongoing attacks on the territorial integrity of Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova. By doing so, Russia is clearly violating international agreements, as well as military equilibrium in the Strategic Black Sea region, not to mention the threat of the deployment of nuclear weapons in Crimea, which would have un lousy consequences. For these reasons, I think it is very important for the European Union to act unanimously in accordance with the principle of solidarity, thereby showing that it will not ignore the security threats coming from Russia. At the same time, the proposal stressed the need to develop a security strategy, including safety at sea, as well as calling on the Commission to support Member States' efforts to increase the defence budget. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution, given its importance, its importance for the revision of the common security and defence policy and the need for a single procedure.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The resolution adopted today describes the current situation in the Black Sea region very precisely, as per the standards of this institution. Russia is an aggressor who not only breaches international obligations by undermining Ukraine's territorial integrity through the annexation of Crimea, but also changes the military balance in the region in a way that is extremely detrimental to the security of the European Union. It is unfortunate that it was only after seven years that the consequences of ignoring Russian aggression against Georgia were noted, and how much the lack of a firm European response then influenced Vladimir Putin's further actions.  However, we cannot wait any longer and we must take effective action together. NATO's role here is enormous and it is a pleasure to see that. Even without cooperation with Turkey, it will be impossible to stop Russian expansion. I fully agree with the call to maintain and strengthen the system of sanctions imposed on Russia and to consider providing ukraine with defensive weapons. Security should be our common concern, and at the moment the main military threat to Europe is Russia. We do not want war, but we cannot passively observe violations of international law in our immediate neighbourhood. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, I welcome this resolution. I think it is important that the European Union speaks with one voice when it comes to dealing with the corruption cases that have dogged FIFA for many years. Good governance is absolutely essential in the beautiful game and is something that we all very much welcome across the European Union because of the importance of football as the great international sport that it is. I would like to refer to one issue which has arisen as a consequence of this entire sorry saga and which involves the Football Association of Ireland (FAI) in my own country, where a payment of EUR 5 million was given to the FAI to deal with an issue that went back to the qualifiers for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. In my view, what was given to the FAI – an unusual payment – was nonetheless small change by comparison to the great injustice that was meted out to Ireland on that occasion, because of the fact that we did not get through to the World Cup qualifiers. On that occasion the issue was addressed. The rules of the qualifiers were changed by Mr Blatter and, indeed, Mr Blatter broke a confidentiality clause. So in terms of the payment given to the FAI: yes, it was unusual, but that was put back into the purchasing of a stadium and, ultimately, into Irish football. In my view this was small change by comparison to what should have happened to Ireland on that occasion.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It was embarrassing. Corrupt networks are being built in a non-profit organisation, and no one notices anything. Help came here from the United States, which then brought down the corrupt network. Today, FIFA's national divisions follow the motto: "Keep the thief!" and outperform each other with suggestions for improvement. Let me be clear: this is not just about clarifying a few false bank transfers. No, this is about the elimination of corrupt networks in FIFA. It is also a question of restoring confidence in the many local clubs that are literally holding their bones. My demand at this point is quite simple: all presidents and boards of directors of the national divisions and boards should ask the question of confidence in order to be re-elected, so that the new beginning can really and really begin.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I totally agree with my colleague Mr Jahr, and I will just say that I do not think that the EU should comment on everything. However, the problem of long-term corruption, which has been quite obvious and has been written about by many periodicals, is an exception and the EU has the right to comment on football in this matter. I've played football, I watch football and I have to say that football is no longer, in my opinion, a wonderful game. It is not a beautiful game precisely because it has been discredited by a network built by fifa's board of directors or top bodies. I am glad that the position of the European UEFA was very clearly anti-corruption from the outset, and I think fifa now has a unique opportunity to cleanse itself so that real football is a wonderful game again.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm páirt a ghlacadh sa díospóireacht anseo aréir faoin ábhar seo. Bhí sé soiléir go raibh gach taobh den Pharlaimint i bhfabhar teachtaireacht a thabhairt do FIFA maidir leis an tslí a dhéanann siad a gcuid oibre agus tá sé sin tábhachtach. Dar ndóigh, is trua i ndáiríre nach raibh vóta le glao rolla againn ag an deireadh mar bheadh na figiúirí againn maidir le guth na Parlaiminte. Ach ba léir, mar a dúirt tú féin, go raibh tromlach mór i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo.  Tá súil agam go nglacfaidh údaráis FIFA leis an teachtaireacht agus go dtabharfaidh siad isteach na leasuithe atá ag teastáil ó thaobh riaracháin de chomh luath agus is féidir leo, mar tá siad ag déanamh éagóra ar dhaoine óga ach go háirithe sa tslí ina bhfuil siad á n-iompar féin faoi láthair.

name: Marian HARKIN
