text: – Madam President, there were a number of amendments to this report which I supported, but unfortunately the entire Parliament did not. These referred to the appalling situation in Qatar, where 1 993 migrant workers have already died building infrastructure for the World Cup, and also to the fact that the ILO tells us that, in certain cases, the three requirements for the definition of ‘forced labour’ are in place in Qatar. I find it extremely unfortunate that the House could not see its way to supporting those amendments today. The other issue raised by some of my colleagues here today, and indeed last night, is that of the EUR 5 million pay-out to the Irish authorities by FIFA. While I accept that this money was used to support small clubs, etcetera, I disagree with my colleague Brian Hayes when I ask the question: ‘does the end justify the means?’ In this case, I think it does not. At best, this was an improper transaction and, because of that, the money should be returned. Given that it has already been spent on small clubs, etcetera, I believe it is now the duty of the state to step in and give that money to the Football Association of Ireland. But we should return the money to FIFA.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I feel that I have maybe done the European Union a bit of a disservice. I have been here for16 years and I have been railing against fraud, waste and corruption – and heaven knows, there is plenty of it – but maybe I was unfair to pick on the European Union simply for sharing attributes that go with almost all global bureaucracies, including this one. The basic problem here is not that the EU attracts bad people. Of course it attracts some bad people – man is fallen, and there are always some individuals who will give in to temptation – but no more than any national government and no more than any other bureaucracy. The difference is the lack of accountability. The businessman is answerable to customers, clients and shareholders. We politicians are answerable to voters, at least in theory. But the Eurocrat, the FIFA delegate, the UN official, the member of the International Olympics Committee – you name it – they are accountable only to themselves and so can concentrate on making themselves comfortable, which is why the only solution, instead of setting up more probes and more inquiries, is to take power closer to the people so that you cut out the opportunity for the corruption.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Madam President, I voted against Amendment 19. While I totally agree that we should all condemn the alleged corruption in FIFA, I find it astonishing that, once again, politicians in this Chamber should call for more gender quotas, this time hidden within a resolution about corruption in FIFA. How is this going to resolve the corruption?

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The scandal related to the corruption episodes of fifa summits is something that mortifies the whole world of football and casts heavy shadows on one of the most popular and beloved sports. The genuine values of sport, such as friendship, healthy rivalry and competition, a sense of the limit, respect for the rules and the opponent, which should inform the entire football movement, seem to have been completely shelved.  The choices of FIFA's governing bodies, and sometimes also those of the various national federations, do not seem to be informed of those principles of financial fair play, good governance and transparency, all too often only proclaimed. We therefore need a thorough and very radical reform of FIFA, and of the system in general, which now seems completely out of control and governed solely by the logic of profit at all costs: there are countless cases, even in our country, of rigged matches, money laundering and fraud. This seems necessary also in the light of the social and educational role played today by footballers and professionals, especially with regard to the new generations. The resolution aims to raise all these issues and calls for the reform process to begin, so I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.).  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to combat corruption in football. It saddens me that sporting values are replaced by pure commercial interest: some of this we know in Spain, where urban scandals and non-payments to the Treasury and Social Security in football are the order of the day. However, it is important to note that under FIFA's corruption there is an even more serious reality: the exploitation of slave workers for the benefit of consumption and spectacle in a globalized world, as other multinationals do recognize their profit- There are 1,200 workers killed in Qatar during the preparation of the World Cup: that's the real scandal.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the immediate resignation of FIFA President Joseph Blatter, as called for in the motion for a resolution. The corrupt practices in FIFA have resulted in the reputation of world football in all classes, from amateur clubs, to be permanently destroyed. But football is more than corruption. It has a great social impact, especially for young people. A fundamental reform of FIFA is urgently needed to restore credibility. What FIFA needs now is an immediate transparent appointment of a new leader and a suitable interim president at the helm, who is credibly committed to reform. In my view, it is also important to call on all international sports federations to ensure that candidate countries must work for major events to respect fundamental rights. In this context, the working conditions for workers on the World Cup construction sites in Qatar are completely inhumane. According to research by the Washington Post, 1,200 guest workers have already died there. The world public must not simply accept this!

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution on the recent revelations of corruption within FIFA is generally positive. It recalls certain principles such as the fact that countries applying for an international competition must respect fundamental rights. For example, the unacceptable and inhumane working conditions of foreign workers in Qatar are denounced. Corruption, which is a hindrance to development and reduces trust between the various partners, must be tackled and I welcome the Fact That the Union is taking the problem into account. I am in favour of reforming the organisation, but I welcome the fact that the resolution is not too intrusive on this point.  I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls upon the Commission to take action with regard to the governance of football. Whilst I deplore what has been going on in FIFA, this EU power grab is all about the politicisation of sport. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Federalism has its virtues. Our twenty-eight European courts have been unable to challenge the turpitudes of FIFA in the world of football. Similarly, switzerland has renounced bank secrecy under pressure from the US authorities, as europeans have so far camped in pusillanimity.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the recent revelations by FIFA of high-level corruption cases and the selection of venues for international sporting events. I support calls for the human rights situation in the country to be taken into account, which is the host of the event. Major sporting events such as 12 June The first European Games, which will begin in Baku, should promote respect for human rights and universal values.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Qatar would not be content to subsidize some of the Islamists in Syria and Iraq?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Recently, the International Football Federation Association (FIFA) has been involved in corruption. Moreover, on the construction sites of the future stadiums in Qatar, slavery practices are to be regretted. It is unimaginable at this time that such practices will continue. With regard to human rights and in order to combat corruption and modern slavery, I am in favour of the statement of the Council and the Commission.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution on the latest revelations about corruption within FIFA strongly condemns corruption in sport and calls for a clear and transparent reform of FIFA. This text even manages not to be too intrusive, even if it mentions points on intolerance and the fight against discrimination. For years, there have been many suspicions about the motivations that led FIFA to award Qatar the 2022 World Cup. A gas emirate with no sporting tradition, the decision was all the more surprising. It is morally intolerable to have endorsed this attribution since we thus condone the actions of the Qatari dictatorship: financing terrorism, no law for women, persecution of homosexuals, despicable working conditions for Nepalese and Indian workers who die in numbers on construction sites, etc. This country dares to infiltrate the affairs of other countries by investing heavily in strategic enterprises or neighbourhoods, but above all by prosecuting those who dare to attack it, including parliamentarians. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. The report is not particularly critical, and I particularly agree with it in that it condemns cases of widespread corruption within fifa's top management, and I believe that there is a need for greater control and transparency, for these reasons I supported it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.). For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has outraged Parliament over the systematic and shocking corruption uncovered by FIFA and called on sports organisations, Member States and the EU to cooperate fully in the current and future investigations into the allegedly corrupt practices of FIFA. Parliament also stressed the importance of swiss and US judicial authorities investigating the fifa executive committee's decision to grant the right in 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022. The World Cups are held in France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar respectively.  Parliament also stressed the importance of ensuring that the further investigation into past corruption practices within FIFA includes, where justified, the removal of all officials involved in financial irregularities and the review of decisions relating to corruption or criminal activity, and called on the EU to closely monitor this process and to create the necessary conditions for an impartial external investigation. Finally, Parliament supported the statement by the head of fifa's audit and compliance committee that the rights to be drafted in 2018 and 2022 were granted. World Cups could be cancelled if evidence is found that the granting of these rights was caused by corruption.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Football and sport in general have a significant positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young people. Sport is a large and fast-growing sector of the EU economy that contributes significantly to growth and job creation. The resignation of Joseph Blatter and the arrest of FIFA officials have created the conditions for a radical reform of FIFA's structures and practices, which are needed to improve the governance of the organisation and clean up corruption and which urgently need to be implemented. Football is by far the most popular sport in the world. It is therefore of the utmost importance to put an end to all forms of corruption that could tarnish the integrity and reputation of football.  The European Parliament urges fifa's executive committee to implement structural reforms to achieve transparency and accountability within FIFA and to ensure open, balanced and democratic decision-making processes. We call on UEFA and the national football associations to step up their efforts to implement fifa's fundamental internal reforms, and in particular the recommendations of the resolution adopted today, by 2016. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I support the resolution on the corruption scandal in Fifa. I think it is right that we should also speak out loud about this problem in the European Parliament. This corruption scandal among the highest-ranking officials of the International Football Association has done damage not only to football, but to the sport as a whole. Football is becoming a bigger business year after year, turning millions, billions into it, which is the ideal basis for corruption. Those individuals who have engaged in these neo-ned-rich businesses and, as a result, illegally enriched themselves must be brought to justice. They have to pay for the damage they've done to football. Although the European Parliament does not have formal levers to influence the functioning of international organisations such as FIFA, it is very important that we talk about this problem and influence the reform of such organisations with our influence and pressure. This will also indirectly influence the eradication of corruption in sport. Now is the optimal opportunity for something concrete to change in sport as well.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I applaud the action of the U.S. investigative bodies that have tackled the punishment of incredible corruption in FIFA's top bodies. Football is the world's most popular sport, but this cannot be said of the world's umbrella football organization. The moral integrity of sports organizations is extremely important, as both professional and amateur sports play a key role in promoting world peace and respect for human rights and solidarity. They cannot fully fulfil this role if they are plagued by scandals. I call on the European Commission to continue to design a coordinated approach to the fight against organised crime in sport by aligning the efforts of sports organisations and national police and judicial authorities. Although the EU is not responsible for this, I want to take this opportunity to warn about the numerous negative phenomena in Croatian football and the work of its umbrella organization.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the recent revelations about corruption cases within FIFA show that the game of football has been governed undign deservedly over the last twenty years. Given the enormous economic interests at stake, I believe it is important to call for a radical renewal of the sport's leadership and greater transparency in all areas of FIFA's action.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The scandal at the fifa leadership level seriously affects the credibility of the world's best-known sports federation. It is sad that, on the one hand, athletes promote positive attitudes and the spirit of fair play, and on the other hand investigations reveal serious acts of corruption and money laundering, tending to the integrity of the federation. I am convinced that the very substantial sums invested in the football industry and the lack of a regulatory authority created the premises for the emergence of corruption and the creation of a cleptocratic structure that had control over the entire structure of the Federation. Sepp Blatter's resignation from the FIFA presidency does not fully solve the problem, it requires a full review of how the federation is organised. A body overseeing and regulating the work of sports federations would be a way to stop abuses, and limiting the mandates of those appointed to management structures would remove the installation of clans for which sport is an illicit business. I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that structural reforms are being needed at FIFA level, both to restore the image and to increase decision-making transparency.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The world of football is getting dirtier and more corrupt. We need more transparency and control, dirty hands must not touch a ball.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.).  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Football is a unifying sport that generates social cohesion. The institutions that govern it must be ethically blameless. The recent scandals involving many of FIFA's high-level officials are discrediting the entire football world, which is unacceptable. In this resolution, we call for greater transparency in the global governance of football. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the recent revelations of corruption cases at the top of FIFA. I hope that the resolution adopted by Parliament will contribute to a serious debate on how to eradicate corruption from the world of football, the image of which, at all levels, is in danger of being tarnished by these events. A review of FIFA's statutes, structure, codes and operational policies and practices with a view to improving transparency with regard to both decision-making processes and the way in which federation officials are remunerated is to be carried out in a timely manner. fans, fans and serious insiders deserve it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely imperative that the revelations of high level corruption are brought to the public’s attention and are dealt with appropriately. Furthermore, the continuing treatment of migrant workers is the real scandal. The fact that FIFA and others are turning a blind eye to the terrible abuses of migrant construction workers is absolutely unacceptable. More than 4 000 workers will have died by the time the Qatar World Cup kicks off. The tragic cost of this corruption in FIFA is modern-day slavery. FIFA is not just corrupt, it is implicitly endorsing the Qatari Government’s abuse of migrant workers’ rights. In light of the deaths of almost 2 000 workers so far, FIFA has no option but to reopen the discussion on the location of the World Cup 2022. The EU cannot continue to look the other way. It should be defending ILO conventions above any other interest. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a resolution concerning the recent corruption allegations against the international football federation FIFA, which in my view have seriously damaged the credibility and the integrity of global football. Through this resolution Parliament called for a zero-tolerance policy on corruption in football and underlined that in-depth structural reforms within the organisation are now urgently needed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because our points on greater transparency and democracy in decision-making processes and on the protection of fundamental rights when awarding high-level sporting competitions were accepted in the report.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because there is an urgent need to tackle corruption in the international sport community. The scandals currently affecting FIFA show the need for a reassessment of the organisation and the choices made by the highest authorities in international competition. Thus, one can question the elements that prevailed in Qatar's choice as the organizer of the 2022 World Cup - despite proven acts of torture, human rights violations, and other multiple violations of international law - and it is positive that this resolution calls for countries applying to host an international competition to have an obligation to respect fundamental rights for all activities related to the event. It was clear that, in the face of the ongoing business scandals, the 2022 World Cup could only be put to a vote and Qatari leaders would have to explain their implications in covert financing cases.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Sepp Blatter should step down immediately and be replaced by an interim leader, the Qatar 2022 decision should be re-run and the World Cup should only be held in countries that are respectful of fundamental human and social rights. This resolution on FIFA underlines the utmost importance of the investigation by the Swiss and US justice systems into the decision by FIFA’s Executive Committee to award the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar, respectively. The Commission, in coordination with Member States and in cooperation with Interpol, Europol and Eurojust, must take all appropriate measures to tackle any possible indication of corruption on the part of FIFA officials on EU territory. Corruption and high-level scandals also corrode the public’s trust in the integrity of sport and our national authorities must not look away when there are human rights abuses associated to sporting events, as is the case with the widespread reports of egregious labour abuses in Qatar.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the recent revelations about corruption cases at the top of FIFA. On 27 May 2015, Swiss authorities arrested 14 FIFA executives in Zurich on charges of money laundering, racketeering, corruption and fraud for a total of more than USD 150 million. A criminal investigation has been launched into the allocation of the World Cup in Russia and Qatar. Despite the arrests, FIFA President Joseph Blatter was elected for a fifth term and then resigned a few days later due to further developments in the investigation. The EP therefore calls for Blatter's resignation to lead to a profound reform of FIFA and calls on all EU Member States to act to ensure that not only football but all sports are based on the criteria of transparency, accountability and democracy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The revelations that have emerged in recent days about FIFA's behaviour are quite disconcerting. I love sport, I practice it when I can and I follow it with passion, and I have to say that certain accusations hurt those who, like me, believe that sport is and should be the symbol and emblem of correctness. Since the facts must be established, and I am a staunch guarantor, I voted in favour of this resolution in order to leave it written, in black and white, that sport and corruption should never be associated, and that football must remain beautiful because it is clean. I hope that the accusations will prove to be unfounded or that, if not, those who have made mistakes will pay in an exemplary manner.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The integrity of sports organisations is important, as both professional and amateur sport play a key role in promoting peace, respect for human rights and solidarity worldwide, bringing benefits to health and the economy to society and being essential in bringing attention to fundamental cultural and educational values , as well as in promoting social inclusion. Unfortunately, for several years FIFA has functioned as an unimputable, opaque and manifestly corrupt organization and recent arrests confirm that fraud and corruption in FIFA are systematic. I support this resolution because I believe it is necessary for the Commission and the Member States to take action to combat any evidence of acts of corruption committed by officials of FIFA or national football federations on EU territory. On the other hand, police cooperation in Europe should be strengthened through the establishment of joint investigation teams and greater cooperation between judicial authorities. I also consider it essential that all candidate countries to host major sporting events respect, in all activities related to the organisation and holding of the event, international standards on fundamental rights.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because, in view of the ongoing investigations in the US, South Africa and Australia, a rethink and reform of the World Football Federation is needed. There must be greater transparency in the awarding of world cups and corruption must be curbed.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 First of all, I can only express my displeasure with the events involving FIFA, the arrests and the ongoing criminal investigation into how the 2008 and 2022 World Cups are to be awarded. This situation has seriously damaged the integrity of world football and sport in general, not only at professional level but also at amateur level, undermining confidence in sporting institutions. Let us not forget that these organisations are of fundamental importance in promoting educational and cultural values, inclusion, peace, solidarity, loyalty and respect for human rights at global level.  I therefore call for a reform of FIFA, through the implementation of strict ethical standards and a code of conduct for its management and the Executive Committee, in order to ensure greater democracy, transparency, legitimacy and accountability in the future. It is the task of the EU, each Member State, sports organisations and sponsors, to support good governance of sport and to cooperate in countering transnational threats to the integrity and ethics of sport, such as doping, rigged matches, violence and all forms of intolerance and discrimination.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Football is a sport upon which the livelihood of many depend, more so since its top levels have developed into a global commodity. It is not therefore surprising that its failures affect those third parties too. The FIFA scandal does not damage FIFA itself alone but has ramifications in other sectors such as the media, broadcasting, marketing and banking sectors. It also plays a social role, being based on support from sports fans, who are consumers.  Sports fans, as consumers, together with other economic players that have a direct or indirect role deserve the highest standards of integrity in this sport. The current allegations beg the question as to whether FIFA can govern itself and how long it should remain free of external regulations. Sport seems to be based on self-regulation without proper checks and balances, yet sports like football show that the commercial dynamics and markets are comparable to any other economic activity.  If we want to preserve the credibility of our sport for future generations, action is needed. Together we must reiterate our calls for greater transparency and accountability on the side of sport.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. We fully share the criticism of Fifa and welcome the legal process that is now under way. It is good that the Swedish Football Association has not only distanced itself from corruption in Fifa, but that it is working hard and long-term to prevent irregularities in football. However, it is not for the European Parliament to micromanage the organisation of associations in the Member States. This applies regardless of the size of the compound. We assume that if investigations show that Russia or Qatar have hosted bribery and other corruption, Fifa will take action and move the competitions. And certainly there may be reason to consider whether Sweden's national team should go to the World Cup in Russia and reason to criticize the working conditions at the World Cup construction in Qatar. But it is basically the individual football associations that have to decide whether or not to participate. It is not something the EU should decide on. Indeed, if Members of the European Parliament wish to form public opinion on these issues, they can do so without using the European Parliament's legislative instruments as a platform.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to combat corruption in football. It saddens me that sporting values are replaced by pure commercial interest: some of this we know in Spain, where urban scandals and non-payments to the Treasury and Social Security in football are the order of the day. However, it is important to note that under FIFA's corruption there is an even more serious reality: the exploitation of slave workers for the benefit of consumption and spectacle in a globalized world, as other multinationals do recognize their profit- There are 1,200 workers killed in Qatar during the preparation of the World Cup: that's the real scandal.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Football is the most popular sport in the world. Corruption cases relating to FIFA are sensitive not only as politicians, but also as private people and sports enthusiasts. I think it is very important to put an end to all forms of corruption that can tarnish the integrity and reputation of football. The decision adopted by the European Parliament urges FIFA's executive committee to implement structural reforms to achieve transparency and accountability within FIFA and to ensure open, balanced and democratic decision-making processes. We call on UEFA and the national football associations to step up their efforts to implement fifa's fundamental internal reforms, and in particular the recommendations of the resolution adopted today, by 2016. I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution condemns the systemic and despicable corruption exposed at FIFA and puts on record its view that these allegations are far from surprising. It also calls on sports organisations, the Member States and the EU to cooperate fully with all ongoing investigations and underlines the utmost importance of the investigation by the Swiss and US justice authorities into the decision by FIFA’s Executive Committee to award the World Cup for 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar respectively. Since I believe that football, like any other sport, should be a platform that promotes sound moral and ethical values to our youngsters who are so exposed to the world of this sport, I supported this resolution.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Corruption, money laundering and betting have unfortunately entered the sphere of the most widespread sport in the world, generating a devastating effect on the entire world of football, from the highest level of professional football to that of local amateur clubs. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the recent revelations of corruption at the top of FIFA, because the time has come to turn the page, adopting a zero-tolerance policy on corruption in sport and removing any shadow over the events of recent years.  We therefore call loudly for an unreserved commitment from Fifa to a thorough review of past and present decisions and the adoption of new reforms such as: the amendment of the statutes, codes, structure, operational policies and above all the introduction of mandate limits leading to total transparency in the future. The integrity of football is at risk and fans are waiting for a new season in which the malfeasing permanently comes out of the stadiums.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows revelations of high-level corruption within the International Football Federation (FIFA) and strongly condemns this situation within FIFA and calls on sports organisations, Member States and the European Union to cooperate fully in all ongoing and future investigations into allegations of corruption. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent corruption allegations against the International Football Federation (FIFA) have seriously undermined the credibility and integrity of world football. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we need to adopt a zero-tolerance policy for corruption in football and deep structural reforms within the FIFA organisation itself.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Football and sport in general have a significant positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young people. Sport is a large and fast-growing sector of the EU economy that contributes significantly to growth and job creation. The resignation of Joseph Blatter and the arrest of FIFA officials have created the conditions for a radical reform of FIFA's structures and practices, which are needed to improve the governance of the organisation and clean up corruption and which urgently need to be implemented. Football is by far the most popular sport in the world. It is therefore of the utmost importance to put an end to all forms of corruption that could tarnish the integrity and reputation of football.  The European Parliament urges fifa's executive committee to implement structural reforms to achieve transparency and accountability within FIFA and to ensure open, balanced and democratic decision-making processes. We call on UEFA and the national football associations to step up their efforts to implement fifa's fundamental internal reforms, and in particular the recommendations of the resolution adopted today, by 2016. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I strongly supported the joint resolution on the FIFA scandal. While I regret that it was at the initiative of the United States that the case was made public, the succession of information leaked in recent weeks concerning suspicions of large-scale corruption as well as the arrests and indictments of several officials of the association, have convinced me that it is essential to review the entire FIFA organization.  I therefore support the request for the resignation of the President of FIFA so that a reform of the organisation can be envisaged and that an interim president is appointed to ensure the continuity of FIFA. I also support the request to conduct a thorough investigation into World Cup bids in Qatar and Russia. Finally, we must ensure that European anti-money laundering regulations are effective and sufficient to combat corruption in sport.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint resolution on corruption cases in FIFA because I find it unacceptable to allow corruption at such a high level, and even more so in an international organisation of FIFA's rank.  I support what is said in the text of the resolution that, unfortunately, corruption in FIFA is profound and systematic and that is why structural reforms must be made in the organisation. Transparency is needed, and the fact that FIFA has not published the full text of the Garcia report is reprehensible. An open, balanced and democratic decision-making process must be ensured in FIFA and there must be no tolerance for corruption in sport. Measures must be taken that effectively address corruption and any indications of its existence in both FIFA and national football associations, in particular those within the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the controls on the undertaking and construction of world cup projects must be made much stricter. The living conditions of workers for these projects must also change radically. FIFA is good, instead of spending the money on meaningless anti-racist campaigns (and that money goes into some pockets), to dispose of it for the good of football.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text on what happened on May 27, 2015, when 14 FIFA executives were arrested on serious charges of money laundering, racketeering, corruption and fraud amounting to about 150 million euros. This serious event has, in fact, only once again put the light on an organisation whose lack of transparency and corruption has long been known.  The European Parliament now hopes that sports organisations and Member States will cooperate in all ongoing investigations and that the process of monitoring past corruption practices will lead to the relaxation of any managers who may be responsible. I also fully support the request to FIFA to finally make public the full text of the Garcia report on the controversial procedure for awarding the 2018 and 2022 World Cups. It was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to have spoken so harshly on a problem that encroaches on a sector which has a great influence on millions of Europeans.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The situation currently experienced within FIFA is not easy and a swift, impartial and, if necessary, with consequences is urgently required. The allocation of the 2018 and 2022 world championships should be invalidated if evidence emerges that this assignment resulted from corrupt activities and the issue of leadership should be resolved, at first, with an interim president. The investigation initiated by the Swiss and US authorities is extremely important to understand the scope of this whole case. I agree that the allocation of the 2018 and 2022 world championships will be invalidated if evidence emerges that this assignment resulted from corruption activities, as well as with the removal of all officials involved in irregularities. FIFA must adopt strict ethical standards and a code of conduct for its management staff and executive committee, which are controlled by an independent supervisory body. Police cooperation in Europe should be strengthened through the establishment of joint investigation teams and greater cooperation between judicial authorities.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it focuses on exposing corruption within FIFA.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The scenario that emerges against the background of the scandal involving FIFA is truly disturbing: corruption, criminal bieco business, sports fraud, exploitation of workers employed to build the infrastructure for the World Cup in Qatar and, not least, arrogance of power. The time has really come to put an end to this commodity that has been put in place to the detriment of millions of sportsmen and women who are passionate followers of football, that is to say the most popular sport in the world. The positive values inherent in sport, and among them in football, have nothing to do with fifa's corrupt and paramafious management. We therefore call for every initiative to be taken to ensure transparency and democracy within the governance systems of the football world, starting with FIFA. It is also necessary to clarify the alleged illegal allocations of the last world cups and, where appropriate, to invalidate the allocation of the 2018 and 2020 editions should it emerge that they are the result of corrupting activities.  On the other hand, the positive values of sport must be revived by encouraging educational projects and sporting activities based on the promotion of the integrity and ethics of both individual and collective behaviour. We need loyalty, honesty and fairness, otherwise, as a game, we don't like football anymore.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. We fully share the criticism of Fifa and welcome the legal process that is now under way. It is good that the Swedish Football Association has not only distanced itself from corruption in Fifa, but that it is working hard and long-term to prevent irregularities in football. However, it is not up to the European Parliament to micromanage the way in which the association should be governed and laws on this are designed. This applies regardless of the size of the compound. We assume that if investigations show that Russia or Qatar have hosted bribery and other corruption, Fifa will take action and move the competitions. And certainly there may be reason to consider whether Sweden's national team should go to the World Cup in Russia and reason to criticize the working conditions at the World Cup construction in Qatar. But it is basically the individual football associations that have to decide whether or not to participate. It is not something the EU should decide on. Indeed, if Members of the European Parliament wish to form public opinion on these issues, they can do so without using the European Parliament's legislative instruments as a platform.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to abstain as I could not really care less about a bag of wind when there are more important things happening. It is a distraction. I say this as a football fan.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ FIFA is shaken by a scandal unprecedented in its history. On May 27, Swiss authorities, in cooperation with the U.S. Justice Department, arrested 14 high-ranking FIFA officials and charged them with corruption and accepting bribes. The situation was not helped by FIFA chief Sepp Blatter himself, who resigned from that position just four days after the FIFA president was defended. It is very important for FIFA to go through internal reform and to repair its cherished reputation in the eyes of both the European and the world public, as football is a global phenomenon. FIFA has seriously damaged the name of world football and it is very important that all allegations of possible corruption, clientelism and money laundering are refuted, as there are also serious doubts about the awarding of the 2018 World Cup to the Russian Federation and Qatar in 2022.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Right and proper to condemn the increasingly dirty world of football following the investigations that are upsetting FIFA. It calls for greater transparency and control.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution. FIFA has been seriously damaged by the recent allegations of corruption and I question Sepp Blatter’s decision to remain as interim leader. We need a thorough examination of past events in full cooperation with law enforcement agencies, and to ensure that FIFA upholds the highest standards of governance, transparency and accountability going forward.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The existence of corruption at the highest levels of the football world – with football now being the ‘world’s game’ – is a proven fact that must be roundly condemned. This endemic corruption not only compromises the quality of play on the field but also reduces fan support for the sport and tarnishes the beauty of the game. FIFA is still structured in a way that fosters corruption: it is clear that the decision-making system must be revised. It is time to reform FIFA, creating a separate institution that functions with transparency and oversight, and also to deal with the broader problems that the World Cup creates in hosting nations, such as the increase in public debt, evictions and the militarisation of public spaces. The recent revelations are very discouraging for the millions of football fans who deserve a clean, transparent sport. But they are also an opportunity to raise the authority of international football governance to the level of the sport it represents.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the motion, since on 27 May 2015 the Swiss authorities arrested 14 FIFA officials, including the Vice-President, in Zurich. The arrests were made at the request of the U.S. Department of Justice on charges of money laundering, racketeering, fraud and bribery worth $150 million. Furthermore, given that the Swiss and US authorities have opened separate criminal investigations into how the 2018 and 2022 World Cups are awarded to Russia and Qatar, the issue also needs attention and scrutiny.  FIFA has operated for many years as an unreal, opaque and notoriously corrupt organisation; whereas recent arrests confirm that fraud and corruption within FIFA are systemic, widespread and persistent. On the basis of the above, I urge FIFA to impose strict ethical standards and codes of conduct on the management and executive committee and to be supervised by an independent supervisory body. I support the proposal that sports governance bodies reduce the risk of falling victim to corruption by committed to good governance practices and increasing transparency.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general.   Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.).

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.).  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Sport is by its nature the bearer in society of healthy values, messenger of peace and social inclusion, a tool to insert young people and educate them in fair play, respect for each other also in the race, morally intact competition.  At a time when sport, and especially football in particular – the most widespread game on a world scale – is becoming a symbol of corruption and reckless economic interests, as is unfortunately the case with FIFA these days, the profound positive social impact and its intrinsic significance are in danger of being distorted and threatened.  Europe must therefore take action to help remember the true universal values underlying sport and take every measure at its possession to ensure that these deplorable events are overcome, restoring confidence in the world of sport as soon as possible and regaining a sense of responsibility and reputation. I therefore welcome the motion for a resolution before us and i greatly appreciate the efforts already made by the EU in this regard thanks to the launch of the Erasmus+ programme, which is precisely on these objectives.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption cases in FIFA because I believe that the recent corruption investigations within FIFA, culminating in the arrest of 14 executives, clearly show how great the problem of transactional corruption in sport is. Criminal activity, which takes many forms, influences the decision-making processes relating to sporting events, indelibly tarnishes the image of sport, obfuscating its educational values of promoting peace, solidarity, the fight against racism and respect for human rights. All sports, and football in particular, have a profound social impact and cannot be tainted in any way by a corrupting and predatory culture. I therefore welcome the call for sport's governing bodies to promote reforms and measures that bring greater transparency, democracy and control of decision-making processes involving important economic and sporting interests. Self-regulation of professional sport must be based on principles of good governance, transparency and respect for the law. Finally, I believe it is necessary to strengthen cooperation and confrontation between sports authorities, public authorities and police forces at all levels, creating intervention mechanisms to prevent such incidents from occuring.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Sport thrives on fair play. That is, so to speak, the basic prerequisite for being able to call anything like sport at all. There is no excuse for the fact that the World Football Federation is now alleged to have engaged in corruption. That is why it was an important and necessary step for Joseph Blatter to announce his resignation. The ongoing investigations into senior FIFA officials make it clear that a corrupt system will never be tolerated. I therefore welcome the investigations by the United States and the Swiss Federal Prosecutor's Office, so that in the future the undisturbed fun of sport will once again be in the foreground. The allegations must be fully investigated. In addition, the awarding of the World Cup tournaments for 2018 and 2022 must now be re-examined.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption cases in FIFA because we cannot allow money laundering, racketeering, bribery and fraud to undermine our societies. Done the right way, events like the World Cup have the potential to bring people together and create jobs and growth. But done the wrong way, as is the case with FIFA, it spreads corruption along with its devastating impact on society and eats away at quality employment. One only needs to look at Qatar – whose appointment as host of the cup is incomprehensible – where migrant workers are enslaved on World Cup construction sites and are dying at a rate of one every two days, according to recent reports. We cannot be complicit in this. The EU should exert pressure on FIFA when it operates in the European market and do all in its power to make sure FIFA starts playing by the rules.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe greater transparency and accountability are needed in the governing of football. Football plays a huge role in the lives of many people, including many of my constituents, and they expect better when it comes to the operation of their sport. Hosting the World Cup is not only a political badge of honour but draws the world’s attention, and a lot of its money, to the host nation. As we have seen, the lure of the World Cup has led to a worldwide scandal of corruption in football, implicating politicians and FIFA itself. It is therefore beyond the right time for the international community to demand better standards of FIFA and the processes it uses to allocate the host countries of its premier competition.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution with a view to ending the corruption of FIFA in particular, and sporting bodies in general. FIFA has operated opaquely and corruptly for many years and the latest scandals confirm this. We therefore call for improved transparency and accountability, in particular in relation to its decision-making process and the remuneration of its management and management tables. We also believe it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the investigation being carried out by the Swiss and US authorities on the award of the 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 World Cups to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, respectively. And we used to call for the democratization of sports bodies.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Recent corruption allegations against the international football federation FIFA have seriously damaged the credibility and the integrity of global football. I therefore voted in favour of a resolution calling for a zero-tolerance policy on corruption in football, underlining that in-depth structural reforms within the organisation are now urgently needed. The resolution also welcomes Joseph Blatter’s resignation as FIFA President and calls on the federation to select an interim leader to replace him. FIFA should put in place a transparent, balanced and democratic decision-making process, including for the election of the new president, to restore its integrity.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption in FIFA. Sport is very important in many people's lives, and football, one of the most popular sports in the world, should not be linked to corruption and lead by example. We must combat opacity and corruption. The EU must strive to protect sports organisations and their members from such incidents, in order to establish certain protection mechanisms to help global sports federations function properly and to avoid such scandalous situations.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.). For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Football and sport in general have a significant positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young people. Sport is a large and fast-growing sector of the EU economy that contributes significantly to growth and job creation. The resignation of Joseph Blatter and the arrest of FIFA officials have created the conditions for a radical reform of FIFA's structures and practices, which are needed to improve the governance of the organisation and clean up corruption and which urgently need to be implemented. Football is by far the most popular sport in the world. It is therefore of the utmost importance to put an end to all forms of corruption that could tarnish the integrity and reputation of football.  The European Parliament urges fifa's executive committee to implement structural reforms to achieve transparency and accountability within FIFA and to ensure open, balanced and democratic decision-making processes. We call on UEFA and the national football associations to step up their efforts to implement fifa's fundamental internal reforms, and in particular the recommendations of the resolution adopted today, by 2016. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Football, and sport in general, has a significant positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young people. Sport is a large and fast-growing sector of the EU economy that contributes significantly to growth and job creation. The resignation of Joseph Blatter and the arrest of FIFA officials have created the conditions for a radical reform of FIFA's structures and practices, which are needed to improve the governance of the organisation and clean up corruption and which urgently need to be implemented. Football is by far the most popular sport in the world. It is therefore of the utmost importance that we put an end to all forms of corruption that poison this sport and damage its reputation.  The European Parliament urges fifa's executive committee to make the necessary structural reforms to achieve transparency and accountability within FIFA and to ensure open, balanced and democratic decision-making processes. We call on UEFA and the national football associations to step up their efforts to implement fifa's fundamental internal reforms, and in particular the recommendations of the resolution adopted today, by 2016. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution with a view to ending the corruption of FIFA in particular, and sporting bodies in general. FIFA has operated opaquely and corruptly for many years and the latest scandals confirm this. We therefore call for improved transparency and accountability, in particular in relation to its decision-making process and the remuneration of its management and management tables. We also believe it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the investigation being carried out by the Swiss and US authorities on the award of the 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 World Cups to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, respectively. And we used to call for the democratization of sports bodies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on recent revelations of high-level corruption cases in FIFA, due to the social impact that sports, especially football as the world's most popular sport, have on the everyday life of citizens of all continents.  Therefore, it is necessary to deprive sport of all connection with corruption and malfeasance in order to highlight its positive effects, namely solidarity, respect for human rights, but also health and economic benefits. In this context, it is necessary to raise the level of transparency, democratic treatment, accountability, ethical standards, but also the rules of conduct of the Fifa Steering and Executive Board, as well as other sports bodies.  More co-operation between countries, stakeholders, sports organisations, agencies, public institutions and others is also needed, given the international nature of corruption in sport. In the present case, I consider that further investigations are needed to demonstrate with precision what malfeasance has been made and how the processes of awarding hosting world championships have actually flowed.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The incredible gabegie that is FIFA requires that we stop at its heavy problems that have political significance. This resolution on the recent revelations of corruption within FIFA is generally good. The unacceptable and inhumane working conditions of migrants and workers in Qatar are strongly denounced. The resolution, which calls for reform of the organisation, is not too intrusive and, apart from a few comments on intolerance and discrimination in the sports world, this resolution is acceptable. Corruption, which is a hindrance to development and reduces trust between the various partners, must be tackled and I welcome the Fact That the Union is taking the problem into account. Because the deplorable working conditions in Qatar have been condemned, because the resolution is not too intrusive in the reform of the FIFA organization, I have decided to vote for this resolution.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. 2012 FIFA has seriously damaged the integrity of world football and its reform is inevitable. It is extremely important to properly investigate the circumstances in which the World Cup was allocated to Russia and Qatar. If there has been corruption, a new selection procedure must be carried out as soon as possible. I also consider it essential to call on the Commission to monitor European anti-money laundering legislation and to ensure that the laws work sufficiently to combat corruption in sport.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on corruption within FIFA. While I strongly condemn the cases of corruption in football and all the abuses that damage the image of sport in general, I regret the inappropriate tone and the fact that the resolution is dispersed on certain issues unrelated to its purpose.  While it is clear that FIFA needs to renew its credibility by carrying out the necessary urgent reforms and that diligent investigations are needed to clarify the conditions for awarding World Cups to Qatar and Russia, the mix of genders prevailing in the resolution has only helped to blur the message, which is why I have decided to abstain on the final vote.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from my voice. I am generally in favour of the text, but unfortunately I cannot agree with it because of the excessive political correctness.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the resolution. With it Parliament asks for a strong commitment from FIFA, as well as other sports organisations, to fight corruption and implement a code of conduct and a zero-tolerance policy on corruption in sport.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Football Federation (FIFA) has faced many complications since its inception in 1904. Although the biggest problem seemed to be for the organization of world war, it turns out that FIFA is not able to cope with itself in the first place. As football became an increasingly profitable business, the more corruption in the organization ramped up, eventually crippling it. The now former FIFA president, Sepp Blatter, led the organization in what appeared to be one of the most successful in history on the surface, but there was disintegration within. Although FIFA is officially a non-profit organization, other nonprofits might be envious. Unfortunately, the big business again absorbed something that was supposed to be clean and to serve as a joy. At the moment, the integrity of world football is seriously damaged. FIFA's practices to date have had a devastating impact on the entire football pyramid, from the highest levels of professional football to amateur clubs at the lowest level, and it is time for redress. For all the said, I have decided to abstain from voting on the joint motion for a resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption cases in FIFA. I believe that the change in the way the organisation operates should be based primarily on the organisation itself, with FIFA focusing on what the fans say and not the supranational institutions.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Bribery, racketeering, money laundering and fraud are some of the charges against FIFA officials who have been arrested last week in Zurich. The corruption charges brought by the US Department of Justice are grave, and the misconduct of the 14 people arrested has been seriously undermining all the educational and cultural values that sport should inspire people with. Their cases involve more than USD 150 million-worth of bribes, and the arrests come as a result of long unaccountable operation and systematic fraud practices. It has to be noted that, since sports make an important contribution to growth and jobs, the EU economy suffers major loses from any malpractice in the sector. The EU has an obligation to act in the anticorruption field, and there is a cross border dimension of these crimes that should not be disregarded. Safeguarding the integrity of sport and fighting corruption should remain at the core of the EU activities, and for this reason I am in favour of the DMR on these cases.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Following recent reports of corruption in the upper echelons of the International Football Federation (FIFA), the European Parliament has decided to express its opinion through a motion for a resolution. The investigation, which started from the United States, demonstrated the involvement of fifa's secretary general, and presumably the Presidency, in possible corruption cases in the allocation of world cup venues to South Africa, Russia and Qatar, for 2010, 2018 and 2022 respectively. I voted in favour because I believe that corruption is a cowardly act, to be condemned in all sectors, both public and private, and even more so in cases of sporting events of such a high standard. Sport and its values must be free from purely economic logic.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. This text recalls that countries applying for an international competition have an obligation to respect a number of fundamental rights and that FIFA is under the same obligation. Controversy arose in particular following accusations concerning working conditions on Qatari construction sites with the questioning of respect for workers, especially immigrants (passport confiscated), with suspicion of forced labour. In addition, some of them died in the workplace. This text therefore condemns any form of corruption within FIFA following the latest revelations and commits it to reform.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to combat corruption in football. It saddens me that sporting values are replaced by pure commercial interest: some of this we know in Spain, where urban scandals and non-payments to the Treasury and Social Security in football are the order of the day. However, it is important to note that under FIFA's corruption there is an even more serious reality: the exploitation of slave workers for the benefit of consumption and spectacle in a global world, as other multinationals do recognize their profit- There are 1,200 workers killed in Qatar during the preparation of the World Cup: that's the real scandal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Football and sport generally have a strong positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young generations. Sports organizations, professional and amateur at all levels must be transparents. Their key role is to promote peace, respect for human rights and solidarity in the world. The grave allegations of corruption at the umbrella football organisation FIFA are very worrying. Transparency, accountability and democracy, i.e. good governance in sport organisations, are a fundamental precondition for such self-regulatory bodies to successfully deal with preventing and combating systemic fraud and corruption in sport, and this is exactly what has been absent in this case. I support the adopted resolution and call on sports organisations, Member States and the EU to cooperate fully in the investigations into alleged corruption cases. It is imperative that FIFA sets and implements strict ethical norms and code of conduct on its Management board and Executive Board, and that they are supervised by an independent supervisory authority.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 When sport turns into a huge corrupt scheme, it is no longer a sport. I voted in favour because all these cases must be condemned in the FIF.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Sport is a sector of the EU economy that makes a significant contribution to growth and increased employment. Any corruption, match-buying and other criminal activity, even linked to criminal organisations operating at international level, harms the economic and financial interests of the European Union, while significantly reducing the credibility and image of sport in the consciousness of the EU people. All this naturally raises doubts about the ways, resources and legality of financing sport. The Commission and the Member States must therefore increase the investigative and control function in the financing of sport and take the necessary measures to remedy this undesirable situation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I supported the joint motion for a resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption cases at FIFA because it is substantiated by presenting, with compelling evidence, the corruption that prevailed within FIFA.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution. Although some of the amendments that were close to our hearts have not passed, the end result is acceptable: the resolution condemns corruption in sport as a whole, and within FIFA in particular, and calls for reform of the organisation. We also appreciate that the final text makes it clear that candidates for an international competition must respect fundamental rights for all activities related to the sporting event in question. We can only hope that this will be respected in the future.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Beyond the purely healthy side, sport contributes to social integration and integration, promotes cultural exchanges and creates jobs within the European Union. The FIFA affair is a serious case of corruption and crime in this discipline which risks tarnishing the image of the sport as a whole. I believe it is necessary to stop such cases, to intensify the reform process and to improve transparency with regard to both decision-making processes and the way in which federation officials are remunerated. For these reasons, I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report as it calls for a pro-active response from the EU and UEFA to tackle corruption in an organisation well known across the EU and the world – an organisation that should be promoting human rights and setting an example to the young people who are so invested in football.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Transparency, accountability and democracy in sports organisations are the three principles that need to be adhered to in order to combat sports corruption effectively. Recent events have shown that the phenomenon of corruption can undermine confidence in sporting institutions, threatening the credibility of sport in general. For these reasons, I have chosen to support this resolution, through which the European Parliament expresses total opposition to any form of corruption linked to the world of sport.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 You need to fight corruption wherever it is. In recent days we have been revealed to us how FIFA and sports bodies have acted corruptly over the years. Greater transparency and accountability is essential, in particular as to the decision-making process and the remuneration of the management and management frameworks of these bodies. Serious investigation is needed into the processes of world cup allocation, both in the past, such as those in France or South Africa, or in others, such as those of Russia or Qatar, where all allegations of human rights violations cannot be ignored, including the use of slave labour for the construction of infrastructure.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The situation in FIFA following the latest allegations of corruption that we have known is really worrying. Irreparable damage to the credibility and integrity of the football world is occurring. I fully support the resolution we have adopted in the European Parliament to condemn this situation and call for zero tolerance for corruption in football. We also believe it is essential to clarify everything necessary about the 2018 and 2022 World Cup awards to review these decisions if irregularities are found.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution regarding the recent high-level corruption cases in FIFA manages to capture the importance of sports in society by underlining its key role in promoting peace, solidarity and social inclusion. Moreover it takes into account its significance as a large and fast-growing sector of the EU economy which makes an important contribution to growth and jobs. The allegations of corruption in FIFA bring about devastating consequences for the reputation of the sport and profoundly stigmatise it. Considering the influence of football in society, these could lead to a negative impact on the daily lives of millions of people. To combat this, the resolution urges FIFA’s Executive Committee to implement structural reforms in order to create transparency and accountability. For example, it proposes the implementation of strict ethical standards and a code of conduct for its management and Executive Committee, as well as an independent monitoring body. Along with this, the introduction of term limits for members of FIFA’s Executive Committee is considered essential to restore its credibility. Furthermore, it calls on the Member States to enhance European law enforcement cooperation through joint investigation teams and cooperation between prosecution authorities. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Although I condemn all forms of corruption, I abstained from voting on the motion on new revelations of corruption cases at the highest level of FIFA. In my view, it does not fall within the competence of the EU, as FIFA is an independent and international organisation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. FIFA is at the heart of a corruption scandal. Fourteen people (including the Vice-President) have been arrested and serious suspicions are raised about the way the 1998, 2010, 2018 or 2022 World Cups were awarded. The resolution condemns corruption. It also calls for reform of FIFA and for host countries to respect human rights and press freedom. I regret that the plight of the migrant workers employed to build the stadiums in Qatar is not explicitly mentioned. Nevertheless, I am voting for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This resolution on the recent revelations of corruption within FIFA is generally good.  Indeed, it recalls the principle of respect for fundamental rights, especially when applying to host an international competition. The inhumane working conditions of workers in Qatar are denounced. Corruption, which is a hindrance to development and reduces trust between the various partners, is bound to be combated. This resolution is not too intrusive. So I voted for this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I agree that it is imperative that sports organisations, Member States and the EU cooperate fully with all ongoing and future investigations into the alleged corrupt practices within FIFA. It is also crucial that sports governing bodies commit to good governance practices and increasing transparency in order to reduce the risk of falling victim to corruption and money laundering.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The financial abuses at FIFA have seriously damaged the integrity of the sport. If FIFA is to regain its credibility, it must without delay appoint an interim president who will quickly organise new elections, radically reform its structures and pursue a financial policy based on absolute transparency and strict ethical codes. It is also recommended that FIFA be fully cleared in all files and tenders that are the subject of possible fraud or corruption. In order to restore the integrity of sport, which is based on universal values such as fair play, peace and solidarity between peoples, it is highly recommended that FIFA and other sports organisations in the future use respect for human rights as a criterion in the allocation of major international sporting events.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ the recent FIFA corruption scandal has far-reaching implications not only for international football, but also for the policies of states linked to the organisation of international football events. Criminal prosecutions have been launched against 14 high-ranking officials in the organisation with regard to the allocation of organisational law to Russia and Qatar, where there is a threat of human rights abuses, contrary to the peaceful ideology of football. As it turns out, corruption is broad-based and systematic and does not only concern isolated cases. As football should converg, fifa's values as an umbrella international football organisation need to be reconsidered. It is unacceptable for corruption to conduct selection procedures in the case of the selection of the promoter, because this devalues a fair process. I therefore support the prosecution of corruption at international level and agree that EU Member States should cooperate with each other in detecting corruption in football, as competitions must be transparent, democratic and the possibility of being hold accountable for corruption offences. FIFA is an international organisation without a supervisory board with a need for reform, as its activities have an impact on the general public and on the reputation of countries. We cannot allow countries to improve their reputations for money, but for their actions.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 All seven parliamentary groups submitted draft resolutions, all condemned the corrupt practices that came to light at the FIFA, expressed concern about fifa's loss of credibility and called for steps to restore this credibility as soon as possible. The draft resolution put to the vote was a joint proposal drawn up on the basis of these seven motions tabled, which therefore enjoyed the support of all the political forces represented in the EP. The draft rightly states that football is, on the one hand, the most popular sport in the world, which must be protected from being overshadowed by what has happened at THE FIFA, but on the other hand it is an economic sector that has moved huge sums of money, so that corrupt practices can cause direct and large-scale financial damage.
