It advocates not only the settlement of the case that has come to light and the deduction of cons, but also the long-term need to prevent a repeat of a case like this by creating a public, transparent and democratic operation. I fully agreed with the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report attempts to condemn the excesses of football business by rebounding on the FIFA bribery case. These institutionalized practices must certainly be condemned in an organization that cares less about sport than about money and call for its reform in depth.  It is also worth noting the highlighting of forced labour on the construction sites of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, regularly denounced by NGOs, without any diplomatic initiative to stop this scandal. The report must therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. FIFA has been suspected of several economic and financial irregularities related to the designation of the countries that organize the football world championships. This mistrust has existed for a number of years and has recently increased due to the allocation of the World Cup to Russia (2018) and Qatar (2022). I am voting in favour of this resolution which advocates greater transparency in the leadership of world football, the elimination of any suspicion of corruption and the adoption of clearer processes with regard to decision-making. I also understand how positive there is a new leadership in world football, with new players who credibility the sport on an international scale.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Parliament deplores the recent allegations of corruption within FIFA, calls for zero tolerance against corruption in football and a reform of the FIFA organisation, and welcomes the resignation of Sepp Blatter. However, this resignation will not be enough. It is therefore proposed to cancel the awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, if the alleged corruption is proven to be true.  The organisation of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar is particularly problematic. For years, for many years, there have been serious suspicions about the conditions for awarding competition to this gas emirate with no sporting tradition. Apart from that, it is particularly shocking that such significant competition has been attributed to a dictatorial country with morally reprehensible practices, such as the persecution of homosexuals sentenced to prison or whipping, the deaths of thousands of Nepalese and Indian workers on construction sites, the virtual absence of rights for women, or the financing of jihadist terrorism. In addition, this country dares to resort to intimidation by prosecuting all those who want to break the omerta, including parliamentarians.  Refusing this submission to this Wahhabi dictatorship, I decided to vote for this resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on recent cases of corruption within FIFA. The resolution follows the arrest of fourteen FIFA officials at the request of the United States Justice Department. It calls on all sport's governing bodies to work for good governance practices and increase transparency to reduce the risk of corruption. It also calls for better respect for gender balance when appointing members to the boards of directors and executive committees of all organizations. It reminds us that sport, including football, is not a prerogative reserved for men.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Suspicions of poor governance and lack of transparency had already fallen on FIFA in the past. The recent arrests raise fears that these are constant systemic conditions within international football, and not isolated incidents. This resolution was therefore essential precisely in order to restore the credibility of a governing body of world football which is called upon to implement immediately strict ethical rules and a code of conduct for its management. My vote on the resolution on recent corruption cases at the top of FIFA could only be favourable. Unlawful behaviour damages the integrity of world football and results in abuses in football practice.  We therefore need a zero-tolerance policy towards these illegal and corrosive activities in the world of sport and a reform that establishes self-regulation procedures and introduces effective mechanisms for detection, investigation and sanction: a reform that provides for the amendment of FIFA's statutes, structure, codes and operating practices. Promoting and spreading sporting values among young people is essential, even more so on the part of those involved in the organisation of world football, who must show responsibility when taking on an "educational" function.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution following the revelations of corruption at the highest level of the International Football Federation (FIFA). In response to the arrest of several FIFA officials and the opening of a judicial investigation into the awarding of the 2018 World Cup, Parliament strongly condemned corruption within FIFA.  The resolution calls on sports institutions, Member States and the European Union to cooperate fully in all investigations into allegations of corruption. The European Parliament, with this text, emphasizes the need to take measures that promote ethics and prevent corruption in the sports world.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 After the recent scandals involving some senior FIFA officials and given the transnational nature of corruption in sport, with this resolution, we intend to stress the need for more effective cooperation between all stakeholders. The new EU sports programme, under Erasmus + , is heading in the right direction: it supports new educational projects, of a transnational nature, which address cross-border threats to the integrity of sport, such as doping, match fixing and violence, together with all forms of intolerance and discrimination, and aims to promote and support good governance in the sector.  Corruption often has implications, not just financial implications, that go beyond the EU's borders, which is why it is one of the priorities of the European Commission's action in the Stockholm Programme. Today, we call on the FIFA Executive Committee to implement the structural reforms necessary to ensure greater transparency in decision-making processes and stricter ethical and conduct standards, which is essential for restoring international credibility in the world's most beloved and practiced sport. Finally, we call on Interpol, Europol and Eurojust to undertake their own investigations to investigate possible cases of corruption by FIFA officials on EU territory.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Football, thanks to its popularity and widespread diffusion, has a great social impact and beyond. It represents a great instrument of integration and is a formidable glue, able to unite completely different populations. It is therefore our task to contribute to the defence of this sport and we owe it above all to the young and very young, who with enthusiasm and passion, and often with sacrifices, dedicate their lives to this game. Therefore, defending the honesty of many against the rot of corruption is our moral duty. For these reasons, I have chosen to support this resolution with a vote in favour.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support measures to reduce the high level of corruption at FIFA. I believe that football, one of the most popular sports in the EU, must be governed by pre-laid rules, in the spirit of 'fair play'. I also consider it important to keep the sport transparent in order to maintain its popularity. In order to achieve this goal, I consider sincere, transparent cooperation between the EU, the Member States and FIFA to be unmissable. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The formation of FIFA took place on 21 May 1904 (111 years ago) to oversee international competition. Headquartered in Zürich, its membership now comprises 209 national associations. FIFA is today responsible for both the organisation and the promotion of a number of tournaments, which generate revenue from sponsorship. In 2013 FIFA had revenues of over USD 1.3 billion, for a net profit of 72 million, and had cash reserves of over USD 1.4 billion. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution that opposes the corruption scandal among FIFA’s high-level officials and proposes solutions to avoid such situations in the future through more transparency, self-regulation and activity reports.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution on the recent revelations on corruption cases within FIFA, because it expresses the opinion of a very large number of citizens outraged by the systemic scale of corruption in FIFA. There has been talk for a very long time, and investigative journalists have often pointed to suspicions of serious corruption within this organisation, and it is to be appreciated that an international and thorough investigation has been launched. It is outrageous that this organisation, which promotes fairness and fairplay through the sport it represents, is in fact plagued by systemic corruption that calls into question many, if not all, decisions made during this time. Unfortunately, this is the result when we talk about enormous amounts of money managed by closed, non-transparent organisations and without independent and permanent control. All those who have committed illegalities must pay, and this organisation must be redone on a democratic and transparent basis so that these acts do not happen again.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution responding to current developments in the international football association FIFA. It is not about interfering politics in sport, but about declaring disapproval of serious suspicions of tolerating or covering up corrupt or at least ethically dubious practices in world football. The tolerance of this conduct gives the impression that such behaviour is acceptable, and the question of where its limits lie is then appropriate. The world's most developed countries, including the EU, should substantially reduce tolerance for such behaviour wherever it affects them and their citizens.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the draft on the FIFA corruption scandal. Money laundering, conspiracy, corruption and fraud must not be part of sport. Over the decades, a systematic and profound scheme has been introduced to unjustly enrich senior FIFA officials. FIFA aims at global football regulation and promotion. The rules of the game must be fair and ethical to all and always be based on the principle of fair play. All sports organisations should strongly condemn FIFA's actions here and show zero tolerance. There needs to be major structural changes in the FIFA, decision-making processes need to be more transparent in the future and penalties for infringements more effective.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – Corruption and other illegal acts in sport must be prevented by any kind of corruption and other illegal acts. The FIFA scandal has negatively affected not only football, but the entire world of sport. Broad structural reform and a review of fifa's code of ethics are therefore necessary in order to enhance and restore the organisation's integrity, democracy and transparency. FIFA must thoroughly review past and current decisions and ensure full transparency in the future. Good governance of sports organisations is essential to promote democratic principles in our society. It must be based on the principle of maximum respect for democracy, transparency, ethics, financially fair play, legitimacy and human rights. There is a need to establish an effective regulatory framework to strengthen the fight against organised crime and cooperation between police and judicial authorities in the fight against corruption. It is necessary to investigate all possible allegations of corrupt practices committed by FIFA officials on EU territory.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to vote in favour of the report proposed by my COLLEAGUES in the EPP, because I fully share the view that transnational corruption in general needs to be combated, particularly in the field of sport, which plays a key role in promoting peace, solidarity and fundamental rights. , as well as representing a large and growing sector of the European economy.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ The lack of rule of law inevitably leads to corruption and the main reason lies in the lack of values, allowing self-interest to override the purpose for common good. The highest problem of corruption and the ethical problem with which we are confronted is that the cost is usually shared by everybody. In the case of the FIFA scandal, I encourage European national football associations to step up their own efforts to push for the implementation of fundamental reform measures within FIFA.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The general public is shocked by the information presented by the US Attorney's Office, in cooperation with the Swiss judiciary, about suspected embezzlement and money laundering at the highest levels of governance in FIFA. The accusations that have been made and relate in large part to commercial rights for all major football tournaments organised over the past two decades, as well as suspected embezzlement and money laundering during the selection of host countries in the 2018 and 2022 world championships, and an estimate that fifa leaders have so far extracted around $110 million into their accounts, a third of all legitimate costs required to organize these tournaments , they're really shocking. Football belongs not to the few people at its helm, but to the millions of people around the world who love this sport. Corruption erodes citizens' trust in democracy and public institutions, undermines the market, pulls millions of euros out of taxpayers' pockets, and in this case serves to launder unfairly obtained money.  Corruption is estimated to cost the EU around €120 billion annually, the amount of the EU's annual budget. I support the commitment to a greater commitment of the European Union to tackling corruption as well as to the FIFA investigation, as I think it is time for changes and transparency in football.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. A resignation at the FIFA summit will not be enough. It is a system of widespread corruption that is uncovered, something that lovers of sport and the common good cannot tolerate. For years, there have been serious suspicions about the motivations that led FIFA to award the World Cup to Qatar, a gas emirate with no sporting tradition.  I ask that everything be put back on the table by 2022 and that the World Cup be awarded to another country. It is unworthy to condone the practices of the Islamist dictatorship of Qatar: financing terrorism, no rights for women, persecution of homosexuals sentenced to prison and whip, death of thousands of Nepalese and Indian workers on construction sites, etc. This tyranny seeks to intimidate our democracies by prosecuting those who criticise journalists and human rights activists tomorrow tomorrow! She attacks when she fails to corrupt.  The proposed text takes these criticisms into account, without going as far as it would be desirable. Nevertheless, it is a first step in reassessing our relationship with this liberticidal theocracy. That's why I'm voting for.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Football, considered the most popular sport in the world, must not be tainted by corruption and must be protected from recent developments around FIFA, not condemned for it. It should be noted that both football and sport in general have a strong positive social impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens, especially young people, and that recent events in FIFA have strongly damaged the reputation of football as a whole.  I think it is important that all sport governing bodies opt for good governance practices and greater transparency to reduce the risk of corruption and money laundering. Consequently, I supported the resolution on the recent discovery of high-level corruption cases in FIFA, as I agree with the fact that it is essential that sports organisations, Member States and the EU cooperate fully in all ongoing and future investigations into alleged corruption cases at FIFA.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the current affair in the fifa world federation bears the symptoms of the disease, which is corruption in some international organizations. I therefore welcome the resignation of FIFA President Blatter, although such a move should have come a long time ago when the first doubts about the purity of FIFA's management's decision-making emerged. I am glad that the European football federations, including the Czech one, did not support Blatter's latest actions and that, even if they were defeated, they ultimately emerge from the whole situation as moral winners. I therefore believe that the future leadership of FIFA will cleanse world football of corruption allegations and will also make better and more transparent decisions about the venues of world football tournaments. I consider the resolution to be balanced and therefore has my support.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The integrity of sports organisations is of vital importance to the EU and its citizens because of the key role that professional and amateur sport plays in fostering peace, respect for human rights and social values. In parallel, sport provides economic and public health benefits, with the added advantage of social inclusion and the educational and cultural values increase, which facilitates through its peculiar aggregating character. To our dismay, the latest revelations of fifa's highest level of corruption cases weaken the confidence of citizens and fans in sports institutions and threaten the integrity of sport as a whole.  Considering that FIFA has operated for many years as a notoriously opaque, corrupt and on the sidelines of any scrutiny and, considering that recent arrests attest to the systematity, generality and constancy of cases of fraud and corruption in FIFA, the European Parliament registers in this position of the rapporteur, which I support, the indignation of FIFA practices and the support given to the campaign for the establishment of a FIFA Reform Commission , non-governmental, independent and supervised by an international authority.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. FIFA, 4 letters that rhyme today with corruption. The clusters of clues had been around for a long time, long before the 2018 World Cups were awarded to Russia and 2022 to Qatar. It took U.S. investigations to uncover the FIFA corruption scandal. As a signatory to the joint resolution, I am obviously outraged by these most egregious breaches of sports ethics from an institution that should lead by example. It is also an insult to the 280 million players worldwide and the billions of fans. Transparency and cooperation at all levels must now be the rule as outlined in paragraph 2 of the resolution which "requires sports organisations, Member States and the European Union to cooperate in all ongoing and future investigations into allegations of corruption within FIFA". Clearly, the Heads of State and Government and the European Union should be more involved in the organisation of sports law, because of the universal values conveyed. This also applies to the Commission's monitoring of compliance with competition rules by all sports organisations.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which strongly condemns the corruption revealed within FIFA.  We ask, if the investigation warrants, that those responsible for this case be excluded and that decisions related to corruption or criminal activities within FIFA be reviewed.   We welcome the resignation of Joseph Blatter as PRESIDENT of FIFA. FIFA must immediately and openly elect a provisional president, who will have to carry out structural reforms towards greater transparency, accountability and democracy. Strict ethical standards and a code of conduct must be adopted, all controlled by an independent oversight body. The time for change has come. Finally, it is essential, in the long term, that all stakeholders learn to react and cooperate with each other in order to effectively fight corruption within FIFA and any other national football association in the European Union.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament calls for a strong commitment from the International Associated Football Federation (FIFA) as well as other sports organisations to combat corruption and to implement a code of conduct and a zero-tolerance policy against corruption in sport. Without transparency and without good governance on the part of sports organisations we are violating the fundamental values and principles of sport.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.). For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I co-signed this resolution, which welcomes the resignation of Joseph Blatter as President of FIFA and calls on the federation to appoint a replacement to act as interim president. The text of the resolution also stresses that officials involved in financial scandals must be removed from office, and that decisions related to corruption or criminal activities should be overturned. The resolution also welcomes the statement by the chairman of FIFA's audit and compliance committee that the awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups could be cancelled if it is proven that these powers are solely the result of corruption. Corruption within FIFA has long been endemic, systemic and deeply entrenched.  The federation must initiate reforms, which must cover FIFA's statutes, structure, codes and operational policies and practices, and provide for the introduction of a limit on the number of mandates and independent monitoring of the members of its executive committee. The resolution also calls on FIFA to adopt strict ethical standards and a code of conduct for its management and executive committee, whose compliance will be monitored by an independent oversight body.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. This Resolution of the European Parliament came in the wake of recent revelations of high-level corruption cases at FIFA following the arrest of 14 officials from fifa, including its Vice-President, on 27 May by the Swiss authorities in Zurich. The corruption that rages within FIFA, which not only undermines the credibility of the sport of competition, but also the integrity of world football, is fully condemned, producing a devastating impact from the ranks of professional football, at the top of the pyramid, to amateur clubs at the base of it. In this sense, it is essential to implement structural reforms, capable of ensuring the transparency, rigour and sense of responsibility that a Federation of this nature must have, which must be guided by strict ethical standards and zero tolerance in terms of corruption, favoring or convenient omissions. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it absolutely essential that the European institutions and the Member States take all measures in their power to combat any evidence of acts of corruption committed in this case, but also in sport in general.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution tabled by the political groups of the European Parliament on 'recent revelations about corruption cases at the top of FIFA'. In view of the recent scandals involving the top management of the International Football Federation, leading to the arrest of fourteen FIFA executives and the resignation of President Blatter, the European Parliament has urgently called on FIFA to implement structural reforms in order to ensure greater transparency and more democratic decision-making. The objective is clear: to eliminate all forms of corruption from football, the most famous sport in the world, at this time strongly threatened in its integrity and credibility. The resolution I voted on also calls for a light to be shed on corruption cases relating also to the allocation of the World Cup, including the 2018 one that is due to take place in Russia.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution with a view to ending the corruption of FIFA in particular, and sporting bodies in general. FIFA has operated opaquely and corruptly for many years and the latest scandals confirm this. We therefore call for improved transparency and accountability, in particular in relation to its decision-making process and the remuneration of its management and management tables. We also believe it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the investigation being carried out by the Swiss and US authorities on the award of the 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 World Cups to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, respectively. And we used to call for the democratization of sports bodies.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ FIFA has operated for many years as an unaccountable, opaque and notoriously corrupt organisation. The recent arrests confirm that the fraud and corruption in FIFA are systemic, widespread and persistent rather than involving isolated cases of misconduct, as claimed by former FIFA President Joseph Blatter.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution. Scandals like FIFA are opening our eyes. Therefore, we should not only talk about the representatives of international organisations, but also about the system for the functioning of influential institutions that are virtually unanswered to anyone. Let us not be afraid to ventilation them and build them on transparent foundations. So that they serve society, not personal interests.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ at the EP in 2013, we warned of an increase in corruption in sport. During this period, we talked about manipulating football matches, buying referees and influencing results through bookmakers. In recent days, scandal has been rolling over the International Football Federation and new and new corruption affaires are coming to light. Football is a game that many people, whether amateur or professional, are dedicated to. For youth, many top athletes – footballers are examples, they want to follow them and they are a role model for them. That is also why FIFA's problems need to be addressed as soon as possible by launching reforms at all levels of FIFA's organisational structure. But I ask myself, is this just a football problem? Where fair play has been lost, and whether it is even possible to return to the original values of a sport that should bring people together all over the world. Let us not allow sport to become a controlled process by a group of speculators, manipulators and corrupters.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The recent revelation of high-level corruption at Fifa is certainly doing what is unacceptable and shameful to such an organisation. I believe that the integrity of sport must be safeguarded, as both amateur and professional sport promote peace keeping, respect for human rights and solidarity. Sport also represents health and economic benefits for the family in general. FIFA has operated as an unfair and corrupt organisation for a year, according to proven facts. Recent arrests, however, are evidence that these fraud activities have been systematic and very diversified. Good government in sporting organisations requires transparency, democracy and accountability. It is necessary to protect players from possible blackmail and intimidation, which are part of serious criminal activity. In addition, sponsorship requires clear criteria for negotiating and distributing funds. A coordinated approach to combating organised crime is needed. The involvement of major stakeholders such as sports organisations, the police and state judicial authorities is important in this regard. Educational programmes that raise awareness of good sporting values should be promoted. Such programs are especially necessary for young people and later for amateurs and professionals. Radical structural change is needed within Fifa itself, especially after the resignation of former president Sepp Blatter. On all the grounds previously written, I voted in favour of the resolution in the European Parliament.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Sport should teach people the principles of fair play. If its representatives resort to corruption, this is indicative of a major moral but also an institutional failure. The European Union cannot interfere in FIFA's internal decisions. However, it can create an environment in which everyone prefers to think twice about whether to give or take a bribe.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ It has been deeply disconcerting to witness the FIFA corruption scandal unfold. Integrity is a vital component of sport, strongly linked to the values of solidarity, the promotion of peace and social inclusion that football can engender. This is why we must restore trust in sporting institutions and fight against all forms of corruption. Therefore I voted in favour of Parliamentʼs resolution calling for a greater collaboration between all stakeholders – including public authorities, sports associations, athletes and supporters – to urgently and thoroughly address the issue of corruption. I particularly welcome the emphasis the resolution places on the need to promote education and strengthen preventative actions. I strongly agree that FIFA must implement structural reforms in order to bring about transparency and accountability.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ We are witnessing recent shocking revelations and allegations of criminal activity in FIFA, one of the world's largest and most famous sports organizations. FIFA was founded more than 100 years ago (1904) and has over 200 member football federations (208), which is more than the United Nations has a member. The existence of crime in such an organisation is a devastating piece of concern.  The charges target senior FIFA officials. Accusations of millions in bribes allegedly given marketing and media rights, allegations of blackmail, fraud and money laundering for nearly two decades are a disastrous fact. When we take into account that such actions affect millions of people and young people around the world who play sport, the European Union, which is based on the foundations and values of transparent business, must clearly condemn this treatment and I support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing \ u2012 I welcome the decision of FIFA officials to resign from their positions. At the same time, however, I stress the need for autonomy for private sports companies. In view of this, too, I believe that the European Parliament should not deal with such topics, which is why I abstained in this case.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European People's Party resolution on recent revelations of high-level corruption at Fifa. As the European Parliament resolution of 2012 on the European dimension in sport already emphasises, sport contributes to the achievement of the Union's strategic objectives, emphasises fundamental pedagogical and cultural values and is a driving force for integration, as it is aimed at all citizens, regardless of their gender, ethnicity, religion, age, ethnicity, social situation or sexual orientation. Sports organisations play an important role in this regard, where there must be no doubt as to their integrity. I therefore join the calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up and prioritise good governance in the context of the EU Work Plan for Sport and to ensure that national associations are fully involved in actions aimed at better governance at European and international level.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's Resolution on recent revelations of high-level corruption cases by FIFA. I believe that football, or sport in general, which is ultimately a very positive phenomenon of the present, as it contributes to the promotion of peace, respect for human rights, solidarity, the development of less developed societies, etc., must not be managed by an organisation operating on a corrupt basis. Although I respect the principle of self-governance, it is clear that such widespread and systematic corruption is no longer just a 'private' problem for a self-governing organisation, but a problem that needs to be addressed in the general interest. This solution is not only the resignation of the current leadership, but above all the establishment of a completely different system of functioning and governance of FIFA.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The ACPL and the Group of the European United Left support all efforts to combat corruption at every level and in every area. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of the report as a positive step towards combating corruption in football. However, we cannot ignore the fact that the process is taking place in cooperation with the authorities of the United States to which different laws apply. There are therefore legitimate concerns about how to cooperate. The report also refers to the Stockholm Programme with which we disagree, as it aims to harmonise and homogenise national laws, strengthen existing repressive mechanisms and create new mechanisms, i.e. measures that restrict and jeopardise democratic rights and popular freedoms.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ For many years the allegations of corruption and foul play against FIFA have been wide and varied. The resignation of Sepp Blatter and the subsequent criminal investigations will shed light on much of this and will mark a chance for the organisation to clean up its reputation, finding space in the headlines related to football rather than scandal. Clearly there needs to be an investigation into the awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar respectively. A key aim of FIFA is to further the causes of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Few could legitimately argue that a country waging war against a sovereign state and another employing migrant workers with few rights to build the infrastructure for the event itself embody those values. On this note, I think we should also take time to question the value in awarding the inaugural European Games to Azerbaijan by the European Olympic Committee. Civil and human right abuses are well documented in that country and I would question the value in offering any international endorsement to such a regime.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Mr Blatter's resignation will not bring back the 1,200 dead at the World Cup sites in Qatar, nor will he erase the manipulations and malfeasations on which he will one day have to explain himself, hopefully, in court. This decision is good news for ethics and football around the world, but it is not enough.  There is nothing to congratulate him, it is just time to say goodbye to him. Sepp Blatter's position had become untenable. For too long the president of FIFA has taken himself for a puppeteer whose puppeteer we have for too long been the puppets and corrupt football, the theater.  What we wanted to emphasize in this resolution is that a profound reform of FIFA is needed, establishing governance above all suspicions, as well as a just and healthy framework in which athletes around the world can believe and recognize themselves. It is the responsibility of the European Parliament to use all its influence to give a red card to corrupt practices, and to tackle the repeated cheating that allows the diversion of the public interest towards the very particular interest of a minority hungry for power and money in defiance of all ethics.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The recent revelations about FIFA have seriously damaged the integrity of global football and this is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Indeed the organisation needs urgent in-depth structural reforms. It is also important to underline that FIFA is constituted of national federations and among them European ones. Therefore, Member States, in cooperation with Interpol, Europol and Eurojust, should take all appropriate measures to tackle any possible indication of corruption of FIFA officials or of a national football association on EU territory.  By voting in favour of this resolution I also wanted to underline that this scandal is not just another financial crime accomplished by rich and powerful men, but that these actions have a real implication on human rights. The most obvious example is Qatar. The decision to award the 2022 World Cup to a state with a terrible human rights record has a real impact on the people working to build the infrastructure for this competition. This is why I believe the award of the World Cup for 2022 should be invalidated if evidence emerges that the awards only came about as a result of corrupt activities.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The scandal that is affecting fifa's highest levels is astonished. Day by day we are discovering how the organization that regulates the most practiced and loved sport in the world has been managed in a clientelistic way by its managers. Bribes and undue pressures are the opposite of the values of honesty, loyalty and respect that a sport like football should convey. It hurts to know that behind the organization of the last editions of the World Cup, which are usually the most followed sporting event globally, there have been cases of corruption to move decisive votes to the election of the Games. I hope that the world of football will be able to clean up internally and that sport will once again be put at the centre of the debate, not scandals.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support a statement by the Council and the Commission commending the recent revelations of high corruption at FIFA, the world's top football organisation. Since FIFA is responsible for the organization of international football competitions, I believe that its employees must act in accordance with sports principles, and this primarily applies to compliance with the laws and rules of the organization in order to provide all participants of the competition with equal opportunities and thus show their consideration to competitors, but also to spectators. In order to restore the reputation of the organization, and to the viewers and competitors faith in fair football competitions at the highest levels, I believe that it is necessary to punish all participants if proven guilty of fraud, racketeering, money laundering, conclusion of marketing contracts and if embezzlement in multimillion-dollar amounts proves true.  Following the allegations mentioned at the very top of world football in the last 24 years, I welcome the resignation of Sepp Blatter, who was elected FIFA president for the fifth time shortly after his arrest.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution on the recent high-level corruption revelations at Fifa. It is necessary to provide the conditions for the early radical reform of its structures and practices in order to improve its governance and combat corruption in this organisation. The integrity of sports organisations is very important, as both professional and amateur sport play an important role in promoting peace, respect for human rights and solidarity. Companies bring health and economic benefits and play an essential role in highlighting fundamental educational and cultural values and promoting social inclusion. Systematic corruption in Fifa requires the harshest convictions. Football, certainly the most popular sport in the world, has an impact on the daily lives of millions of citizens. Especially in young people, it is extremely popular. Let us make sure that it is not only a source of fun for young people, but also a model of a healthy, honest life.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution with a view to ending the corruption of FIFA in particular, and sporting bodies in general. FIFA has operated opaquely and corruptly for many years and the latest scandals confirm this. We therefore call for improved transparency and accountability, in particular in relation to its decision-making process and the remuneration of its management and management tables. We also believe it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the investigation being carried out by the Swiss and US authorities on the award of the 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 World Cups to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, respectively. And we used to call for the democratization of sports bodies.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution with a view to ending the corruption of FIFA in particular, and sporting bodies in general. FIFA has operated opaquely and corruptly for many years and the latest scandals confirm this. We therefore call for improved transparency and accountability, in particular in relation to its decision-making process and the remuneration of its management and management tables. We also believe it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the investigation being carried out by the Swiss and US authorities on the award of the 1998, 2010, 2018 and 2022 World Cups to France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, respectively. And we used to call for the democratization of sports bodies.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on recent revelations on high-level corruption cases in FIFA as it is important that european institutions play an active role in FIFA reform. It is also important that human rights compliance is called for as a prerequisite for the award of any tournament and that work is being done to end the lack of gender balance in this organization.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the recent revelations of high- level corruption cases in FIFA. We should start investigating the FIFA scandal immediately, as well as the Russian and Qatari World Cup bid; if not the integrity of global football will be damaged even more. I hope that the Commission will continue monitoring the EU anti-money laundering legislation and also make sure that the current legislation is sufficient to fight against corruption in sport.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. The Resolution denounces the facts of corruption in FIFA and the negative impact this has on both football and sport in general. Specifically, it calls for FIFA to carry out a structural reform highlighting transparency and financial guarantees, and to review its statutes and codes of conduct, as well as its decision-making practices.  It also calls for the support of sponsors in this reform process, which stresses that one of the EU's priorities is the fight against corruption, which is also included in sport, and that it will implement all available and necessary resources (Interpol, Europol, Eurojust, European Sport Plan, etc.). For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to combat corruption in football. The case of FIFA reflects how pure commercial interest has replaced any other positive value associated with sport: something we already know in the Spanish state, where urban scandals and non-payments to the Treasury and Social Security in football are the order of the day. However, it is important to note that under FIFA's corruption there is an even more serious reality: the exploitation of slave workers for the benefit of consumption and spectacle in a globalized world, as other multinationals do recognize their profit- There are 1,200 workers killed in Qatar during the preparation of the World Cup: that's the real scandal.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliamentʼs resolution calling for a greater collaboration between all stakeholders, including public authorities, sports associations, athletes and supporters, to urgently and thoroughly address the issue of corruption. I particularly welcome the emphasis the resolution places on the need to promote education and strengthen preventative actions. I strongly agree that FIFA must implement structural reforms in order to bring about transparency and accountability.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Although I condemn all forms of corruption, I abstained from voting on the motion on new revelations of corruption cases at the highest level of FIFA. In my view, it does not fall within the competence of the EU, as FIFA is an independent and international organisation.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The scandal in FIFA has hit during the credibility of world football's governing body. Sport must transmit values and healthy competitiveness, not be dragged into shameful trade that obscures even the clearest victories. FIFA must modernise and accept the international community's scrutiny. That is why I voted in favour of this report and I hope that it will serve as a basis for a healthy debate on sports governance.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The EU Parliament is now responsible for the financial management of an international football organisation. No member of the European Parliament was able to demonstrate that the European Parliament had any Community competence over FIFA during the debate in plenary. Parliament puts its view on the record. My view on this is that there is no need to approve the events at FIFA. But it is first and for the public prosecutor to clarify, evaluate and punish the events. The EU Parliament should stay out of this. That is why I did not vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ It has been deeply disconcerting to witness the FIFA corruption scandal unfold. Integrity is a vital component of sport, strongly linked to the values of solidarity, the promotion of peace and social inclusion that football can engender. This is why we must restore trust in sporting institutions and fight against all forms of corruption. Therefore I voted in favour of Parliamentʼs resolution calling for a greater collaboration between all stakeholders, including public authorities, sports associations, athletes and supporters, to urgently and thoroughly address the issue of corruption. I particularly welcome the emphasis the resolution places on the need to promote education and strengthen preventative actions. I strongly agree that FIFA must implement structural reforms in order to bring about transparency and accountability.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Revelations about corruption at the highest level FIFA demonstrated the state of the whole system. As the most popular sport in the world, raising the hopes of millions of young people, football should be governed by transparent structures, and not as in recent years. Although I think it is a subject that did not belong on the floor of the European Parliament, I commend my colleague, the Belgian Member Iva Belet, for his work on the report on the future of professional football. I supported the resolution because it sends a clear message to current and future FIFA officials.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Swiss authorities arrested 14 FIFA executives in Zurich on 27 May, including the vice-president, arrests requested by the US Department of Justice on charges of money laundering, racketeering, corruption and fraud, amounting to more than $150 million. These investigations have shown that FIFA has operated for many years as an irresponsible, transparent and notoriously corrupt organisation, and that these conditions are systemic, widespread and constant rather than isolated cases of illegal behaviour, as claimed by former FIFA President Joseph Blatter. The arrests of FIFA executives and the resignation of President Blatter have created the necessary conditions for a radical reform of the Federation's structures and practices, so that its governance can be improved and corruption can be combated without delay. It must be considered that the integrity of sports organisations is of fundamental importance, given that both professional and amateur sport plays a key role in the global promotion of peace, respect for human rights and solidarity. Sports governing bodies are committed to applying good governance practices and increasing transparency, reducing the risk of falling victim to corruption.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: In writing ‒ The honesty of sports organisations is very important because both professional and amateur sport play a key role in the global promotion of peace, respect for human rights and solidarity, have health and economic benefits for society and have an irreplaceable role in promoting social inclusion. There are also a number of young people among football fans who look up to footballers as their role models, who inspire them and who want to follow suit. The last thing sport should be associated with is corruption. I believe that pressure from the European Parliament will also help to reform FIFA and restore the credibility of football officials.
